Pours a deep golden orange color with a three finger head that laces out nicely. Aromas are citrus forward with little subtleties of caramel, lemon balm tea and even a bit of earth driven malt. On the palate its big and full bodied with a smooth sweet citrus front end and a bitter grassy finish thats rounded out with some nice caramel malts.

This is a hell of a beer. 

Pours crystal clear copper color with a head that disappates quicky. Strong, sweet citrus hop aroma - everything I expect out of a west coast DIPA. Big hop flavor in the front, but not too acidic (doesnt burn the tongue like other big IPAs) and is balanced out with a ton of caramel/toffee sweetness. Id compare the middle flavor to a really really beastly ESB. 

For how boozy and bitter this is, its balanced surprisingly well and doesnt feel heavy at all. Very, very, very nice.
Aroma is super citrusy. Mandarin orange and grapefruit. Taste follows the same with a mellow malty finish...and slightly dry woody aftertaste.

Chalice at Whole Foods Chandlers Watering Hole. Lovely golden amber with slight head that disappears quickly. Citrus, hoppy nose with malty grain backbone. Sweet forward with hop taste without the bitterness at first, well balanced. Slightly bitter finish. Different from other DIPAs and thats what makes it awesome.
Bottled. Paler in appearance than expected. Brewed without crystal malt. Deeply inviting impressive nose. Peppery on the swallow. Excellent.

Pours burnished gold/amber with medium head that didn?t last. Good lacing. Aroma is pine resin, citrus, grapefruit and earthy. Tastes heavily of pine with little hints of citrus and sweet malt. Finish is dry with and mild earthy astringency.

The head is robust. it smells fantastic, different hoppy, a bit creamy, fruity. The taste is very intensive, different hoppy, a lot of fruits like peach, lemongrass, citrus, a bit grassy. Very good! 12/12/12/12/11/12

pours a clear golden color, with a small amount of white lacy foam.  aromas of pine and citrus.  tastes sweet, with a medium bitterness that lingers.  body is medium, with a sort of oily, long bitter finish.  tastes ideal for a double ipa.  burping up pine is always a good sign.

great stuff; intense flavour of ripe apricots and elderflower, followed by smooth caramel and malt; on the palate its still fruity but becomes more and more malty and a bit spicy; be carefull: its a strong one but you dont really recognize it ;-)

22 oz. bottle.  Pours a clear golden color with a small white head.  The aroma is sweet caramel, citrus, pine resin with some mild cat piss.  The flavor is in line with what a DIPA should be; big caramel, big citrus and resiny hops.  Medium plus body with strong bitterness to the finish.

Pours clear dark yellow with a sticky white head.
Clean aroma of citrus rind and light pine resin.
The flavor is smooth bitterness with a dry finish. 
Just enough sweetness to balance and not sticky sweet like some Double IPAs.

Bottle 07.12.12
Visual: Pours a clear pale golden, with small, quickly-dissipating head.
Aroma: Hops (centennial & simcoe) . 
Taste: Citrus/hop bitterness, medium body, light carbonisation,


Visual:
Aroma:
Taste:

0.65l bottle shared with The Tasting Crew. A treat! This is a clear golden-flower colored one with a small bubbly off-white top. Smells really nice! Sweet caramel, piny hops, some cat piss, apricots and the green part on the strawberry. Smells really nice. Oh, lots of sticky caramel sweetness in the taste, but its quickly balanced by a string pine cone-like bitterness. A Sticky mouthfeel and a soft to average carbonation level. Warming sticky alcohol - that hits many spots. Its clearly not fresh this bottle, but still quite tasty! 26.10.2012
This to me could be the finest example for my taste buds of the perfect American IPA!
Very strong citrus aroma, especially pink grapefruit. Very smooth texture. Has a nice flavour balance as the malt sweetness is not overpowered by the hop bitterness.

Pours a pale, golden yellow, with small, quickly-dissipating head. Strong hop aroma. Flavor is dominated by the citrus/hop bitterness, with a sturdy underpinning of malt. This is one of the good ones!

Pours hazy orange, thin white head. Amazing tangy sweet hops, orange and citrus zest on the nose. Flavour is bitter sweet. hops and citrus orange. Carbonation is quite lively. Another twisty in the finish, with some cinnamon spice. Great beer.

Bottle at home. 
Fantastic aroma, notes citrus, clay, vitrus. 
Clear light amber color, one finger ehite head. 
Smooth taste medium to full body, alcohol, hay, citrus, herbs, a little bit spicy.  
Really nice IPA. 


Bolton Brew Rocks !!

Quite a fiery double IPA.  Lots of balance, despite an over-the-top amount of grapefruit from the hopping.  Caramel, bran and hay dominate the second act of this beer.  Lots of flavor and a long finish.  Very good.  High alcohol isnt entirely hidden, though.
Citrus & pine well balanced, sweet and earthy aromas. Light copper color, clear. Light bodied, piney, earthy flavor -- quite dry. Bitterness not lingering. Tropical fruit flavors. Delicious

Thanks Adam!

The beer appears hazy and light orange hued with an inch of dense, white head. Plenty of lacing coats the walls of the pint glass. The aroma offers some malty sweetness, as well as some hop and citrus notes. The flavor brings forth a huge helping of malt and candied oranges. Strong. Hop presence is there as well, of course, but the flavor seems dominated by malt, candied oranges, and a sweet presence throughout. Thick in body, even a bit syrupy. Alcohol presence is prominent throughout. Overall, an ok beer, but not my thing.

nice amber/gold pour with luscious white head and aromas of pine and grapefruit - on the palate its a nice robust malty flavor with a lingering grapefruit/citrus - this one is an almost perfect blend of malt, alcohol, and hops

Purchased at Evolution Wine & Spirits, enjoyed at home recovering from a crazy workout.  Appearance is a vibrant, glowing gold with a rich, frothy white head.  Aroma is rich in grapefruit notes, caramel malt, and citrusy hops, nothing too out of the ordinary for the style but done very well.  Taste is pretty thick, chewy for a DIPA, moderate bitterness, can tell that it packs a punch, very good balance between caramel malts and hops.  Well done and enjoyable.
Big floral and grapefruit notes.  Pretty aggressive, but stays on an even plain. Good stuff!

UPDATED: AUG 14, 2013 Bottle->SA.  Orange-gold with frothy offwhite head.  A: big citrus and grapefruit hops.  T: bittersweet grapefruit and pine hops.  Rich, almost chewy.  Lingering bitter aftertaste, very pleasant.  Excellent.

This was a nice surprise.  Picked this up recently and fell in love.  Golden with a nice white froth.  As expected, this is a choppy but beautifully balanced DIPA.  Citrus fruit with some sweeter characters make this a must try for hop lovers.

A- slightly cloudy honey golden with a resilient sticky 2 finger head that leaves a lacing that will stay until you wash out the glass.

S- All hops here. Lemon citrus and some faint floral notes... Mostly citrus though. Very nice.

T- All bitter hops up front, very bright citrus notes that give way to some sweeter floral hops in the middle. Not a ton for a malt backbone but enough to make me want another drink sooner than I should, given the high ABV. Finishes with a lasting, wonderful bitterness that youd expect from a big west coast IIPA. 

M- A solid medium body with perfect carbonation, not too oily but not too fizzy. 

O- Very good beer. Not what I expected out of a "double version" of Firestones Union Jack, a beer Im not a huge fan of. Not much for balance, but if thats what youre expecting, youre barking up the wrong tree here... Although I should point out that it isnt as much of a hop bomb as some of the other IIPAs from the west. I highly recommend this one for fans of the regional style.

22oz bottle. Bottled 2/15/12... I should have drank this as soon as I got it... Which was about 2 months ago. Very nice pine citrus hop nose. Impressively big hop flavor still, soapy. Has that malty musty smell that old hops get, but its still aggressively and assertively bitter and hoppy, with a very dry texture. Smooth, crisp lighter carbonation. Dry, with a long soapy hoppy aftertaste. Mildly hazy orange body. Good foamy off-white khaki head. Leaves good bubbly lace. Good, but I probably need to re-rate this fresh sometime. Its bound to be much better
Very clear for an ipa. Golden colour. Aroma is full of citrus and pines. Body is full to medium , taste is piney with caramel in the back. Good bitterness and mouthfeel.

Huge hoppy and vanilla flavours. Citrus mainly.
Very dry finish with a strong bitterness. Clean and lovely DIPA!
no se porque le dan 100 puntos.  esta buena pero tampoco es de pasasrse.  tiene demasiados hops - no mi estilo
Bottle shared by Jeff (mista). Pours a hazy, bright orange with lasting head and nice lacing. Aroma is strong pine and citrus hops. Taste is hops but its well balanced. Nice finish, great DIPA.

22oz bottle, not sure how old it was but maybe a couple months? Nice light orange color, a little lace, short head. Smell was nice but not a super hoppy west coast like I was expecting. It had a touch of alcohol but mostly just had a really balanced smell, a little malt and a little hops. The flavor was very similar, I think I caught a bit of citrus but it was not hop forward at all. the alcohol was noticeable but didnt detract from the flavor. I was actually surprised I enjoyed this as much as I did because I usually only like west coast hop bombs (which this may be when its fresh). Overall this was a nice balanced beer and just reminds me that Firestone Walker makes solid beers.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 05-28-2011 20:16:04

Bottle thanks to Jeff!  Thanks!  Pour is a clear honey gold, with a nice white head that has some sticky lacing.  Aroma is nice punchy white fruit hops, resiny citrus peel, just a bit of pine.  Taste is much the same, with maybe a bit more pine.  Slightly thin.  Nice lingering finish. Great beer.
Taste at Brewdog shoreditch, 7th November 2012 , probably preferred the Redchurch DIPA that I had the same evening
22oz courtesy of GT2/CaptainCougar thanks guys! Lighter orange pour with modest head nose is bright hops and taste just rocks with grapefruit awesome awesome beer

22 oz. bottle: Pours a copperish-orange with a medium off-white head that leaves nice lacing. Citrus aroma has a tangerine presence with hints of grapefruit and pine. Sweet malty flavor is hoppy with a pine presence and a spicy mouthfeel in the mild dry bitterness of the finish. Well balanced and delicious!

22 oz. Bottle from Baltimore. What a great DIPA! Biting pine hop scent with a candied grapefruit undercurrent, the perfect mix. Hazy copper pour with a thick, foamy off-white head. Medium body, slight sticky feel, but mostly a silky texture. The taste kicked off with the candied grapefruit, great sweetness, to a bitter pine hop and back to sweet malt for the finish. Wow.

Bottle shared with (and courtasy of) The Bergen tasting crew, and Gunnar. Pours a golden light amber colour with a medium white head. Herbal aroma with nice hops, apricot, pine and some citrus. Sweet flavours og hops, apricot, sweet berries and some candy. Has an incredibly soft and nice mouthfeel, and a medium bitterness. A well-balanced, sweet and great DIPA.

12 ounce bottle. Resin blasts and lemongrass. Dark yellow appearance with clearly delineated streams of bubbles floating up. An island of foam in the middle of the surface, surrounded with heavy amounts of lacing on the glass. Strong hop flavors jump out and yet the aroma is very mild, grapefruit. 9.5% alcohol is practically undetectable, adding to its drinkability. Light bodied. Double Jack is a tonguebomb thats nice about it.

Draught at Firkin on Paradise, Las Vegas, NVHazy deep blond color; medium sized head. The aroma is piney and resiny. Good toffee flavor, leaner than expected, and without the annoying crystal malt; very moderate residual sweetness; very strong hopping, resiny and piney; long final.Excellent, mostly because its more easy to drink than most beers in the same style.
Pours a clear dark orange, with minimal head.  Aromas & flavors of hops, citrus, grapefruit, tangerine.  Sour, bitter aftertaste.

Shared bottle at BBGTC tasting. Pours clear golden with a small white head. Aroma of oranges and grapefruit, fruity, catpiss light,berries, all in all quite pleasant and inviting aroma. Taste is strong and heavy grapefruit and pine, green hops. Very dry and bitter, ends even more drier, good one.
The high alcohol content creates a perfect bed for the rich malt to meld with the piny hops. Fantastic beer with excellent not over carbonated mouth feel.
650 ml bottle. Nice light reddish brown color. Sweet malt smell and taste. Accompanied by medium hop. Delicious all around.

Bottle: Thanks Andrew:
Medium sized vast creamy head, which changes slowly into vast thick creamy lacing on top of a hazy orange amber colored beer.
Smell hops, citrus, grapefruit, creamy malts, hop liquor, piney soap, strong citrus.
Taste hops, pine, citrus, grapefruit, creamy malts, hops, light spices, creamy.
Aftertaste is hops, bitter, spicy, light dry, malty and light creamy grass.
Low carbo, soft creamy silky spicy mouthfeel, full body and a creamy light oily texture.
Nice beer, not too complex and I am sure that this one fresh is killer.
user_location: Best of E-Town mit 2 Brauhausen, NETHERLANDS

text: UPDATED: JUN 10, 2015 Pours clear golden with nice head. Heavy lacing as head recedes. Huge aroma of honey, citrus and pine. Very similar to Founders Double Trouble or Bells Hopslam. The best smelling beer I have ever encountered, wow! Sweet honey citrus start, with nice hop bite going down. Piney hops aftertaste sticks with you. Nice refreshing mouthfeel, but with slight alcohol warmth. Hides booze extremely well. A new top 5 DIPA for me. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

So glad to see it here in the Illinois Valley area finally. Light amber pour with an off-white head. Wonderful aroma of fruity hops. Taste is a nice balance of malt and hops. Super hoppy but not to a point of too much. Hop flavor sticks to your pallete. Alcohol not noticable until you had several bottles. The flavor sticks in your mouth long after the beer is gone,

Bomber bottle poured a clear golden hue w/ white diminishing head. Strong aromas of hop, pine and citrus. Taste of grapefruit, honey, and floral notes. Initial flavor of sweet with a bitter finish. Warm, creamy mouthfeel and lively carbonation.

UPDATED: NOV 3, 2012 Pours clear golden color with big, disappearing head. Aroma is very intense hop; citrus and piney. Flavor is very intense with a malt and hop balance. Pushing it on bitterness. Finishes moderately bitter.

Appearance was clear orangish caramel honey gold with diminishing off white creamy tiny 1 finger head, spotty head.  Aromas are sweet caramel, crystal, 2-row malts, hops of citrus fruits, herbal and spicey with estery soft yeasts. Taste are hops of grapefruit, orange, lemon, pine, resin, herbs and spice, alcohol hidden well. Palate was smooth creamy CO2 with meduim-full body, the long amazing balanced smooth finish. Excellance in a bottle...

draft- pours clear wildflower honey w/ small white head that recedes to a ring of lace Aroma is perfumey: floral hops, peach, detectable alcohol. Taste is similar. Very good stuff. Mouthfeel is medium/ full & finish is sweet, bitter, & lingering.

very nice citrus hop aroma with a hint of  candylike maltiness..clear orange yellow color with thin white head good lacing..tastes of grapefruit,orange and even lemon with malt mostly for full bodied flavor more than balancing..refreshing perfectly carbonated tingly medium bodied with a bit of stickiness..in short a model of the double ipa style

from notes - snifter pour of light hazed straw with a light white head.  Nose was full of juicy grapefruit, citrus and hops with pine and resin.  Flavor is similar with pine and resin up front, hops and citrus following.  Bitter throughout.  Medium body with light lacing.  Quite amazin.
Poured from a 22 oz bottle shared at home. Almost opaque light amber with a thick frothy head.  Citrus hop aroma.  Tangerine notes. Sweet round finish.

bear vs. griffin thing! who wins.  griffin thing. look at those claws.  pours gold, white head.  nose of fresh pale malt and hoppy goodiness.  mouth: exactly what im seeking, solid clean malt, with fresh green suck in my nose hops. overall, firestone has for me consistently giving fresh tasting brew, yes i live close to the west coast but ive had other cali brews that fail to achieve such a distinction.

Phenomenal beer.   Had it at my 40th birthday in Las Vegas!!   Recommend it to anyone!!!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bomber bought at Super 1 in CDA, ID. Pours crystal clear deep old gold (clearest IPA/Impy IPA Ive ever seen, I think. No hint of haze whatsoever); lacework sheets the glass. Aroma is catboxy, grapefruity, hint of coconut (wha??). This is how I like my imperial IPAs to smell like--nice and hoppy, limited malt presence, and most importantly, no vegetation! Taste is bittersweet with a lingering bitter finish; flavor is citrusy backed by honeyed bready malt. Carbonation is soft, body full. Nice one, but it doesnt top Port Brewings Hop 15 as far as recent Imperial IPAs Ive tried. This is one of those beers where you relish a good belch...nice resinous hoppy flavor comes back up onto the palate...disgusting, I know.

I like my IPAs a little hoppier in the nose than this was. That said, it was otherwise a very spectacular beer. Kinda creamy mouthfeel, great bitterness,  alcohol very well hidden. I would definitely buy this again if it wasnt so expensive in Germany. (11 per 650ml bottle)

Has big bold scents of hops, sweet and malty notes as well. Taste is a nice balance of malt and hops, has a nice bitter hop flavor, smooth finish.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Had on tap at Palmer Place. Served in a tulip.

A: Pours a slightly hazy copper color with a nice off-white head. Sticky lace follows me down the glass.

S: Nice notes of citrus and some grassy with a little grapefruit.

T: Citrus smoothness, some grapefruit with a nice fruity sweetness up front. The malt body comes through in the middle and finishes a little bitter hops bite.

M: Medium to light bodied with a coating quality to it. Nicely carbonated.

O: Very solid offering from FW. The flavors blended together nicely. I havent been disappointed by any of their offerings yet.

Serving type: on-tap

Reviewed on: 10-16-2011

Aroma - Sweet, a bit of pine and citrus
Appearance - Clear Orange, minimal head
Taste - lightly to medium sweet
Palate - Medium body, thin texture with soft carbination and lightly bitter finish.
Other notes: served in 12oz snifter, ten minutes after in fridge. Very well balanced beer. Great IIPA if youre not looking to get your tongue kicked in by hops. Another great beer by FSW. Cheers!

Pours clear amber with a thick white head and lots of lace. Aromas are wonderful fruity hops. Taste follows suit with the aroma, tons of bitterness, medium body well hidden alcohol. This is a palate wrecker!

pours a clear amber-orange with a medium size off-white head, and good lacing.

smell is of citrus, hops, a touch floral, and caramel in the back.

taste is clean, citrus, hops, a touch of pine, caramel, and a malt back.  ends nicely bitter.

Bottle at Bens. Thanks Craig. Light Amber with a white head. Aroma is tropical with lots of Pines and some caramel. Not wildly bitter. Well balanced and not particularly radge. Safe by IIPA standards.

A showcase for hops which are wonderfully aromatic and flavorful without excessive bitterness. The hops are nicely balanced by the malt and perhaps the alcohol content. The grapefruit nose comes through in the taste and is a real plus for me.

UPDATED: JUN 29, 2013 Growler from Bowery Whole Foods: Pours a rich golden with pretty good clarity and a strong off white head. Huge bouquet- huge pine, bright citrus and lychee. Has a nice velvety body. Smooth carbonation and firm body without being sticky nor cloying. Big flavor with lots of citrusy hops, lychee, a firm doughy malt back (subtle) and a huge long bitter piney finish. Very clean and hoppy. A great westcoast IIPA.

Keg at BrewDog. Bright orange golden pour, thin white bubbles. Big grapefruit, light pineapple, big pine resin on the nose. Rich, resinous pine, grapefruit, maybe a little too much caramel malt, big boozy resin on the finish. Pretty standard American DIPA.

22 oz bottle: Pours a light orange with a thick white head and mounds of CO2 release. Nice aroma of grapefruit and some spruce hops, nice caramel malts. Taste is amazingly sharp, clear, citrus hops and good malt balance. Very smooth to drink, does not feel like a DIPA. Amazingly good beer!
Another winner from this brewery. Love it. Puts a little light. The color is deceiving looks weak. But certainly proved me wrong. Worth finding, worth buying.

Rate #800
Keg @ BrewDog Edinburgh 280912
Bronze amber, clear, bubbly white head that dissipates
Aroma - citrus hops, some grassy hops, lots of hops, background of sweet soft caramel malts, alcohol noticeable
Taste as aroma. citrus hops, orange, grapefruit, herbal aromatic notes. Not that fruity...maybe its a bit old, rich malt backbone, booze quite noticeable
Palate - medium carb and body. Finish quite boozy, complex tail of alcohol, bit herbal with some tropical fruits, fairly bitter dry hop, slight metallic note
Overall - Maybe its me but it didnt bowl me over, its a pretty good. beer but nothing amazing. Maybe its a lot better out of the bottle.

Slightly chilled 12oz bottle, poured into a tulip glass. 1/4" sudzy white head with good amount of lattice. Color is a light mahogony almost orange. Aroma is a wave  of various citrus, clover, spice, and some dark buckwheat honey. Zest fizzy entry hits you with crispness, then the afore mentioned middle backbone of malt, which has a toasted raisen breadish element, as well as honey, and burnt  sugar. But not too sweet at all. Then citrusy hops of tangerine , orange, even  dark cheery hit you. Medium mouthfeel, not hard to drink, and yes alcohol is well masked but there is a small burn there. Long lasting complex finish, a beer to be savored and reflceted upon with each sip.

Pours a bright red with a medium white head.  Heavy aroma with pine, grapefruit, pineapple, some lime, and a good amount of floral hops.  Taste is huge in pine and grapefruit, caramel undertones, and an excellent hoppy punch.  Very bitter.  Strong and long lasting aftertaste of pine, hops, and a bit of grapefruit.  More full in body and very sticky when drinking.  This one is a wonderful effort in this style.  It is a very extreme offering that doesn't disappoint.  Try this.
22 oz bottle from AJs in Phoenix.  Pours bright, golden amber in colour, lots of white frothy head, which leaves tonnes of lacing.  Huge piney, citrusy and floral hops.  Big beer, hint of alcohol.

On tap at Brewdog Camden. A transparent golden coloured ale. Thin off-white head. Floral aroma with citrus fruits, especially tangerine and lime then honeydew melon and avocado. Full bodied. Bitter flavour with ripe cantaloupe, pine, damp wood and earth, tropical fruits, biscuit and tea. Long, moderately bitter finish. Overall, very balanced and very tasty.

Bottle sample.
Clear deep yellow color, nice head.
Amazing aroma of fruits (citrus, melon, lime), grass and earth.
Alcoholic flavor with high bitterness.
Medium body, oily, long finish.

Nice clear deep golden, orange with a nice off white fluffy head that disappears quickly. Aroma is very hoppy with  nice piney, grapefruity notes. Taste is very balanced. I get a nice maltforward body with a slight caramel sweetness. And of course there is a big hop profile onj this on with grapefruit and piney notes. I also get some orange, tangerine, other fruits that I cant pinpoint. A nice balanced DIA with a good hop profile!

Absolutely delicious. Poured from a bottle from LetsPour. Poured an amber gold with small head. Very well balanced DIPA, possibly a new favorite.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

22 ounce bottle.  Pours a clear golden amber with an average off-white head.  Aroma of citrus, florals, grass, and malt.  Taste is citrus fruit, grass, florals, pine, and light malt.  Well balanced.  Good stuff!!

Huge hop aromas and flavors of tangerine, grapefruit, citrus zest, cat pee and florals, with rich layers of honeyed malt bread. Rich, concentrated and balanced. Long, lingering flavors of tangerine, citrus rind, honey and cling to the palate. A classic IIPA. Nothing surprising, though nothing wrong. A dependable beer.

--- tasted while on a long journey to understand the world around me...

a very delicious double ipa i think this one wasnt as fresh so the hop aroma had died down and could have been better. in fact i have had fresher or tap beers that were more crisp and aromatic. but still one of the best double ipas

In bottle at Bens. Pours a dark golden colour with a fair tan head. Aroma of pine, pineapple, passion fruit, caramel and alcohol. Similar flavours with mild carbonation and an oily mouth-feel. Fairly bitter. Lovely.

Bottle, thanks Craig. Amber with white head. Massive resin pine aroma, caramel, grapefruit, peach. Taste is similar, pine, sharp citrus fruits. Nice bitter finish. Enjoying it more the more I drink. Very nice
bottle at home ...amber... big white head ... soft floral zezty pepper orange hop nose ... very juicy fruits ... orange fruits ... mellow nice sofe peachy

Well, lets just start by saying that this is pretty much as close to perfection as a DIPA comes in my book. I have held my breath for about 3 years waiting to get a bottle of this and would like to thank the GBBF 2012 for getting this to our shores, and better still getting it here as fresh as possible. 22oz Bottle. Pours deep, warm gold with a copper/amber hue. Big fluffy white head which reduces to  decent covering a few cms high. Aroma is a big pine/tropical fruit fest. Comes on strong with the aroma of pine, hop resin, mango, tangerine, honey, flowers. It just smells the part, most of all the aromas are as clean as a whistle, no smudgy malt here, the malt is crisp as are all other aromas. Flavour enters on an equally resinous note with pine to the fore giving way to lovely tropical fruits, certainly with notes of blood orange, more tangerine, mango, and some nice citrus qualities as well. Its backed up with just the right amount of caramel and light toffee sweetness to balance the lovely hoppiness. The malt is of a soft and almost delicate honeyed style, just there to support the hops, its what keeps the beer so fresh feeling. Finish is all about subtle resin notes, a hint of earthiness which I think has crept in since the first bottle I had a month ago (how quickly our beloved hops begin to turn)  and classical citrus rind, grapefruit and so on. The reason I rate this beer so highly is its drinkability. This drinks like a 7.5% IPA. I hate when DIPAs become to chewy or thick and malt dominant. This is a true west coast expression and a monument to how to sculpt a great DIPA. This could have been stupidly hopped, but theres just enough restraint to make this a true class act rather than a novelty DIPA. Hats off to FstW. You guys rule. I have a 2011 Parabola thats been sitting in my collection for 1 year and a quarter, I look forward to it whole hartedly. Any hop head or appreciater of fine wares has to seek this beer out and drink it, I urge you, you will not be disappointed. Selah.
Pretty incredible beer. Affordable, considering how delicious it is. Great flavor with a lovely hoppiness and a crisp finish. Dark amber color for an IPA, easy to find.

Tap at Alewife Queens. Pale amber pour with a nice tight white head. The aroma is very bright and peppery. A bit of sweet toasted malt and a lot of pine and citrus character. A touch of grapefruit and some sweet lightly estery character. A touch of pepper and some bright dry-hopped resinousness. Awesome stuff.
Bottle.  Aroma of grapefruit and some tropical fruits.  Nothing really stands out in the flavor.  Just a little too much sweet flavor mixed with bitterness.

Pours a high carbed light apricot in color with a fizzy/foamy head. Aromas of citrusy/pine/grapefruit hops, apricot, slight peach candy, and caramel behind all the copious hops. Flavors upfront remind me of peach flavored candies I used to have when I was a kid with peach flavored syrup in the middle. Theres some apricot, citrus, grapefruit, some herbal and caramel malt to back it all up decently. Has a more noticeable malty note than the union jack ipa. Seems to have less of a bitter aftertaste than the union jack as well. Medium sweet. No alcohol noticed. Great Dipa.
Have been a fan of Firestone Walker and had been wanting to try this. Met my expectations, subtle cherry in the usual citrus and pine, nice.

Deep golden color with a nice egg white head. Carmel dominates the aroma. Very smooth flavor that includes some hopes, Carmel and finishes with a great bitterness!

Thinker

Pours a clear bright golden orange color with a nice thick head that lingers.  Aroma is fruity, malty and hoppy all together.  Getting oranges, grapefruit, pineapple, cherries, caramel malt, flowers, and some herbal spiciness.  Taste is sweet fruit and caramel at the beginning.  Big hop bitterness takes over the middle and it turns somewhat dry and malty in the finish.  An earthy and floral taste lingers a long time.  This is my kinda Imperial IPA.  Reminds me a lot of Avery The Maharaja.  Complex, fruity, funky, malty, hoppy, everything all in one beer.  Great.

Bottle at my Cousins house, PA - 21/05/12.
Slightly hazy deep orange with a white head.
Hoppy, piney nose bursting with citrus.
Grapefruit and citrus on the palate allied to sweet malts in the background.
Medium bodied, average caronation, smooth and easy to drink.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: Pours a clear, medium gold with minimal white head that builds a bit from the bottom after sitting for a minute.  Hoppy pine aroma with sweet malts.  Good body in the mouth without being syrupy at all, which often happens with double IPAs.  Nice hops around the side of the tongue, but nicely balanced with malts and grassy pine undertones.  This is a very good beer.  Lots of good flavor but not overpowering in any one area.

One of my favorites from the first sip. Golden colored. Some citrus fruit flavors. Malty. Balanced. Reminds me of a Chimay. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: OCT 15, 2013 22 oz. bottle poured into a pint glass.

A: Pours a medium amber color with fantastic clarity. The head is a three finger white color thats textured beautifully, and retains itself quite well.

S: Its a typical DIPA aroma, with grapefruit, pine, and herbal hop qualities, but behind the hops is an underlying layer of sweetness, much like the draught version I had several months back. Fairly citrusy in general, which I always enjoy.

T: Initially, the flavors are citrusy sweet. Its far more orange-y than many other IPAs Ive had, and even evokes sucking on an orange slice. Afterwards, it reverts back to a more piny, peppery finish, with low to moderate bitterness. Also, the maltiness becomes less sweet caramel and more neutral breadiness. All good so far...

...except for one problem - its too boozy. It doesnt necessarily remind me of drinking straight up Orange Glo, but it comes across like 11.5% rather than 9.5%. The hop complexity of Union Jack is still there, at least. Take out the aggressive booziness, and this would be an easy 4, or even a 4.5, but as it stands right now, its disappointingly average. Positively, the booziness calms down a bit, being replaced with more piny, resinous hops near the bottom of the glass.

M: Im losing my patience with syrupy IPAs, and sadly this fits the bill. The finish is heavy handed in its sticky wetness, and the dryness of the hops fail to balance things out; but other than that, the mouthfeel is fine in terms of carbonation and texture.

O: There are some fantastic qualities here, but the harsh, boozy, syrupy nature of this beast really kills its chances at greatness. The best way to enjoy this is to drink it cold and split it with friends. Its worth a try - especially on tap - but it was a disappointment for me.
Pours a golden amber color with a white head and excellent lacing.  Aroma of citrus, pine, and caramel.  Well-balanced flavor of caramel, pine,grapefruit, and tangerine.  Just exceptional!

Aroma is a sweat Carmel with piny citrus and a little hint of alcohol. Pours a dark orange color with off white head leaves a nice lacing and very carbonated. Taste is kind of sweet floral with a little pine. Very clean on the tounge goes down smooth for being 9.5%. Overall this is a very great beer I found at the liquor store in salt lake.
Bomber. These Firestone guys have yet to disappoint......another stellar beer. This specific one is toward the top of my list of IIPAs. I tiny bit too malty but otherwise awesome.

Bottle at home. Hill Farmstead Glass. Fridge Temp + a few degrees.

A - Clear golden grown, white head.

S - Lots of malts, big nice smelling malts. Burning hop bitterness. Lots of grapefruit and citrus. Hint of pine cones.

T - Wow. Alright, aside from the obvious that a 9.5% IIPA is "malty", its a big beer. It lingers for a long time with huge maltiness like eating croutons. I get lots of grapefruit and tangerine peels. I get some pineapple and lots of pine sap. finish is this floral sort of relaxed light flowery delicious aftertaste that coasts my mouth. Very nice!

M - 20% carbonation, medium body (surprisingly). VERY bitter. 

O - Its lacking the balance of Heady topper or the bitterness of Pliny but its a solid offering in the big IPA category.

Bomber courtesy of GT2. Thanks man! Pours tiny hazy golden with a small frothy and creamy offwhite head that is rather quick to dissipate while leaving a thick trace on the glass. Smell is slightly sweet, hoppy, fruity and tiny herbal with bread, orange zest, pine, mango, pineapple, peaches, lemon zest, lemon balm, lemon grass, crackers, lime juice, grapefruit rinds and fresh grass. Taste is slightly sweet, bitter and fruity with mango, pineapple, cape gooseberries, lychee, lemon balm, grapefruit juice, unripe peaches, wine gums, gooseberries, bread, alcohol, orange zest, lemon zest, crackers, pine, resinous wood and grapefruit rinds. Mouthfeel round, oily bitter, tiny astringent, tiny dry and near full bodied. Finish is tiny sweet and bitter with bread, pine, grapefruit juice, moist soil, unripe mango, unripe pineapple, orange zest, lemon zest, crackers, green grapes and hints of gummi candy. Very nice...

Bottle at Mumsig Miniprovning, Göteborg. Golden beer with a small offwhite head. Pineapple aroma, mango, grapes, pear, orange, bready, biscuits, hay, metal notes, salty, peach notes. Hoppy grassy flavor, mango, woody, pine needles, mango, some perfume, citrus, floral notes, metal, dill notes. Malty finish, lovely hops, pineapple and other tropical fruits.

Bottle @MMP. Pours ckear pale amber with a small off white head leaving some lacing. Aroma is fresh fruity piny citric a bit tropical some touch of perfume and a stable maltyness. Flavor is malty sweet caramel fruity piny resiny citric bitter pungent. Finishes sweet bitter malty. So damned good.
Pours a golden amber with a two finger head that fades quickly. Nose is pine with mild citrus. Taste is the same but with a sweet malt balance. Excellent beer! I will be buying this again.

Pours a peachy gold with a 2 finger, slightly chunky off white head. Aroma is big on toast, biscuit, and caramel, with some cereal and grainy notes right away, the hops coem in a bit light, but pleasant, floral, citrus, light tropical and a hint of tart berry bite. Flavor is sweet caramel, light toffee, biscuit, sweet malt, cereal dusty hay, then the hops, sweet and bitter citrus, some pine, light tropical, floral and hints of pine to the finish along with something that tastes a bit like I would imagine reduced, mixed melon juice tastes like. Medium body, sugary entry to slick, slightly dry finish with a moderately coarse, light carbonation. Good stuff, though it seems like it may be a little past its prime, but the date stamp is not properly applied, so its impossible to tell, though I am fairly sure it was bottled @ 16:55.

Gold, quick-fizz eggshell head, blast of sweet citrus aroma.  Upon closer inspection, aroma also has bitter pine elements and light malt caramel.  Flavor is equal parts pine sap and orange/grapefruit citrus.  Light malt sweetness is generally overshadowed here.  Somewhat boozy and hot, especially after sitting for a while.  Medium-thick body with coarse carbonation.  A great IPA; the aroma makes it!  But the bitterness (when warm) is just too much for a great score.

One of the best beers Ive had this year!  Fullness of the hop experience tempered with an ample dosing of malted sweetness.  Aggressive assault from start to finish, though never unbalanced and never too much.  Grapefruit, pine, resin, and even some caramel.  Delish.

Ar: Musty - grapefruit citrus, resiny, herbal hops - tid bit of alcohol
Ap: Translucent, deep honey amber - frothy white head that dissipates rather quickly to a fine frothy lacing 
T: Follows the nose perfectly -really well balanced 
P: Great DIPA mouthfeel - medium to full bodied with soft carbonation
O: Smells skunky wonderful, looks beautiful, fantastic balance

(bottle sample from a friend) Poured cool, a hazy bright golden orange with a decent white head. Strong aroma of grapefruit, pine, and some tropical fruit from the hops, a little malt sweetness with a hint of grain. Smells gorgeous and inviting with no trace of alcohol. Early in the palate that same combination of juicy hop flavours comes through, with a little malt and bittering hops balancing each other out. This turns into pine hops and more malt sweetness and bread with lingering fruit, and finishes dry but not bracingly bitter, the pine resin and caramel malt and alcohol all balanced out. Mouthfeel is medium with pleasingly soft carbonation. Smooth and well-integrated with a delightful nose and the alcohol well-hidden, more DIPAs should be so balanced and drinkable in my opinion.

A - Pours a hazy golden-orange color with a finger of frothy white head. The head fades down fairly slowly leaving behind some nice lacing.

S - Aroma is full of grapefruit, pineapple, pine, and citrus hops, sweet caramel malts, and some biscuit.

T - Starts off with grapefruit, pineapple, and citrus hops with some bitterness and some sweet caramel malts. Through the middle, lots of pine hops come through with more bitterness and a bit more caramel malts. The finish is a mix of grapefruit and pine hops with some resiny bitterness and some sweet caramel malts and a touch of booze.

M - Medium-plus bodied with moderate carbonation. Feels smooth with a dry, bitter, and resiny finish.

D - Very drinkable. Very nice hops profile and bitterness and the overall balance is spot on.

Bomber - honey gold in color with a decent white head and nice lacing on the glass. Has a strong citrus nose and a great hoppy flavor to it. It has a nice medium-heavy mouthfeel and while it has a dry finish its not overdone. Definitely one of the better DIPAs out there.

This is a solid DPA.  Pours golden honey with a hue of orange and light lacing of white head.  Huge aroma of hoppy citrus (grapefruit/orange), malty caramel, and a dab of basil.  Medium body of perfectly balanced caramel malt with a touch of sweetness, and bitter citrus that is just slightly resiny.  Finish is smooth and clean with a light lingering of bitter orange peel.  Insanely balanced and drinkable for 9.5% ABV.

Aroma is pure and clean hops. The maltiness in this one is more subdued, probably due in large part to the high alcohol content. It's a nice balance. The hot split the pallet just right and lingers a bit but it never feels too overwhelming for the style.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: FEB 8, 2015 A perfectly balanced IPA, with caramel maly mingling with tons of grapefruit and orange citrus/ tropical fruits here, finishing with an intense piney hop background and a spicy undertone. Smooth and balanced, with hops lingering long, with very little trace of heat. Yummy stuff.

UPDATED: AUG 5, 2012 This is about as perfect a double IPA as I have tried. I am a huge Stone Ruination fan, but in a slightly less macho way, I think this is better. Pours a beautiful amber, with a lacy head that paints the glass as you drink it (rapidly). Aroma is strongly citrus, mostly grapefruit. The finish is bitter and at the same time flowery-fruity, and it doesn?t leave you puckering like the Ruination. Overall a beautiful, quaffable beer for hop lovers.

No mistaking this beer on the nose.  Hoppy character jumps out of the glass and smacks you in the face asking for its money.  Nice dark amber color to it but the head leaves a bit to be desired.  The taste is hops through and through with a touch of raw dough.  Grapefruit pith, burnt citrus and pine needles leave a great bitter ending that lingers around.

Aroma is big, piney hops with strong grapefruit and citrus notes. Massive earthy/leafy bittering hops with a pleasant fruity zest. Very bittering hops with a formidable bready malt base falling into a strong presence of alcohol. Overall, this is a serious brew with massive hops. Id give this an A+ rating.

bomber picked up in vacation in CA; i got more piney than citrus in aroma.  thick palate - taste - definitely felt the hop kick and booze; the more I drank the better it got (it packs a punch) - very hoppy but not bitter with strong malts; this leans to the hop side; well made beer but too much to be my fav ipa..

On tap at Flying Saucer in KC on 7/21/2012.  Pours a clear golden orange with a thick off white head.  Aroma is hops, malts, and citrus.  Taste is piney and bitter with a malty and honey sweetness.  Awesome beer.

750 ml bottle. Pours a yellowish dark brown with a nice white head. Smells like citrus, flowery hops and fruits. Tastes like citrus, cereals, caramel. Quite sweet. Nice citrus finish, very resilient citrus taste. Medium bodied. Very good IPA.
Bomber from BevMo. Highly hopped nose. Some pine and citrus with a little sweetness. Full flavored hoppiness. Very well balanced with a solid maltiness. Finish is grapefruit. Very good brew.
Floral, piney hops on the nose. Nice dark golden hue. Good balance in the flavor, with a little sweetness. A little too carbonated.

Pours clear copper orange with a substantial white head. The aroma explodes with citrus and pine and a very subtle hint of light sweet malt. Taste is strong bitter, with some solid tropical fruit flavors. Medium-bodied with a smooth texture and mild mouth-carbonation, Firestone Walker Double Jack IPA finishes with a spicy bitterness.
Great head with a dark golden color, nice aroma with great hop kick.  Doesn't get better that this.
The hop bill on this one was very good, but there was nowhere near enough malt to carry it through. this one was a bit too hop water-like for my tastes.

Growler - fresh as the day is long.  Pours a light amber with a thick, white foamy head. Nice lacing. Aroma is bready, piney grapefruit. A nice lingering bitterness in the taste. The ABV is apparent, but not overwhelming. A very solid DIPA offering that I could see leading to trouble ;)

Hop juice for the hop lover. Insane amounts of citrus, pine, and sticky resins. 
Solid malts, chewy, and bready. Heavy bitterness, really intense. Solid tropical fruit, and grapefruit in the finish, with loads of pine resins. Really a solid balanced DIPA.
Its hoppy, stuff and junk. Im not a huge fan of this brewery. High ABV is pleasant, and balanced by hop and malt body,
Bottle pours a clear golden with a small white head. Scent is pine, grapefruit, and floral. Taste is citrus, grassy, caramel and pine.

Poured at a good temperature with a large, foamy, cream-colored head that subsided after a bit and lots of lace. Color is a clear yellow amber. Aroma is resin, hop, malt, grain. Flavors like nose, carbonic tang up front, follow immediately by bitter/sweet and the other components. Body and carbonation are perfect for style. Finish is like flavor, long, and super drinkable. Its a lets git it beer.

Bottle: Poured an amber color ale with a large foamy head with good retention and some good lacing. Aroma of citrus and piney hops notes is quite dominant with some dry caramel malt with some residual sugar also noticeable. Taste is a hops forward mix of citrus notes with light piney notes with some bitterness. Malt backbone offset some of the hops presence with light residual sugar notes. Body is quite full with good carbonation. Solid beer though I was expecting more floral hoppy notes.

22oz bomber. Pours pale orange with medium head. Aroma is pineapple hops. Taste is big sweet fruity hops with boozy lighter malt body. Incredible citrus flavor from this beer. Huge body without being heavy at all. Really delicious for a DIPA.

22oz bottled March 15, 2012.  Served at around 40-45F.

Pours clear amber with a three finger off-white head that leaves some nice rings and webs of sticky lacing and holds a real nice cap.

Aroma is grapefruit, orange/tangerine, floral hops, some pineapple, apricot, decent bit of caramel malt, some alcohol.  Very good strength.

Flavor is juicy orange, tangerine, grapefruit, apricot, resinous hops, some pine, caramel malt in the middle with a bit of sweetness, finishes with good bitterness and a noticeable alcohol burn.  As I get further into the bottle: apricot, caramel, alcohol.

Mouthfeel is medium to full bodied, oily, sticky, good carbonation.

A big ol Double IPA, thats for sure.  Pretty good stuff, albeit with 4 months on it.  Could imagine how good this would be if super fresh.  Other than the age, the only real knock is the booze...this one is fairly hot for the style.

Little heavy. Great fruit flavor and spectacular aroma.  Big grapefruit taste is welcomed after the bite from the 9.5% alcohol 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

This is exactly how I like my beers. Hoppy, bitter and light malts. Pours golden caramel with a small white head. Little to no aroma but could be from the inadequate glass. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. Incredible scent of citrus is a powerful starting point of this fantastic IPA. I love Union Jack IPA, but I love this even more. Incredible hop flavors mingle perfectly with a deep maltiness. No overwhelming bitterness, but certainly distinct. A nice balance between bitter and sweet, fruity and malty. Outstanding. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

12 oz bottle. Had a sample of this at a craft beer tasting a week ago, thought it was good enough to get a full bottle of. Pours an effervescent light bronze color with a small off-white head. Smells of hops, fresh citrus, malt, and a bit of earthiness. Taste is very strong; definitely tastes the tangerine, good hops presence, and you can taste some alcohol warmth. Full bodied flavor, though Im not sure I like the tangerine/grapefruit citrus combo (not bad, but a bit different). Overall a very impressive beer.

On draft at Henrietta MacGregors. Pouts a clear yellow with a white head. Nose is sweet malt, citrus hops, and slight pine. Flavor is similar with citrus and sweet malt all over. A nice double ipa. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: MAR 29, 2016 Tap at Todd English Pub on the Strip. Clear amber with a good sized off-white head and nice lacing. Huge citrus aroma over pale malts and florals. Taste is plenty bitter, but theres a nice balance as well. Medium bodied. Excellent.

Bottle.  A transparent golden coloured ale.  Thin off-white head.  Floral aroma with citrus fruits, especially tangerine and lime then honeydew melon and avocado.  Full bodied.  Bitter flavour with ripe cantaloupe, pine, damp wood and earth, tropical fruits, biscuit and tea.  Long, moderately bitter finish.  Thanks Peter for sharing this one!

Pours brilliant crystal clear deep straw.  Really nice aroma,  sharp and rounded. Flavor is hoppy but smooth hoppiness  it really is well done.  Lingering hops all the way to the finish.  Really great beer.  Does not show its 9.5%.

Poured from a 22 ounce bomber into a goblet. No freshness info on bottle. I suspect that it was rubbed off.

Appearance: Pours a clear light golden-amber color with yellow-orange highlights and a 2 finger fluffy eggshell head. Very nice lacing.

Smell: Sweet citrus with a touch of pineapple and grapefruit and hints caramel and candied malts. Theres just a whiff of alcohol in the aroma. Smells delicious.

Taste: Bitter grapefruit and caramel malt up front followed by resinous piney hops and a mild candied sweetness in the middle before ending with lemon zest and pine at the finish. Aftertaste is bitter with a touch of sweet citrus and is quite long-lasting. The alcohol is subdued and just creeps through at the finish.

Mouthfeel: Medium-to-full-bodied with a decent amount of carbonation. The tongue gets coated with hop oils which leave a sort of film which, in this case, is a good thing.

Drinkability: Very good drinkability. Im savoring this one and will have no problem finishing the bomber. 

Overall: Excellent beer overall. Id love to try one that I know is fresh to be able to see if I missed anything. I found this one to be great, so if it gets better than this youre in for a real treat. Try it.

Poured into tulip.  Nice head retention.  Orange with good clarity.  Awesome lacing.  Big fragrant citrus and fruit monster.  Bit of spicy juniper in there as well.  Good malt backbone with carmel notes.  A bit woody in the nose.  Intensely bitter and juicy, with a long, lingering citrus and mango finish.  All the malt to back this up.  Not a trace of alcohol present.  Every conversation concerning the top DIPAs in the world needs to have this in it.

UPDATED: SEP 19, 2013 Poured from bottle. Beautiful clear amber color. WOW. The aroma is wonderful: floral, citrus, pine, a very complex smell. Fruity, but not overwhelming. Hoppy, but not too much. The taste is smooth, lightly sweet, but hoppy. There is a malty smell/taste that provides some body, but not too thick. Surprising alcohol at 9.5%, but you will never know. Overall this is an impressive DIPA. It has moved into my favorite category. (6/24/2012) I bumped my rating of this beer up. I had it again (12/27/2012), and it was every bit as good if not better than I remembered. That often does not happen.
Amazing aroma of pine, honey, vanilla, grapes, citrus. Golden colour with not a lot of head. Taste is well balanced, bitter and sweet, citrus. Awesome DIPA.

Not as hoppy as a lot of double IPAs but the hops are nice and floral with a great malt sweetness. Easy to drink but packs a punch. Great beer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
This is one of my favorite DIPAs, golden pour with a white head, Citrua and hoppy with some caramel malts on the nose, wonderful hoppiness on the flavor and smooth and creamy.  This beer is awesome.

UPDATED: AUG 21, 2014 65cl, as Double Jack Double IPA, American brew, from De Hopduvel Gent, very complex bitter brew, bitter/sweet and slightly fruity, heavy, yet balanced, hazy, good head, very good brew, yet expensive!

Poured from 22oz bomber, pours a crystal clear light golden/orange with a thin head and some lacing, the arom has a ton of citrus and hops, the flavor has a dank wet hop front end with some citrus and mango in the finish, nice mouthfeel, very smooth.  It hides the 9.5% extremely well, good stuff.

[bottle]
Potent hops aroma of pine, cat pee, currants, pineapple, and a little citrus. Almost clear deep gold under a lasting, off-white cover. Intense hops flavour that comes in with some base malt sweetness and ending with an assertive but not quite harsh hops bitterness. Some of the sweetness is probably from ethanol. Complex flavour includes apricot, pine, ethanol, cat pee, and other resinous hops notes. Medium to full body, medium carbonation, residual bitterness in the finish.

Pours a golden amber colour, clear with a frothy off-white head. Aroma is quite hoppy with noticeable citrus fruit undertones and some caramel malt. Not very sweet or bitter, but it is consistent and balanced with a slightly greater bitter bite. Creamy mouth feel, medium body and softer carbonation. Overall an awesome double IPA.
Tap @ Pony w James. Fresh pine aroma, fresh pine palate. Tons of fresh hop. A quintessential imperial IPA. Straight-forward, bold.

On tap and snifter served at Lunar Brewing Co., displaying a clear & bright golden color, creamy, off white head foam, and a band of clingy lacing at the rim that broke up somewhat as the liquid decreased. The aroma was expressive pine and citrus as orange & pungent grapefruit, smooth malt and complementary sweetness. Medium+ body, some creaminess to the mouthfeel, warming alcohol from the start, medium, earthy, tanniny, lingering astringency, and decent malt content to balance described the flavor. The finish offered some sweetness, but was mainly bitter, crisp, and dry. Very impressive!

Clear gold with rocky white head. Nice lace. Big hoppy nose of orange, grapefruit, and pine. Flavor follows with just a touch of caramel malt. A little soapy and perfumey. Big bitterness. Light mouthfeel. Good drinker for DIPA.

Wow! This one is definitely a keeper. Im not a huge fan of DIPAs, mainly because the alcohol takes over. But this is a beautifully crafted ale. The alcohol only makes its presence known late into the finish.

Very well done. Menu was actually very vague and didnt list much about this beer, and it was on tap. Aroma of clean fresh hops. Medium-heavy bodied and very tasty and drinkable. Smooth smooth smooth. I actually didnt even know this was an imperial until I looked it up afterwards.

Pours straw with a thick creamy head. Aroma is light hops, with a sweetness. Flavor is tart, nice and sweet and very boozy.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

22oz bottle.  Pours a clear amber color with a thick, rocky head that rapdily dissipates. Aroma has lots of grapefruit, floral, orange peel, grass, big caramel maltiness, and biscuit.  Taste has lots of complex malts, honey, caramel, grapefruit, and bittering hops.   Medium bodied with a nice hop kick. Light carbonation. Very drinkable for 9% abv.

22 oz bottle.  Pours a bright amber with a slightly off-white head.  Fresh citrus and pine aroma with honey and caramel.  Strong, resinous pine and citrus hops, touches of tropical fruit, some sweetness.  Very fresh and tasty.
A perfect example of an American double IPA, citrusy floral aromas medium bitterness.  Measure others by this.

An intense grapefruit, citrus and slightly floral aroma. Golden straw in color, and a very well-balanced body and bitterness. This beer showcases the cascade hop very well, and the fruity hop flavor is really representative of what an American IPA should showcase. Win.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle. Deep clear orange with a thick head. Aroma is super bitter hop. Flavour is deep citrus, grapefruit with a tremendous lingering finish. Strength is hidden very well

Absolutely fantastic brew.  Color is golden amber.  Smell of citrus, spicy hops, mild pine.  Taste has several things i love, pineapple, grapefruit, slight mango, slight peach, mild pine and a sweet malt backbone throughout to balance and showcase the hops.  medium mouthfeel and awesome laing on the glass throughout the beer.  crisp hop finish leaves me craving the next sip.  definitely a top 5 double IPA for me.

perfect orange with about two fingers of creamy white head. Grapefruit, tangerine, maybe some peach and pine on the nose. Medium mouthfeel. Fruity notes from the hops are present, but the malt is shown nicely as well. No note at all of the 9.5%, this is a fantastic double IPA.

Just when I thought I was getting sick of IPAs...
Aroma is citrus and spice with a huge hit of hoppy pineapple and grapefruit
Taste is much like the aroma with a sweet malt background. I wont call it a backbone but its there.
Palate is dry and thin, refreshing.
Overall: Some of my IPA love returned to me with this bomber.
Clear pour, sticky head, golden color. Smells of pine and citrus hops. Grapefruit notes for flavor. Nice bite on the finish, disguises the alcohol. One of my favorites.
Bottled.  Pours orange red with a clean head. Hops pine resin aroma. Similar taste with some grapefruit and malts. Pretty good

Appearance: A gorgeous deep amber and super, super clear. Just amazing. This color knows what it is and states it proudly. Theres a tall three finger head that takes its time dissipating. Quite a time too.

Smell: Tangerine jumps to the front with orange and lime backing it up. Citrus dominates the aroma profile and its all the I can get to here.

Mouthfeel: Syrupy but carried extremely well by the alcohol and carbonation. Its refreshing but heavy. Its light but strong. Its delightful. 

Taste: Burning hops step to the top and like Hoptimum, you need a few sips before you can really start to judge the beer. Theres a distinct bready character that lies underneath helping disguise just how alcoholic this beer is. You really have to be careful with this brew. Lime and tangerine start to appear next and are helped along with a sweet, juicy fruit flavor. Almost like mango or passionfruit. Theres a very clean finish 

Overall: This only gets me more excited about the Sucaba barleywine sitting in the cellar. Firestone-Walker has impressed me on their first showing. Ill definitely be back for more based on this and I suggest any hop fans head out and pick this up. Not for the hops (theres hoppier stuff out there) but for the balance here. This is a really great Imperial IPA example and everyone should get a chance to enjoy it.

Picked up a 22 oz. bottle from my trip to Berts Better Beers today. Had to see what the hype was about. Smells mostly pine with a good bit of citrus lemon and grapefruit. Medium-heavy body with medium carbonation. Oily, syrupy  texture. Fruity, resiny hops in the flavor with plenty of malt to help balance it. Bitterness is there throughout the sip, yet it has a short pine abrupt finish.  For 9.5% the alcohol is pretty well hidden. Well made.

Bottle. Pour is bright orange. Aroma is strong with hops and fruit. Very good smell. Taste is borderline amazing. It has bitterness, but not too much. A very good beer and has a lot of fruit. Some bitterness in the aftertaste, but not much at all. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pizzeria Paradiso, Alexandria tap ($8): Pours an orange with a white head. Aroma is grapefruit hops, and some more hops, and a well-balanced malt backbone. Taste is normal DIPA, but done exceptionally well. I dont think that this beer breaks any boundaries, but it does successfully make a very well-crafted and, more so, well-balanced DIPA.
Medium head. Crystal clear with a golden hue. Citrus and hoppy nose. Medium carbonation. Slightly sweet with bold hop flavor. Long dry and bitter finish.
On draft. Incredible hop aroma of grapefruit, pineapple, peach and other citrus with a little pine. Tastes like it smells but its incredibly easy drinking at 9.5%. One of the best IIPA I know of.
UPDATED: DEC 29, 2013 Bomber. Wow - what a monster, and truly awesome. Big time west coast DIPA with loads of citrus hops. Well balanced. Tremendous.

Bottte this time.  Also had on draft before.  Poured a pretty good lookin gold color, medium full head.  Awesome aroma of citrus fruit hops.  Medium-full bitterness.  Medium full body, creamy texture, ave carbonation.  Long bitter finish.  Great mouthfeel.  Fresh piney, grapefruit, peach, hop up front, followed by some maltiness in the background, the ending with nice bitter hop.  Excellant stuff.

13/V/2012 - 1Pt. 6Fl. Oz. bottle @ home - BB: n/a (2012-492) Thanks to Jeremy for the bottle! 
Clear orange beer, big bubbly off-white head, very stable, pretty adhesive as well. Aroma: lots of passion fruits, very sweet ripe pineapple, little piny, some citrus. MF: soft carbon, full body. Taste: sweet malty start, lots of citrus fruit, passion fruit, some grapefruit, piny, honey, nice fruity bitterness. Aftertaste: lots of ripe sweet exotic fruits, passnion fruit and mango, nice bitterness. Amazing stuff.
Bottle from total wine sac. Beer is copper in color with a white head. Aroma is hops beer is sweet grapefruitness with a nice hop bitter finish!
Great IPA should be the benchmark for all DIPAs.. stacks up all round buy this beer! Gutted its now a finished bottle!

UPDATED: JAN 24, 2013 On tap tons of times and loads of bottles. Maybe the best and most consistent ipa on the market. Poured a vibrant orange, thin body. Impressive lacing and stickyness to glass. Aroma is ripe grapefruit, tangerine. Juicy up front with just the right bitter hops in the back. Taste is delicious fruity hop character, dank cheesey tangy hops, with grapefruit, pine, honey, pineapple and earthy basil quality in finish. Awesome IPA that reminds me of elder. Another homerun from FW.
A great DIPA.  Going broke between bombers of DIPA and six packs of the Union Jack.

UPDATED: JUL 28, 2012 Pity I have to drink this beer in double time (wine tasting I am late for...).  Hefty weight in the middle and back palate for this beer.  I fine example of a DIPA.

RERATE:  Better than I remembered.

UPDATED: SEP 26, 2012 Pours  amber orange with a nice white soapy head that lingers nicely.  Aroma is of orange, tangerines, grapefruit, tropical fruits, apricot, and some pine, and some sweet malts.  flavor is similar to nose with ton of citrus hop including tangerine, orange, grapefruit, and also pine resin, and sweet and earthy malts.  Has a medium body with a super creamy mouthfeel and dry, bitter hop finish.  overall, a very tasty DIPA that hide the 9.5 ABV very well.

Bottle. Pours a nice golden orange color with a white head. Aroma is filled with tropical fruits like mango, pineapple and passion fruit, also sweet citrus fruits like orange and tangerine, some sugary notes too. Flavor follows the nose with tons of sweet orange and tangerine, some grapefruit, tropical fruits like mango, pineapple and passion fruit with a slight sugary and sweet malty flavor. The body is medium with a dry mouthfeel. Overall a really tasty DIPA!
Fantastic Imperial IPA. Strong notes of citrus, hops and pine with an addition nice floral aroma. Very enjoyable and drinkable even at a high abv. Great beer!

On tap at the Parkway in Tacoma: great aroma of grass and honey appearance; fantastic dank poss. Citra hops taste. A beer I will have to return to. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle- Nose is sweet hops, citrus, pine, pineapple, spice, floral, grains..Taste is Citrus hops, sweetness, fruits, pineapple, bitter..Palate is dry and bitter.

Wow. Big 2IPA. Nose is hops with a nice sweet backing. In the mouth, initial big earthy hops, middle has a mild sweetness, perhaps appricot. Back end is all hop bitterness. Medium carbonation and medium in the mouth. Great beer.

A very good, intense double IPA. Floral hop nose . Full bodied, but definitely weighted to the extravagant hops. If hops are your thing, this is the beer for you. Oily and weighty mouthfeel. A bit fatiguing, but very well made.

Strong alcohol ester, grab you by the neck and scream " I gonna get you buzzed" 9.5 then smooth and surreptitious ...an IPA with an adult ABV

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Tap. Golden with creamy white head-decent size, decent lacing, decent retention. Smells like I like it. Piney, grape fruity, resent, maybe a little passion fruity. Not a lot of sweetness in the nose. Grapefruit comes through in the flavor, followed by bitter. Not much sweetness here either. Nicer long hop finish, a bit warming, soft carbonation. Youll put this up amongst the faves. Was just reminded of the 5 in the forums today- do here is one for me.

Great crisp double IPA. Clear, coppery color. Wonderful fruity aroma. Alcohol exceptionally well masked.

-- Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone.
Clear, orange appearance with not too much head. Great hoppy aroma and taste with a bit of an alcohol aftertaste.
Clear blond color, decent head and quite a lot of lace. Tropical fruit in the nose and a bit of nutty malt. Decen balance but not really vibrant or expressive. Drinkable but forgetable.

(Bottle) Pours clear golden with a cream off-white head. The aroma holds overripe yellow fruits/tropical fruit salad, watermelon, hard candy, floral perfume, olive oil, old/light sweaty sock, sweet citrus (orange, tangerines, mild lime peel and grapefruits) and green-ish hints of grass, pines and mild minty/peppery herbs. Undertones of toasted malt, doughy bread and honey. Juicy, fresh and candy-sweetish on the nose. The flavor is light to medium sweet, near medium bitter and tiny to light acidic. Super juicy flavor of orange, grapefruit, tangerine, mango, peach, lychee and passion fruit. Herbal, piney and grassy undertones. Touch of toast, honey, doughy bread and caramel.  The mouthfeel is clean (minus the yeastiness), juicy, soft and tiny astringent with a light to medium carbonation.  Citric, tropical, piney and herbal finish. Medium bodied. Passar bra till smörgåstårta.
Theres a lot of mediocre IPA/DIPAs out there. But each time I taste Double Jack, preferably fresh, I know that I still like hoppy beer, if they are well made. One of my favorites.

A truly superb Double IPA.

Ar: Extremely hoppy (citrus) with a little bit of pine as well. Caramel malts are quite apparent as well. A very well-balanced brew. 

Ap: Pours an amber-orange with a nice, large white head. 

T: Grapefruit and other citrus hops, although certainly not the most bitter IPA. There is some sweetness here as well, though perhaps not as much as the aroma might suggest. 

P: Medium-to-heavy body.

Copper color in the glass. Pleasant fruity, citrus, resin hop aroma. Quite bitter but not in an unpleasant way, it all stays in balance overall. My first beer from this brewery and I must say I am impressed.

(from notes- tasting party) Pours a light orange, w/ some white, creamy bubbles. Love the nose on this! Peach, apricot, citrus. Nice malt backbone to support all of the hops. Fruity, sweet. One of my faves!

This beer is worth the price simply for the aroma! Smells like heaven. Rapidly becoming my go-to beer. So glad that it is readily available locally. Rates up there with the best West Coast DIPAs for sure.

Originally reviewed: 3/20/12. Brought back a bottle of this from my recent trip out to Cali. Bottled on 1/26/12.

Poured into a tall goblet. Pours a cloudy dark orange with a thick white foamy head capping it off. Sticky globs of lace cling to the glass. The aroma on this one is stellar. Big citrus notes of tangerine, orange, grapefruit; light lemony-pine scent as well. Floral and sweet, just how I like it. 

This one is lacking in bite, as the beer is quite smooth, almost erring on thin. This goes down really slick. The flavors are not as pronounced as I had hoped. The citrus character is almost muted, and the hops are not all that flavorful. The alcohol comes forward a bit as there is an ethanol wash on the finish. I was really excited for this one, but it ended up a bit of a letdown. Not a terrible beer, just a slightly above average one.

Tap @ The Front Door: Crystal clear like dark apple juice.  Nice fuzzy head and abounding with juniper aroma.  On first taste, you are confronted with a TON of taste - junipers, apricots, pine needles, some grapefruit rind and alcohol.  The aftertaste is a bit musty and not as sweet and syruppy as many 2 IPAs but still excellent!

#2 - tangerine! (22 oz bottle)

#1 - Had a sip from someone else then they ran out. Need to try again liked a lot. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

20 apr 2012, bottle. Light gold and. clear. Nose is equally faint alcohol and grapefruit hops with prominent strong ale malt. Med body, slightly sugary, dainty fizzy. Pretty alright. Some strong ale alcohol with faint alcohol twinge and some reding bitterness. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

The smell is the best part of this double IPA, citrusy and piney notes dominate. The beer pours with minimal head and has a nice, somewhat light appearance. The taste is certainly reminiscent of the aroma, but the alcohol notes are strong for me; not hidden well at all. Strong hop bitterness throughout the taste. For me this is a good, but not great, beer.
amber with a cream head.  Nose is tropical fruits, sticky, fresh, grapefruit, and lightly bitter.  Super smooth on the palate, sticky hops, bitter, grapefruits, and light citrus.

Paleish orange pour with mild head,some lacing
Good hop aroma fruity,sweet bready,pastry malt,tangerine,some floral,somewhat musty fresh fruit on the tropical side papaya/coconut etc..
 Taste is hoppy with dry malt not quite toasty but a bit dry, sharp citrus hop sting on the tip of the toungepretty huge tangering taste and a rhindy orange/grapefruit type bittering some menthol/herbal-maybe the alcohol behind it.Id be curious how this ages.
Strongly hop flavored/bittered with big tangerine taste upfront citrus some floral and in bittering with grapefruit or orange rind with sweet malt lurking in thebackground-overall.Id rather try the regular ipa-this is a double im not real huge on.I just wouldnt run out and get another bomber too soon.
This is a great beer.  Has a sweet taste, followed by the hoppy bitterness.  Love this stuff.  Bought a growler of this a week ago, highly recommend  it.

Draft @ Cattlemens, Dixon, CA. Pours a bright orange with a compact white head,
Big  aromas of fresh fruit-grapefruit, tangerine, floral and herbal. Taste of grapefruit and other fruityness, Nice dry bitter lasting finish. Good balance of sweet and  medium bitter.

From bomber.  Pours a clear rich golden color with a small white head and tons of clinging and lacing.  Piney resin-y hops, peach, biscuit , and soap on the nose.   Taste had a little too much soapiness for me to fully enjoy, which is too bad because I thought the pine/peach contrast was unique.  The mouthfeel is nice on this one, sweet, good carbonation, smooth citrus/resin finish.

Really enjoyed this one.
Super piney aroma to me.  Good sour orange aftertaste.
Really like this one, just sad my glass is almost empty and the next one will be bought next time I visit the US.

Bottle. Love the aroma. Copper color tan head. Wow. Nice iipa. Nice lacing. Glad I tried this beer. Very enjoyable. Want more

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

I enjoyed this quality beer poured from a large bottle into a trumpet glass.  The beer had a rich aroma of citrus, spices, pine, and a bit of clove and some grassy notes.  It was a clear, light amber-gold color with a big foamy white head that had good retention and a lot of cling and lacing.  Its taste had a good bitter graininess, with a presence of alcohol, and a touch of sour citrus flavor; it was not sweet.  The beer had a thick mouthfeel and was very fizzy with good carbonation.  It was a very dry beer, strong, and best for sipping.

22oz bottle poured into tulip glass.  Bottle on date 1/5/12 (95 days ago)
Aroma: oranges, peaches, bubblegum, lemon, lime, hint of grapefruit
Appearance:  Very clear pout and 1 finger frothy off-white head that faded slowly.  
Taste: medium sweet, mild sour, medium bitter
Palate: medium body, thin texture, slick.  lively carbonation.  mildy bitter, sweet, and slighy sour finish.  Very light and crisp.  Refreshing.
Overall:  I like this.  More aroma and flavor than Union Jack.  Less bitter as well.  Surprised at the 9.5%, would guess closer to 7.5 to 8%.  This beer is very well balanced without being too sweet nor too bitter.  Will pick this up again and try to get a fresher bottle.

Pours with a citrus aroma.  Dense gold color.  The malts are apparent after an initial bitterness. Finishes smooth. The big alcohol content is apparent throughout. 







---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Pours cloudy orange ..nose is ginger...spice..musty goodness..in a,good way....good stuff

Acquired a bomber at mile high wine & spirits  in Lakewood , CO. 

Poured into a goblet glass . First impression is the smell- this beer smells like a hoppy pack of juicy fruit!!!! Beautiful golden yellow hue that is really intriguing . First sips remind me of a west coast styled double IPA that is very one dimensional . It has very nice balance between grapefruit & pine but not much else. Good for a Pliny lover in need of a good  IIPA but no substitute .

Bomber and on tap. Great Double India Pale Ale. A smooth, well balanced big brew. Lots of grapefruit and pine smoothed out with the sweet caramel. Long bitter finish with a touch of alcohol burn. Tasty.

On tap at Blind Tiger. Pours a clear orange-old. Caramel and a touch of biscuit with moderate pine bitterness. Honestly, a bit one-dimensional. I was expecting a lot more. Solid but pretty forgettable.

Pours to a big head that recedes quickly to about half a finger length. Smells mostly piney with a good bit of citrus as well. Thick texture upon the mouth, piney hops strike first, then a hit of sweetness, and finally a fine malt aftertaste blending with the hops, along with a little bit of an alcohol burn (it *is* 9.5% ABV, after all), but not over-the-top burn at all. Definitely as full of flavor as I remember it being the first time I had it about two months ago.

Draft. Poured a golden orange with a bright white head. Big grapefruit, tangerine, and citrus aroma. Taste starts out sweet, very smooth in the middle, big grapefruit, and a moderately bitter finish. Very well balanced, but still very hoppy. Another glass please.

UPDATED: JUN 21, 2013 Golden with a lasting white head. Aroma of hop resin, grass and floral. Taste matches the aroma nicely with a cleansing palate and good bitterness, pretty smooth for how bitter it is, some sweetness balances it out.

Firestone Walker Double Jack is a dense, very clear, sparkling golden ale topped with an elastic off-white foam that has excellent retention and lacing.  It has a huge floral hop aroma.  It smells sweet and candy like, pretty citrusy.  Its pretty full bodied and smooth.  The finish is quick and clean.  Its flavorful and well balanced.  Theres a soft sweetness from start to finish.  It tastes floral at first, but the bitterness turns to citrus by the finish.  The aftertaste is long and bitter, with the flavor of orange peel and fresh cracked black pepper.  The sweetness hangs on for a while as well.  This is really solid stuff.  Ill buy this again, for sure.

My first firestone, but it had to be an ipa. On tap but why do I torture myself with this rude style? Because its there? wtf? Fairly scary ipa aroma. First taste yeild a dull oily soapy mouth coating impact that will not let you soon forget about it. Dull and rubbery is my first impressions. Lingering chewy thing will not dissolve. Wierd stuff, even for an ipa. Barely any co2.
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Standard Market draft.  Peach and citrusy aroma, bright gold pour.  Bitter right away and throughout, but nicely balancing citrus notes and a crisp finish.  Lack of syrupy sweetness found in other heavy IPAs ends up being too much, but again this showed very good balance.

Bomber.  Pours a hazy amber to slight orange color with a nice foamy head that clings to the glass.  Fruity hop nose with a strong bitter kick, but the high alcohol is not present except possibly the finish.  Excellent strong IPA.

On tap at House of 1000. Has a huge juicy hop notes, fresh and floral and fruity with pine. Golden amber clear with thin white lacing head. Medium-heavy watery body with medium carbonation. Medium sweetness with apricot and pine hop notes, fresh and juicy. Mild to medium bitterness in the after with some carbonic bite. Delicious.

Bottle from Consumers Beverages Niagara Falls. Pours a pure copper colour with a pile of fluffy white head and clumps of lacing. Smells sweet smooth hop, citrus. Tastes a little boozy with a citrus peel hop bitter. Really smooth.
Bottle.  Very noticeable hop flavor.  Lots of pine and resin but not overly bitter.  Good flavor.  I didnt notice much alcohol taste in this.  Pretty good overall.

Bottle 2010.  Aroma has notes of citrus, resin, caramel and grapefruit.  Medium clear amber hue with a small off-white head that mostly diminished and left little lace.  Flavor is very sweet and very very bitter.  Palate is full bodied and watery soft.  Overall a nice IIPA but the appearance is to clear and not enough head and lace.
Poured a yellow gold, tinged with burnt orange. Aroma is promising, a touch heavy in the mids. Nice for a change from the norm, for a short bit.

UPDATED: NOV 15, 2012 re rated with a fresh bottle

Served in a Duvel glass. Pours a clear golden orange with a thin white head and decent lacing. Aroma is grapefruit, orange peel, pine resin, tangerine, lemons, and caramel. Taste is grapefruit, tangerine, and pineapple up front. It gives way to a caramel malt with some breadiness and a floral back bone. Mouthfeel is medium and very little alcohol is present. It is a very easy to drink beer and an awesome example of the style.

Bomber from AJs Fine Foods. Well, here it is: the best beer that I consumed on my trip to Arizona. This stuff is glorious! It pours a solid orange color I like so well from the style with a frothy white head. This is the first beer I tried out here that made me utter "wow" upon taking a sniff. The floral bouquet is endlessly complex and strong. Its a straight up IIPA with tons of citrus and evergreen. The hops run that gamut of citrus with a little rosemary and pineapple standing out. The malty sweetness is just a canvas except for the slightest biscuity note that makes things a little interesting.  The palate is outstanding: dry, not too sticky, but still resinous.

Clear bright copper-amber color, small white head. Fruity, citrus aroma. Medium-bodied. Fruity, resiny hoppyness in the flavor. Sweet bitter finish. Good drinkability. Nice one.

Bottle from Healthy Spirits, SF. It pours amber, with a thick white head. The nose is fresh pine, grass, spice and caramel sweetness. The taste is pine, resin, leather, floral, leaf, oily hop, grass, spice and a touch of citrus peel, with a long bitter-dry finish. Medium to full body, moderate carbonation and slightly oily mouth-feel. Very savoury indeed, I would have like some juicy citrus to balance it out. A really good DIPA nonetheless.
Awesome!!! In my top three. Beautiful aroma, smooth mouth feel.

Thanks to Pete for this treat. Good foamy head, solid carbonation and a clean as you like orange hue. Nose is soft citrus hops - very refined. Very balanced DIPA. Not too much sticky malt body and not a huge tongue blast of hops. Good solid bitter finish. Malt body is sweet on the finish. VERY well made - which is the hall mark of this brewery. Hides 9.5% very well too. Great lacing.
Great floral aroma.  Dark clear amber copper.  Heavy cascade flavor.  Hops hide alcohol content.
