great hoppy flavor, slightly sweet, great balance for a high alcohol %. Not overly malty, great hop presence.

Really nice IPA. Hops are nice and smells unbelievable. Citrus is most noticeable with orange and grapefruit. Heavy piney sap is in there as well. The taste starts with grapefruit, cirtus, and even a hint of mango. Turns bitter toward the middle with piney hops that go till the finish. The finish leaves the mouth wet opposed to a dry, crisp end and lingers with bitterness. The 9.5% abv is well hidden. Nearly a religious experience!

Bottle. Lovely orange amber color with a huge, creamy white head. Attractive. Sugary orange nose, plenty of grassy hops. Spun sugar, angel food cake. The taste is bitter tropical fruits, more orange peel zest. Hoppy, sure, but grounded by some nice brioche-like malting that gives heft and importance to the mouthfeel. Creamy, silky on the tongue. Nice indeed. The bodys medium/full. The carbonation active and prickly. Overall, a great beer. Very tasty without resorting to being an over the top hop bomb. The alcohols hidden very well, I finished the 650ml bottle like it was nothing.

Deep copper with off-white head that lasts.  Amazing citrus & mango nose with hint of booziness.  Perfectly rich mouthfeel with acidic hops throughout.  The alcohol is fierce and not masked much, even though the malts are caramelly and sweet.  I really enjoy the upfront alcohol in this, as all of the senses are attacked.  Huge hops, fiery burn, sweet middle.  Very enjoyable!
Amber with a nice sized head, good retention. Tropical fruit in nose. Taste is pineapple and grapefruit, a bit of pine all backed by a strong caramel sweetness.

UPDATED: MAR 4, 2012 Tap @ MacGregors Penfield.  Pours a clear light amber with a smallish head that doesnt really seem to leave much lacing.   Heavy citric hops in the nose. Impressive hop rate.  Taste follows suit.  Light malt backbone which I really like in DIPAs... not to say that this beer is dry, but it isnt super sticky sweet either.  Anyway, I really liked it.
Appearance is medium white head with clear amber. Aroma is a sweet earthy hop. Taste is bitter and grassy but with a nice citrus blend. Overall a solid IPA.

Pours a little hazy.  This is a big beer.  Lots of malt.  Not too bitter, very well balanced.  Its a bit fruity and sweet and mouth feel is a little sticky.  Great beer not as bitter as I expected though.

Picked up a bomber bottle at Bevmo in San Diego, CA, and poured it into a tulip glass.  Pours a nice amber color with a fizzy white head and light lacing.  A lovely aroma of piny hops and tropical fruit.  Flavors are beautifully balanced between the slight herbal bitterness of the hops, caramel malt notes, and very pronounced, juicy fruit flavors (citrus, pineapple, apricot).  Alcohol flavor is well-hidden.  This stuff is delicious.

Been waiting a while to get my hands on this one. Pours orange with a tight foamy head. Aroma is massive citrus of peach and grapefruit with a subtle earthiness from the significant malt presence and the danker notions of the hops. Flavor is intense but well balanced. Starts with piney notes with the fruit as well. Nice malty presence comes in and then an everlasting finish the echoes the lovely aroma. Great beer.

Bomber pours a clear golden color with a large white head that lasts and laces.  The first whiff is strong citrus hops.  Aroma is mostly grapefruit.  Taste is bitter, but malts in the finish balance this. It has a medium body and just enough carbonation to excite.  The high ABV is well hidden.  A very good IIPA, but not quite as complex as my favorites.

Bottle @ Timbers, Denver. Pours golden with a creamy white head. Aroma of pale malts, caramel, grassy, fruity hops, peach, grapefruit. Taste is very malty, light caramel notes, citruss, grassy, grapefruit like hops. Medium body, soft carbonation, bit of a alcoholburn iin the far finish. Good one. 260212
Bottle from Rodmans DC.  Very well balanced hop forward DIPA.  Alcohol was not overpowering.

Poured from a 22oz bottle.  Pours a beautiful copper crystal clear color with no head.  Aroma is that of pure hops, hops, hops, with a hint of alcohol detected.  Burst of citrus fruit taste with a nice background of grass and pine.  Initial palate feel is smooth and perfect.  Hop bitterness is balanced well by the light maltiness of the beer.  Bitterness on the palate lingers and becomes deeper in the back of the mouth as the nice bitterness lingers and draws me back for another taste.  Alcohol is masked very well and allows me to focus more on the complex variety of hops used in this beer.  VERY nice assertive Double IPA and one I would love to have again and again.  Well Done!

I poured this brew into an Imperial Pint glass and it poured a light golden orange with about a finger and 1/2s worth of a white head that left decent lacing.  Immediately I could smell the hops(F.W. uses a combination of Amarillo, Cascade, Simcoe and Centennial hops in their dry hopping to give this beer its overwhelmingly awesome aroma) wafting from my glass and they gave off a strong and enjoyable aromas of Pineapple, Grapefruit and grass. The taste was very similar to the aroma except with pine notes mixed in as well and finished very dry. The mouth feel of the beer was very light and had a slight sting from the 9.5% ABV.

pours a murky amber hue with a small white head that is mostly diminishing
aroma of tropical fruits and citrus - flavor just the same but pretty damn hoppy
medium mouthfeel with light carb
on tap at library alehouse in santa monica ca.

Bottled.  Aroma is complex, malty, pungent and sucrose.  Mouthfeel is dense and frothy. Sweet caramel to prolonged skunky malt.  Bitter chocolate undertones with an unending hoppy kick and plant.  Would like to try this on tap under a proper temperature to truly appreciate this well-rated selection.

From notes: Poured into snifter, bubbly orange-amber with a small, thin bone-colored head that was gone quickly.  Lots of carbonation bubles along the wall of the glass.  Strong, deep (yet not overpowering) grapefruit aroma, and maybe a light woody note.  Medium-thick, yet very deep and full-bodied with a slight oilyness and a long, somewhat astringent finish.  Flavor was, as expected, hoppy.  Mostly pine, with some grapefruit in the finish.  Also a mild woody note in the finish.  While quite hoppy, it was somewhat restrained (in a good way) as compared to some other double IPAs Ive had.

Copper in color. Has a thick, frothy, off-white head with Constallation lacing. Head descipated rather quickly. Hoppy aroma. Hint of citrus in the aroma. Piney aroma. Creamy texture. It coats your mouth. The hops hits the back of your throat almost instantly. There is a salty taste to it. I love this beer. A definite Hoppy lovers beer.

22 oz. bottle- Pours crystal clear orange with a nice three finger head and good lace. The aroma is pungent bitterness, pine, very resinous, sweet and syrupy, love it. The taste is very pungent and resinous, juicy grapefruit, very tasty. The body is medium, finish lingers, carbonation is medium. Overall a wonderfull DIPA, would have to compare with others to see if it makes my top five or not.

My bottle [660ml] shared with garthicus & herrbrown1974. Pours a cloudy orange with a small diminishing frothy white head. Lovely resiny hop aroma along with caramel malt, tropical fruit and a hint of alcohol -- smells great. Flavour of caramel malt, tropical fruit, citrus, a good amount of resiny hops, a hint of alcohol and a nice bitter finish. For 9.5% the alcohol is quite well hidden. Medium bodied. A really nice DIPA, good stuff.

Shared a 650. Thanks to blankboy. This is a fine 2xIPA. Fruity and balanced, big tIme hops.  Plenty of grapefruit and orange with caramel malt in the aroma. Soft and meaty mouthfeel. Balanced fruit rInd. This is simple and exactly what many brewers strive for in an IPA. Not
Much left to say. Just drink and soak it up.

Thanks to Blankboy. Appearance: Hazy orange, small snow white head. Aroma: oranges, pine, lots of pine and wood, mango and citrus. Flavour: Tangy, mango, lots of pine, thick sweet mouthfeel, grassy and sticky, long sweet finish.

On tap @ Cafe Amsterdam. Clear golden yellow with a thick, white head and nice lacing. Aroma is big grapefruit, pine resin, tropical fruit and some sugary bubble gum. Flavor is firmly bitter but with a bit of malt sweetness and some light alcohol. Medium body with active carbonation and a long bitter finish. Very nice IIPA, tons of hop aroma and a fairly balanced taste.

(22oz bottle) A clear, bright orange amber, with a big off-white head. Light lacing on the glass. Strongly citrus aroma: lots of orange notes, also grapefruit. Also very floral, some fresh grass, sweet caramel malt. Full bodied, creamy with an oily feel. Bitter hop flavor up front before rounding out with some sweetness. Finish is long and bitter--the bitterness seems to keep building.
A deliciously fruity and crisp IPA with an aroma that is not easily forgotten. Color is golden amber with decent lacing. An excellent blend of malts and hops which mask a quite potent ale.

Reviewed from notes.  Poured from a bottle into a CBS snifter.

A.  Pours a deep orange color with a 3mm head, rests after 30 seconds to some slight bubbles around the edge and a thin ring.  Slight lacing on the glass.

S.  Smells of grapefruit, sweet and ripe orange peel, mild pine and lots of other citrus.

T.  Tastes if lots of grapefruit, tangy citrus, tart and sourness of the grapefruit coming through, slight bits of orange and a hint of pine.

M.  Medium body, mild carbonation, wet feeling and a hint coarse.

O.  A good beer.  It wasnt anything out of this world.  Ive had many better DIPAs.  Its worth a try and tastes good, but not something to go searching for.

Pours a slightly amber copper orange with medium white head, decent lacing.  Aroma is obvious of citrus hops but decently balanced with malt sweetness.  Flavor matches well, but a little extra sweet holds it back from the elite DIPAs IMO.  Extremely good DIPA though.

UPDATED: MAR 6, 2013 Been quite awhile so im rerating this.  Bottle from Park Towne Bev.  Pours clear copper with a small white head that quickly dissipates.  There is a ton of carbonation in the glass.  The aroma is loaded with citrus including grapefruit, mango, and then a big astringent run.. some pine.. awesome smelling brew.  The taste is assertively hoppy with a medium bitterness that is followed by a huge citrus taste.  This guy is heavy on the grapefruit and the carbonation cuts the alcohol very well.

Pours clear golden orange color with large off white head. Nice tropical fruit on the nose, pineapple, apricot, grass. Clean medium body, not a ton of bitterness, sweet maltyness, mixed with nice fruity hop flavor, long finish. Great completely that all works together.

Pours thick, dark golden and opaque.  Thin but long lasting white head.  Aroma is pine, citrus, grass and grapefruit.  Taste is more of the same, but with a sweet malty backbone.  The taste lingers - a mixture of sweet malty goodness and bitter hops.  Med. thick mouthfeel.  Not as carbonated as it looks.  Very good.  No taste of alcohol for me.  A delight.

UPDATED: MAR 3, 2012 Pouts a clear golden amber with a moderate amount of white head. Nose is strong of floral, pine, and citrus hops. Mouthfeel is moderate. Taste starts sweet with brown sugar syrup, followed by strong grapefruit and piney bitterness. Alcohol is well hidden. Well done to style, a good example of imperial IPA. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

I really like this one. Lots of citrus (heavy grapefruit) hints of mango, gorgeous golden orange. I could go on, but its all been said already. IPAs are pretty much my favorite style, and this one I bought on a recommendation from a beer-buddy so it wasnt that much of a reach. Just drink it.
Bottled (thanks veliempojot!) Deep golden cloour, smalll head, Aroma is fresh fruits, sugar and some nectarines. Flavour is fruits, nectar and honey. Way too sweet to be nice.

Pours clean golden with a finger of white pillowy head. Big bubbles. Smell is very piney, strong bitter. Taste is bitter, but not super overpowering. Pine and floral hoppieness. Waxy finish. Crisp and drinkable. Not a bad IPA at all for the price.

A nice gold color and a white lacy head. The aroma is very citrusy (lemon zest) and piney. The flavor is strong on the pine, with a somewhat spicy aftertaste where the citrus appears. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Aroma is intensly hoppy and sweet. Wow ... The hops are strong but  there is a very unique floral taste.

Sampled at the 12 GABBF.  Clear deep golden color with a sticky off white head.  Huge hop candy nose with tons of grapefruit.  This is a hop jolly rancher beer.  Sweet with red grapefruit, pineapple and lots of sugars.  All supported by a thick malty base.  This is a big IIPA.

UPDATED: JUN 13, 2012 I hope my opinion wasnt to tainted by the Port Brewing Co. double IPA. This did not have the same full body. 

I had it a second time and I enjoyed it, but there are better IPAs out there

First Firestone Walker brew. Snifter. Nose is copious amount of pine and grapefruit with an earthy scent. Like a grapefruit had sex with a pine tree that had a bee hive in it. Honey undertones also were in the aroma. This one poured a nice golden amber color with an effervescent, lively head. Taste was full of hops and smooth caramel malts. Some honey malt crept into the mix as well. Overall this was very drinkable and enjoyable. Bitter and sweet flavors meld perfectly here.

A big thanks to OmegaX for this one. The scent was FULL of honey and hops, a tad like tree sap altogether. Tasted fantastic, lots of hops that were fresh and bitter with a sharp aftertaste were enticing. Undertones of rich malts and smooth alcohol demolished the palate with aggressive notes of grapefruit and graham cracker. Insane.

Bomber into pint glass. Huge billowing head retreats but leaves its signature on the glass, notes of Pine needles, mango, grapefruits. This is a well balanced and world class DIPA. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

(bottle). A new find complements of Keg_Juggler.  Crystal clear golden complexion with thick white head. Aroma is intensely grapefruit and hops. The flavor bites with hops and fades inter more mellow aftertaste.  Smooth palate.  

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: MAY 29, 2013 
 65 cl bottle @ home, bottled 18.11.2011
Rather nice and fruity aroma with american hops. Some resin, peach and mango. Flavour is rather hoppy and fruity with peaches and some mangos. Somewhat sweet, but not in a disturbing way. Very nice DIPA!

UPDATED: DEC 26, 2014 
65 cl bottle. Bottled on 04.10.2013.
Lots of citric fruits and caramel on the nose, quite piney too, resinous hops and faint herbal tones. Somewhat sweet orange and mandarin on the flavor, caramel, resin, pale malts and hops. The bottle is not that fresh anymore, though it feels a bit more balanced now, alcohol comes through a bit but doesnt disturb at all, hop profile is still very nice. Excellent.
65 cl bottle. Bottled on 18.11.2011.
Pours clear golden color with medium head. Aroma of exotic hoppy fruits grass, mild caramel notes and pine needles. Flavor of exotic fruits, mild grass and herbal notes, caramel, spices and grape fruit. A bit sweet but nicely hopped and crisp.
Rating: 8-3-8-4-16
4615

650 ml bottle.
Pours a copper orange colour with a white head. Lovely aroma of exotic fruits, caramel and some herbs. Flavour of exotic fruits, strong floral hops, caramel malts, herbs and toffee. Full bodied, thick mouthfeel and a fruity, floral, citrusy finish. Not too sweet, has the right amount of bitterness, but this isnt as refreshing as North Bridge Extreme for example.

660ml bottle from Whole Foods SoMa, San Francisco, CA
Bottled on 18.11.2011 - Pours dark orange with a clear haze and smooth white head. Aroma of fresh exotic fruits, grassy hops, pine and grapefruit. Taste is extremely fresh and slightly sweet with exotic fruity hops, grass, pine and caramel malt. Finish is fruity and bitter with tingly notes. Excellent, well balanced and tasty IIPA.

This beer is great hands down bar none. Aroma is big and very earthy full of citrus and basil. Pours is the color honey with a medium off white head. Flavors are big but still smooth and the bitterness is perfect .

Poured from a 1 pint bottom. Beer pours golden with a med white head the small of frash grapefruit, herbs, and pine. This beer is a thick, creamy hop bomb with loads of flavor. This for sure is one of the best  doubles that I had this will be a beer I will always look for.

Bomber from total wine Tucson AZ. Deep golden pour with a nice foamy head. Big hopy start followed by caramel grapefruit and other citrus flavors. Nice carbonation and very well balanced. 
Cheers!

On tap at MacGregors.  Pours a light golden color with a lasting white head and beautiful lacing. Aroma has notes of yeast, flowers, citrus fruit, and  sugar. Taste is rich with notes of caramel, grapefruit and anise. Finish is  sweet and citrus and hoppy. This one of the best double IPAs Ive ever had.

UPDATED: MAY 31, 2012 Pours clear gold with white head, aromas of resinous piney weed like herb and some tangerine citrus and grain. The taste is phenomenal, crisp and clean. The pale malt is step for step with the tangerine citrus and some pine - herbal hops if not in the foreground. There is a little sweetness to it that really makes it dangerously drinkable. Not really a dry finish it lingers with a grainy palate (with a wee bit of alc) and some bitterness that increases as it warms. Overall one of the best iipa?s.

Copper orange color.  Smells of some citrius, pineapple and a good bit of spruce and pine  Very stong aroma.  Delicious bitter hop taste.  Lasting bitter hop aftertaste that stays with you for a while.  Hides the high ABV pretty well.  Nice finish, could drink this all day.

I drank this back to back with its little brother Union Jack (or I guess Single Jack).  Basically the same thing, just stronger.  The Union is 7.5%, this is 9.5%, which is about 25% more.  I would say that sounds about right for everything they just turned it up a bit.  Not sure if its good enought to justify 2x the price though.  Not a knock on this, but more of a credit to little brother.

Overall this is a very good Imperial IPA.  Easily in my top 10 IPAs.

22oz bottle.  Served in a globe. Pours clear copper, one finger of white head with good lacing on the glass.  Smells of hops - pine, resin, citrus, grass.  Medium body, nicely balanced between malt sweetness and hops.  Caramel flavors, citrus, and a wonderful lingering bitterness and not a hint of alcohol.  One of my favorite DIPAs.

Bottle as shown. Pours a clear orange with small off white bead and spotty lacing. The aroma is floral hops and citrus. Medium mouthfeel with a sweet hop and citrus. A good IIPA that hides the alcohol well making it very easy to drink.

I was really hoping the hops had held up while I waited for this to make back from my trip to Seattle. It definitely has and is definitely one of the best doubles I have had. Aroma is big orange and citrus. A little bit of sugar. Flavor is nicely balanced with sweetness caramel and orange candi sugar. A little bit of bubblegum. Finish is pleasantly bitter and relatively long with a good orange candy flavor. Nice balance and drink ability. Tasty

Bomber pours a very elegant amber with a thin white head.  Flural aromas up front also lots of citrus and pine. Flavor is bitter citrus rind up front and very piney also a bit of malt smoothness and pepper.  Body is medium withand some alcohol warmth and very astringent feel. Finish leaves a very bitter taste. Great ipa

A little expensive but a really delicious double IPA. Nice aroma, but mine was served a little too cold. There is a big malty body that helps cut the bitterness. Tons of hop bite at the end. 

-

650ml boomer from High Spirit Liquors in Providence, Rhode Island. Pours a clear golden orange with a tall foamy head.. Some lace, but not very long lasting.  Nice sweet citrus aroma. Flavours is citrus with zest bitter, pine, and very nice spicy sweetness. Full bodied, almost syrupy, nice lingering bitter. Alcohol - at 9.5% - not overpowering.

Nice hops straight off. Cut with a bit fruit flavor. Definitely grapefruit. Color is great, smells like heaven. Doesnt make u pucker. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

One of the best IPAs Ive had. Strong piney aroma. Beautiful clear golden slight orange color. Taste of mild sweetness, little to no alcohol taste and a wonderful hoppy bitterness that I crave in my IPAs. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: AUG 20, 2012 Poured from bomber into a tulip. Pours a medium orange color with a nice, but small head.

Very hop based aromas of pine, resin, hops and a lot of citrus aromas as well. Big, but not overdone.

fuller bodied with a very good feel. Polished with a real smoothness to it along with flavors of resin, oranges, hops and some bits of pine flavors as well.

This is an extremely good DIPA. You dont feel any of the alcohol and while it is a very hoppy beer, it isnt in the way too much category either.

Bottle. Pours a hazy orange with a white head. Smells of pineapple, orange peels, and some floral and grassy notes. Tastes of a thick acidic pineapple cocktail, with a medium to strong bitterness hiding below the surface. Fill bodied. High carbonation. Very rich, and very good.

Draft. Pours tastes of caramel, bread, spruce, alcohol, vanilla, light sweetness, medium bitterness, medium body, sticky, average carbonation, has a nice taste starts out semi sweet with a huge hop finish. For as much hop that is in it its still balanced well that all of it works nice with the bitter fininish.
Good balance between the malts and the hops. Syrupy mouthfeel. strong hop finish. the hops give a nice piney and citrus flavor.

Strong aroma of and balance of citrus, pine and yeast.  The flavor is heavy of pine/citrus with a very thick, almost syrup-like body aided by a good malt base.  Among the most balanced DIPAs Ive had, along with a still very strong hop bitterness, this was a great ale all together.

bottle thanks to wavers(i think).  poured gold with a bubbly white head.  aroma was pine and white grapes.  flavor was much the same, but had more of a pine resin note.  body was light with low carbonation.

This is a perfect IPA. The aroma of hops is overwhelming. The taste is crisp and clean. Hops are perfectly balanced with a malt flavor throughout.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Color is a light copper color. Smell is strong citrus with slight floral tones. Taste is slightly hoppy but very smooth. One of the most drinkable IPAs I have had.

Porous loose white head, leaves lateral lacing.  Aroma of strong citrus and more subtle hops. Citrus flavors up front. Bright, shiny and refreshing then moving to a well balanced mouth feel and great acidity/sugar balance. Light bitterness at end, but amazingly pleasant and welcome. Fantastic Ale. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a clear golden orange with a small,.quickly diminishing white head. Nice lacing on the sides of my FW tulip. Aromas of pine and hints of citrus. Some fresh baked sweet bread is present also. Flavor is a nice combination of sweet and bitter. Dry finish with the sweetness lingering a bit. Moderate carbonation. A very nice Imperial Ipa.

Pours a very transparent gold with a healthy, dense head and the aroma of grassy hop oil, almost the smell of a fresh hop off the bine.  A bit sweet with very citrusy taste but not the grassy hop note which dominates the aroma. Nicely balanced with very slight bittering in the finish.
This beer was pretty a o k.  It is a good one on my list bro.  Tasting good times. Yum fun.

Poured from a bomber it has a golden orange color. Aroma is all IPA. Fresh, crisp and citrus explode from the glass. Taste has big hop flavor along with some citrus. Grapefruit and lemon are definitely present. Good beer.

Bottle. Pours golden with a white head. Gooseberry and grape notes in the aroma. The taste has got notes of grape, melon and gooseberries. Very fruity. Not overpoweringly bitter. I have never before tasted a DIPA as crisp as this one! And i my book, that is a really good thing.

Bottle.
Pours nice golden with a white head.
Bitter DIPA dominated by nelson-style hops, but still very drinkable!

Thanks to my Secret Santa for knocking this off my wishlist. Clear copper, big fluffy white head. Smells great - grapefruit, fresh cut grass, a little pine. Really nice, hoppy aroma. Flavor is pretty much the same - lots of hops, just a little bit of malt. Maybe some whiskey, too. Very tasty.

Always a quality DIPA!  Lots of pine with a hint of citrus. Body is medium, certainly not overwhelming (in a good way). Taste follows the nose, lots of malt sweetness (perhaps this is an older bottle (DAMN YOU FIRESTONE FOR NOT DATING!!!)) with about 5/10 worth of bitterness coming through at the end. Easily enjoying a 22oz by myself of this.

Name: Double Jack
Date: April 08, 2011
Mode: Bottle
Source: Total Wine, Vegas
Appearance: clear gold, frothy off white head, drippy lace
Aroma: sweet citrus aroma, candied orange, crystal sweetness, hint of pine
Flavor: sweet crystal malt flavor, lots of fruity sweetness, orange, pine, touch of citrus rind bitterness, touch of peppery spicyness
Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 15/20
Rating: 3.6/5.0Drinkability: 8/10
Score: *** /4

22-12-11 Bouteille 650ml: Couleur jaune-dorée, limpide avec une effervescence normale et très peu de mousse. Arômes de malt céréales asser puissant, avec une touche de houblon et des notes fruitées style pèches-poires. Saveurs très maltée avec une bonne touche dhoublon et de fruits. Bien balancé, mais moins houblonnée que la plupart des double ipa. Corps moyen avec une texture ronde et asser soyeuse. Carbonisation moyenne et finale bien balancée également. Bonne bière, sans plus.

Pours clear gold, 1 finger if bubbly lace.  Aroma of citrus fruit, Mango, Honey, a bit of earthiness and toasted malt.  Citrus and pine up front, mango, caramel, some breadiness.  medium bodied, sweet, resiny, very smooth, right amount of carbonation.  Damn good.
featuring a big malty middle to cloak the high alcohol and respectable hop bitterness. Huge tangerine, grapefruit and juicy fruit aroma blossom over the herbal blue basil and malt earthiness.

rich malty aroma with a thick musty resin hoppiness.
surprisingly sweet with a healthy bittersweet hop finish. smooth and malty throughout. this is good but is more of a barley wine. not sure why breweries are labeling barley wines "double ipas" these days. theres very little fresh hop aroma. still, its tasty, very smooth, and alcohol is well hidden though its a bit hot in the finish.

On tap at Blue Monk 
Aroma intense, clean bold in your face hop aromas. Hint of honey, aromatic flowers. Bold yet balanced neat approach.
 Appearance  clear with gentle haze, amber. Medium top , lace noted on glass.
Flavor and Palate : Medium plus bodied. Ultra clean with plenty of hops. Very well presented, produced strong hoppy ale. Another superb brew from Firestone.

Pours a clear green-gold with a thin white head. Aroma is fruity, floral, citrus, pine, pineapple. Flavor is surprisingly fruity; long on the grapefruit and some burnt caramel; bitter with a very smooth finish. Really well done.

 Flavor is real fruity, tangerine and grapefruit come to mind with some nice underlying malt. Overall a real quality brew!
Bottle.  Pours a thick cheddar orange with a nose grapefruit, orange peel, and pine.  Flavor is grapefruit, orange, light bread and pine.  Chunky on the tongue.  Great IIPA.
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text: 22oz Bottle from Wine & Cheese Place. Crystal clear copper color with a short head. Incredible hop aroma, mostly citrus and floral some pine and bubblegum, not unlike Dreadnaught. Reminds me of fresh Dread. Medium body, syrupy and slick leaving a sharp bitterness. Flavor is real fruity, tangerine and grapefruit come to mind with some nice underlying malt. Overall a real quality brew!
user_location: Cape Coral Waterfront Wonderland, Florida, USA

text: Bottle - DJ IPA pours a Clear amber with a white head.   has a great hop bitterness. tangerine, grapefruit and fruit aroma. very good beer!
Bottle shared with friends.  Pours clear golden with a white head.  Citrus and grass in aroma.  Flavour has grapefruit and caramel.

Golden orange pour with copious lace. Intense aroma of eucalyptus, menthol, flowers, passionfruit, grapefruit and toasted woodchips. A sip reveals more resinous hops, big caramel and bread flavours in the middle, and a spicy finish. Immaculately balanced; despite what I expect is an enormous IBU, the perceived bitterness is kept firmly in check. Could put it down to the huge malt backbone. Creamy, full body. Could probably be a little dryer - otherwise, practically faultless.

22oz bottle poured into an ABC pint glass. Golden/orange with a tight finger sized head. Sweet malts, a bit of alcohol, passion fruit, and grapefruit in the nose. Fresh Double Jack is definitely a treat...loads of resin, tropical hops, and mango stick to the toungue due to a slightly cloying, bready malt backbone. A bit too dangerous, ABV is totally ignored due to flavor.

Bottle. Moderate raosted and caramel for the malt, moderate to heavy pine and grapefruit peel for the hops, with background notes of date, pepper, alcohol and a medicine-y hint. Head is average size, frothy, slightly off-white with fair, thin lacing and is mostly diminishing. Color is clear light amber/orange. Flavor starts lightly sweet and lightly to moderately acidic, then finishes lightly acidic and moderately to heavily bitter. Palate is medium, oily with a soft carbonation and a finishe that is lighly astringent, lightly to moderately alcoholic and is fairly drying. Nice juicy hops and a perfect balance with the malt backbone makes this DIPA top notch.

Tasted on 3/14/11 from a 650mL bomber bottle purchased at Lush West Town.  Pours burnt orange with an average off-white head that slowly recedes to uneven lace.  The nose is full of piney resin hops, tons of lemon peel, with caramel malt and just a hint of maple.  The flavor has some sweet orange and caramel up front, moving to pine resin bitterness, a hint of soap, and chewable vitamins.  The body is medium and somewhat sticky with average carbonation and a long bitter orange peel and resin finish.

22oz bottle from the 300 East liquor store in SLC - Pours a crystal clear yellow color with a medium sized pure white head that sticks around forever. Aroma is full of green resiny hops, with notes of grapefruit and touches of light caramel and faintly toasted malts. Flavor is fairly hoppy with grapefruit notes, touches of caramel and lightly chewy malts. Finish is balanced but with a slight residual sweetness. This is basically a strong version of union jack, almost identical in fact. Its almost like you took a bottle of union jack and poured in everclear. Its very good, much like union jack. However, I sort of think a double IPA should be different than a regular IPA, not just an identical but stronger version of an IPA. Nevertheless this is still very good.

The aroma is delightfully unique.  The citrus / fruit reminds me of a chewing gum product that I can not name but is very familiar.  Very balanced taste, sweet up front from the malt with a long hoppiness linger.  Maybe, just maybe kick up the hops a few IBUs (that is my CO side of me talking).  best beer Ive had from Firestone!
Draft. Pours golden amber with a white head. Citric and cat piss hoppy aroma with some piney notes. The flavor has resinous piney hops, grapefruit rind, and some citric sweetness. Good stuff.

pours a light golden color with a lasting white head and beautiful lacing.  aroma is very complex with notes of yeast, hay, flowers, citrus fruit, and candy sugar.  Taste is rich with notes of caramel, grapefruit, chamomile and anise.  finish is dry, sweet and lushly hoppy.  This one of the best and most elegant double IPAs Ive ever had.

UPDATED: JAN 17, 2012 Re-rate: 1/12, on draft, multiple times from my sixtel from SL. Original rating is moving up from a 4.9 to a perfect 5.0. You can do no better from the style. Original rating: Pour was golden to very light orange with a nice thin and well-sustained white head. The aroma was friggin awesome grapefruits and tangerines and faint resinous notes. The flavor was rich citrus grapefruits and tangerines with some great herbal hops and wood barrel notes. This thing was absolutely wonderful and Id have rated it a 4.0 if not a single tasting. Mouthfeel was tingly if not spicey, great moderate body and dry finish.

Pours golden with  a thin white head.  Nose is bitter with grassy hops, honey, and citrus.  Smooth and tangy to start with a malty gliding start and a finish of complex citrus hop, sage, resin, and faint nutmeg.  A hop haven.  nice beer with no telling element of the hefty alcohol it hides.

Cloudy orange, bubbly with small white head.  Aroma of an evergreen forest with some grapefruits and flowers around.  Medium-full body, a bit of alcohol, not much, some mild carbonation.  Nicely bitter hop flavor more piney than citrusy with restrained malt balance and long finish.  Pretty much just like I would want an IIPA to be.

Spicy citrus and pine oil aroma. Bready malt balance. Intense hop character.

The appearance is bright, clear orange. tons of carbonation. Decent head retention.

The flavor is spicy, woody hop at first; burns the tongue a bit. Malts of earthy amber stock; red and spicy. Some finished wood. (Great burp!) Very spiced up. An alcoholic burn at the end.

The feel is chewy, fizzy, thick and very sticky. A big, woody Imperial IPA with a solid balance. Burns just a little.

Bottle at Theis tasting. 
Pours hazy amber with a tan head. 
Aroma is heavy hoppy with notes of caramel, pine, peach, grape and tee. 
Flavour is very smooth and balanced, typical IIPA with notes of bitter hops, caramel, peach and pine.

22 oz bomber
Aroma: pine/citrus/spicy/earthy hops
Taste: get a lot of the same hop profile with additional bitterness/resin, sweet malts, light toasted malt
This is one of the best IIPAs that I have had. Will have to buy more while I still can.

Ths poured a cloudy orange colot with an off white head, Arona was cutrs fruits, and a good amount of caramel, a little disappointing.  Flavor was very odd, Most of what I would consider mediocre IPAs start of with good hop, flavor but dispate into malt, this one was the complete opposite. Started of malty and then finished with a fruity bitter finish. Odd and meh.

Great hop flavor...bright and clean, almost like wet-hopped.  Bottle taken care of,  but still substantial chill haze. The alcohol is there, but not harsh and is well behind the hop flavor.  The bitterness is pretty low for a DIPA.  Tons of hops added at the end of brewing.  Quite pleased with this one.

(Flasche) Farblich ein dunkles Gelb mit einem roten Einstich. Das Aroma ist fruchtig-tangerineartig oder graipfruitartig und das sehr schön "rund". Der Grundgeschmack ist süßlich-malzig und im Abgangist es recht breit Bitter. Auf der Zungenspitze und Retronasal schmeckt man das fruchtige Aroma. Zusammengefasst ist es sehr lecker, aromatisch und man schmeckt den Alkohol nicht.

(bottle) pours a clear deep golden colour with a frothy white head. very tangy aroma of pineapples, mango, passion fruit and ginger, with light notes of powdered sugar, very resinous. flavour is mostly the same, lots of resin and tropical fruits, with a hint of caramel and a pronounced grapey bitter finish. medium to heavy-bodied with average carbonation. nicely balanced with subdued sweetness.

This starts with a nice big punch of hop aroma, orange and grapefruit being the predominant notes.  Pours a clear amber, with a huge fluffy white head.  The flavor is not quite a punch of hops, as it is an aggressively hop forward beer, with a big malt profile to soften and balance it out.  Very easy drinking, with just a hint of heat pointing out the alcohol content.  Im very impressed with this one.

[4048-20111029] 650mL bottle. Tangerine hoppy peel aroma. Clear, orange brown body with a quick foamy off-white head. Bitter grainy orange peel flavour has a lingering bitterness. Medium-full body. Tasty hoppy brew. (8/3/8/4/16) 3.9
Overheard: "Im uh, drinking a lot of vodka tonight."
(c/o DuctTape, w/ him, jerc, others)

Excellent Double IPA - shared a bomber with friend at the Freakin Frog in Las Vegas.  This beer shares a seat in the same class as Pliny the Elder.  Really enjoyed it and wish I could get it here in Columbus.

Pours a hazy amber with a thin white head and good lacing.  Aroma is big grapefruit and citrus hops but its not overpowering.  You can stick your nose in your glass for days.  Taste is a great balance of grapefruit hop bitterness and sweet malt.  So well balanced.  I wish this was available to me at all times!

On tap at sierra.  One of my new favorite DIPAs.  What really gets me in this one is the citrus element.  Looks great in the snifter, a great darker golden color, rich white head.  Aromas are dominated by a lemon citrus with slight orange, just superb balance.  Bitter in the finish with flavor that rips the palate with pine and west coast flare.  Amazing, FW never ceases to amaze me.

Bottle - 650ml. Beautiful hazy amber/orange body with an average white creamy head. Fresh, sharp hoppy taste with flowery, fruity, bubblegum, and malty hints. Alcohol is very well hidden. Its robust, complex hoppy taste carries fruity and caramel notes. It ends with a long, strong, warming bitter finish. Excellent Double IPA.
Very fresh citrusy taste, could have had a stronger hop bite, but over all this beer kicks hard and tastes great

Bottle at home - Tasting. Clear amber - white head. Grape fruits, flowery, light  toasted, high freshness, light to medium malty, super lovely gigh hoppy, light grapes, light herbal, light knækbrød, Fantastric... still good after 2 mdr in DK.......

Bottled. amber coloured.  unclear. dense off white head. Aroma of herbs, flowers, pine, light sweetness some pine, sweetness and caramel.  flavour of herbs, flowers, caramel, spice, pine grape and citrus. Medium to full bodied. ends on a citric and flowery bitterness in the end. DE-LI-CI-OUS

Bottle.Thanks Hopscotch for providing. Pours bit hazy golden with a creamy off white head. The aroma is peach, passion fruit, sweet caramel, citrus, light pine, light grapefruit and light mango. The flavour is heavy fruity and caramelish. It has notes of passion fruit, peaches, fruit bowl, grape fruit and caramel in the flavour. Extremely refreshing and quaffable!

Herlig fruktig doft som sprider sig direkt.
Smaken är fyllig. mycket fruktig och mycket välbalanserad.
Fanastiska toner av grape och apelsiner. Dracks på flaska men den känns som om den kom purfärsk från fatet
22oz bottle Wow this cost $16, but worth every penny. Sipping on this, I could feel the love. Very complex, beautiful beer without the muddiness of many IPA2s. Awesome.
user_location: Peoples Republic of Bloomington, Indiana, USA

text: Bottle from brewolf...thanks Michael! - Pours clear light amber with a thin foamy white head. Woody and sharp, with citrusy hops underneath and a malty sweetness. A bit of menthol and pine. Taste is upfront fruity, lightly grassy hops with an herbal mintiness. Resiny as hell, sweet, and a touch of heat on the end. Pretty thick, but it doesnt detract at all.

650ml bottle shared with friends 29/10/2011
Lovely hoppy aroma.  Clear amber pour.  Nice smooth bitter aftertaste.  Great!

bottled at mcbc. pours lighter amber with a small off white head. aromas of citrus, caramel, and spruce. flavors similar. moderately sweet with light candy feel. palate is more sweetness from the alcohol than hoppy crispness, but overall it works very well. pretty decent beer with lasting flavor and bite on the tongue.

2011-10-29. Golden amber body with a modest white head. Lovely hoppy aroma and flavour with lots of green leafy hops and a bit of citrus. Smooth average plus to medium bodied palate. Alcohol is not obvious at all, rather good and quite drinkable. Bottle shared by DuctTape

Aroma- big hops, booze, breadiness, funk
Appearance- incredible lacing, golden orange, nice foamy white head, extreme carbonation
Taste- reminiscent of Nugget Nectar in some respects, same very smooth malty middle and bitter hop aftertaste, although this beer is more hoppy and is cleaner all the way around
Palate- medium-bodied, crisp, refreshing
Overall- Im impressed.  Nothing fancy, nothing life-altering.  Just a damn good, smooth as hell, DIPA.  Probably in my top 5 list of IPAs.  Very drinkable as well. Caution: Firestone Walker is a force to be reckoned with.

It is good that this solid imperial IPA is available at reasonable prices.  Piney aroma - a humid, green, IPA scent - and a clear, brassy pour.  This appears to be Adrians brew of the year.  It is mighty stuff - lots of full, dry hop bite that gets a touch harsh.  Good overall, but I prefer FWs Union Jack, a lighter IPA.

This beer could get you in trouble.  Bomber to a Weizen glass.  Pours a bright, cloudy amber with significant and foaming head.  Crisp, floral, hoppy aroma.  Goes down very, very smooth.  Not sure how this is near 10%.  Great Double IPA.
Sweet hoppy aroma, Sweet taste, Alcohol is well masked, slight malt with a big citrus hop finish. One of the best doubles Ive had in a while.

Bottle from Whole Foods Market - P Street, October 2011.

Clear medium copper with a medium white head. Very hoppy aroma and taste with resin, caramel, pine and citrus. Nicely balanced and with a great bitterness. I really liked this one!

(22 oz. bottle from Candia Road Convenience) Pours hazy amber-orange with a finger or so of off white head. Big hoppy aroma - grapefruit and pine over vanilla. Mouthfeel smooth, medium-full, very lightly prickly, a bit sticky. Weepy dabs of lacing in the snifter. Flavor of big sweet grapefruit/citrus and lighter pine with vanilla and lighter caramel. Tasty, sweet and hoppy big IPA with lingering bitterness.

Draught, 9.5%. Good grassy aroma. Hazy golden colour. Very small white head. The flavour starts off powerful, alcoholic and hoppy. Caramelly and sweet. A bit of hop burn. Caramelly and sweet finish. Late hop bitterness. Gets a bit rough after a while, but a good beer.
Draft. Had it before in a bottle but enjoyed it much more in tap. Minimal head that hangs on the side of the glass, loved it. Perfect balance
On draft.  Poured clear copper with off white head.  Sweet, sugary nose.  Flavor is of sweet candy sugar, citrus, rye, and a bit of spice.  Syrupy.  Finishes dry.  Solid IIPA.

This pours with an golden orange color with a substantial frothy head that hangs around. The aroma is a little sweet with just a hint of the hops that are to come. The taste is slightly sweet with a hoppy bitter finish with a slight alcohol taste thrown in. A good hoppy beer.

Bottle from New Beer Distributors, New York, NY. A golden/amber coloured pour with a medium white head on top. Decent hoppy, malty aroma. Tastes hoppy, malty, grapefruit, yeasty, bitter, sweet. A quality Imperial IPA.

Grabbed a growler for Thursday night poker game.  Taste is malty, grassy, grapefruit, and other IPA deliciousness.  You get caramel, and citrus.  Its kinda sweet and just hoppy enough.  pretty decent although drinking an entire growler probably wasnt good idea.

Bomber from Holiday Wine Cellar ($7.99).  Pours a clear orange-amber color with one finger of creamy white foam that has excellent retention, (not dissipating at all!).  Aroma of sharp hops (grapefruit, tropical fruit, earthy resin) along with a nice balancing caramel maltiness.  The initial flavor of intense hoppiness (resin, pine, bitter grapefruit) is soon followed by a good deal of honey-caramel malts and a hint of alcohol.  Both lingering bitterness and sweetness lead to a pleasant finish.  A very good and finely balanced DIPA.  (466, 619)

Bottle.

Head is initially average sized, frothy, white, mostly lasting.
Body is dark yellow.

Aroma is lightly to moderately malty (toasted grain), moderately to heavily hoppy (resin, grapefruit).

Flavor is moderately to heavily sweet, moderately acidic, lightly to moderately bitter.
Finish is lightly to moderately sweet, moderately acidic, moderately to heavily bitter.

Medium to full body, velvety/watery texture, lively carbonation, lightly to moderately astringent, moderately alcoholic.

The aroma is certainly to style for American IPAs, but its remarkably one-dimensional.  Resinous green hops not much else.  The usual suspects in the mouth, too...citric, astringent, and quite bitter.  This doesnt really do anything wrong, but its the same as hundreds of other American renditions.  I guess its too much to ask for something unique in this style, but one can dream.

22oz bottle poured into a Snifter at 40°.  Color is a bright gold with good carbonation and a thin head.  Aroma is big citrus with a grassy back note.  It has a medium body with a crisp mouth feel.  Flavor comes out with a bold citrus taste (they nail it in there description with tangerine), then a bit of malt shows with a faint sweet feel and a big bitter bite on the end.  In the after taste the citrus hangs as the bitterness peaks.  Overall its a very good Imperial IPA just leans a little too much on the citrus for my taste.
UPDATED: OCT 10, 2011 Smells strong of piney notes.  Good head on the appearance.  Very hoppy taste, almost grapefruit.  Very good IPA.

22oz bottle in a tulip.  Pours copper with a thick, fluffy, off-white head.  Aroma strong of citrusy hops, some caramel malts, and hints of alcohol.  The malts could be stronger to balance out the hops/alcohol, but overall its a really good beer.  Could be a little thicker too.

Coppery amber in color with an off white head. Very nice taste with citrus flavors, hints of spice, and a slightly herbal or floral hoppiness. Very good bitter finish. Not overly strong considering the alcohol. A very good IPA.

Bottle 22fl.oz.Clear medium orange colour with a average to large, frothy, good lacing, mostly to fully lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, caramel, moderate to heavy hoppy, citrus, wood, orange - citrus, pine, soap. Flavour is moderate to heavy sweet and bitter with a long duration. Nice balance IIPA. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20110930]
Orange pour with watery white head and lace. Huge resiny aroma with nice malty sweetness. Sweet caramel start with a nice resiny bitter finish. Medium/full bodied with good carbonation. nice beer.

UPDATED: OCT 21, 2011 Poured from a 650ml bottle into a pilsner glass. Color was caramel amber. About an inch of head. Average amount of lacing on the top. The film on the sides wasnt as good as I hoped, but still had a presence. 

Very hoppy on the nose. The usual suspects with pine and citrus balancing the way. Lemon zest is the main citrus with grapefruit a semi-distant  second. 

A lot different than I expected with the taste. Some caramel in there, along with the previously mentioned citrus and pine. The initial taste immediately gives way to a sharp alcohol bite. It then smoothes out at the end with citrus finish that slowly dissipates.

Medium body. Average carbonation. Smooth and consistent taste throughout. Orange comes through later in the beer, where it seemed to be lemon and grapefruit early on.

Just a fantastic beer. It got better as I rated it. I am a bit of a Firestone homer, but its hard not to be when their beers are so good.

bottle.  clear brass body with an off-white diminishing head.  hugely resinous pine sap nose with complimentary notes of orange oil / floor wax, burnt citrus  rind and an unpleasant peanut and ethanol note.  medium body, moderately sweet, coming across sticky and a bit waxy, with strong pine sap / amber / resin rather than fruit / grass, which i prefer.  alcohol is noticeable, malt is overly rough, sweetness is far too high and the hops are excessively astringent.

Very bitter double IPA, if you like bitter, this is for you, probably the most bitter dipa I have ever had, nice flavor to it, but bitterness dominates and takes away from the taste IMO, but still worth trying, top notch.
Bottle. Slightly hazy deep golden with medium off-white head. Aroma is malt, citrus, hops, caramel and pine. Flavour is malt, pine, citrus, hops, grapefruit, caramel and bitter.

fonefan tasting. Hazy golden with an off-white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, caramel and very hoppy - pine needles and grapefruit. Flavor is quite sweet and rather bitter. Dry and rather bitter finish. 300911

Bottle @ Morten minus Peter smagning, Ulfborg. Pours cloudy golden with a small creamy white head and lacings. Nose and flavors are heavy grapefruit and pine.  Green hops. Very dry and bitter. Smooth. Ends really dry.
Bottle @ fonefan tasting. Nice head wit good duration. Color is amber. Aroma and taste are flowers, peach, citrus, malt, caramel and hops. Nicely balanced.

Love this Double IPA. Great pine aromas with a hint of citrus. Great bitterness that fades away. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

A straw-colored hazy beer with a medium cream-colored head that sticks around and leaves lace. Aroma is amazing juicy fruity hops - strawberry, grapefruit, orange. Some pine too. Flavor is a good amount of fruity hop, atop a serious caramel maltiness. Finish is bitter, alcohol well hidden. Great beer.

Pint @ Chucks. Incredibly hoppy aroma. It stings the nostrils. That said, it doesnt leave any fuzzy feelings in my mouth. Palate is incredibly smooth. More balanced than I would have expected. Fantastic.

Appearance: beautiful brilliant golden oranges under a voluminous pithy head, tight and in no hurry to disappear. Mousse-like with random bubbly pockets. Lace surrounds.

Nose: orangey hoppy juicy freshly squeezed goodness. Mango, kiwi, and guava squeezed for my pleasure. Husky in the back. Hop cones in the back. Kiwi grows as initial chill dissipates.

Palate: hits the spot! Mango, kiwi, and guava. Lemon rind in the finish along with inner ripe yellow banana skins. Tropical flesh into tropical skins for lingering juicy husky bitterness with a rawness to it. Honeycomb with more comb than honey. Tangerines freshly picked and juiced.

Final Thoughts: clean and delicious. Firestone Walker inspires and teases because I cant get any here in Florida. One of the tasting highlights of our Massachusetts vacation. Juicy hoppy goodness.

Poured from the bottle. Color is light and clear. Thin head and limited lacing. Aroma smells like fresh hop pellets right out of the bag. Smells like Amarillo hops, so Im Curio us what they used. Flavour is nicely buttered probably around 90 ibus. Palate is thick and oily, not as dry as you would expect from the high abv. Overall a awesome beer!

22oz bottle, moderate gusher.  aroma is well balanced grainy pine and distinct grapefruit.  maltiness is pleasant and comes in bounds, earthy and organic.  appearance is deep gold near ruby with active carb and floating island head, ring as well.  flavor is substantial lightly darkened citrus up front and BIG lasting bitterness on tail end, booze is present but melds well into big, beefy maltiness.  never comes across as offensive or even reveals on its own, just partners with the grain bill and rolls on through.

hazy copper, medium white head, lots of lace.  loads of citric hops in the nose with some sweet malt offset.  flavor of sweet malt, offset by a nice citric hop and a bitter end.  medium bodied, nice bitter finish.  fairly comlpex, slightly astringent mouthfeel (i like that), and an enjoyable citric hop presence.

Bomber pours a clear orange with a small off-white head. Aroma has strong malt characteristic , big orange and tangerine, pine. Strong malt and caramel presence all the way through finishing on citrus and pine bitterness.

dont see what people like in this beer.  I get none of the "big malt middle..." that they speak of in their description.  it was more like acidic, brutally hoppy saltine water.  The aroma was nice, and there was a beautiful cap of creamy-looking head, but one taste and I instantly had heartburn from the hop-acid.

Draught at BoHo.
Clear dark orange with a white head. Aroma moderate malty (caramel), heavy hoppy (classic American). Flavor moderate sweet, heavy hoppy, well balanced. Almost full body. Mums.

Poured a light yellow-amber color with a medium sized creamy off-white head.  Very nice aroma with lots of apricots and lemons.  A good amount of pine and resin as well.  Taste is very smooth and well balanced.  Creamy and fruity with lots of apricot at first.  Finish is pretty hoppy with lots of pine, lemon, and grapefruit.  Aftertaste is slightly sweet.  Overall very flavorful and well balanced.  Great IPA.

22 oz bottle  Pours light reddish amber with medium head. Lively carbonation, slick to creamy texture.  Medium body, full flavor of grass, and sweet malt.  This has a strong alcohol kick to it.  Good IPA with a lot of flavor, but I am not sure it is worth the price compared to Dogfish Head or some others.

Tap.  Ive stayed away from this beer for YEARS because I wasnt impressed by Union Jack.  This, on the other hand, is exceptional.  Big beer with a lotbto offer.  Opaque amber pour with excellent lacing.  Aroma of passion fruit, poached pears, and tea leaves.  Taste is malty sweet with grassy hops.  Palate is full and amazing.  Great beer.

650 mL bottle.  A very, very well constructed double IPA.  Nothing is out of place or balance.  The hop profile changes as it warms, with lots of citrus early on, then more and more pine as I made my way through the beer.  Stunningly drinkable for a beer this large.  I want more.

UPDATED: OCT 3, 2011 Orange gold pour with big foamy head and nice lacing. Hoppy aroma: spruce and orange. Flavor is sweet, with caramel and orange and general hoppiness, with a dry bitter sprucey finish.

Dark gold, fast receding head.  Nose equals big hoppy tones, mostly grapefruit, a tad of pine, tropical fruit.  Dry palate not as malty as normal IIPA, but not as deeply hoppy as an IPA, extremely good will be getting this again. (from BOTW).

draft at Coles, Buffalo, NY. Pours a golden orange color with small white head. Aroma is heavy grapefruit, tangerine, citrus pith, light herbal notes. Flavor is grapefruit upfront, slight alcohol tongue Grat bitterness followed up by some sweet malts. Delicious

On tap at the brewery in Paso.  Pours a hazy golden orange with a great white and frothy head that stays a great deal as you drink. Aroma is of apple, pine pitch and some sweet something I cant fully pick up.  (The way a DIPA should smell.) Taste of more apple, pineapple and some sweet caramel which really adds something Ive not gotten in other DIPAs.  Overall an awesome DIPA that I come back to again and again.  Glad this is a permanent offering from FW.
user_location: Morro Bay via Orange County, California, USA

text: On tap @ Lures, Crownsville Md-Golden pour w/a moderate head. Floral hop flavor, lots of citrus, & tangerine, Had quite a bite, but it was a nice sipper. Alcohol was well hidden. Good brew.

22 ounce bottle into tulip, no bottle date.  Pours crystal clear orangish golden amber color with 1-2 fingers of a dense off white head with great retention that reduces to a fairly thick lacing cap.  Some nice lacing clings to the glass as well.  Aromas of huge orange, grapefruit, pine, caramel, and spices.  Beautiful aromas here with big strength, this might be a fairly fresh bottle.  Taste of huge caramel, pine, orange, grapefruit, spices, and a bit of tropical fruits.  Nice amount of bitterness present on the finish with lingering notes of citrus, caramel, pine, and spices.  Fantastic balance of bitterness and sweetness in this, nothing is overwhelming.  Alcohol is practically invisible, only a very small warming on the finish noticeable.  Medium carbonation and body, with a bit of a prickly and slightly creamy mouthfeel.  Very drinkable stuff, I am surprised how easy this is going down at this alcohol level(9.5%).  Overall, this is an absolutely incredible DIPA with great balance of flavor and smooth drinkability.
Bomber. Clear golden ale, citrus nose. Bitter but sweet and a very good attempt @ balance. So drinkable.

22oz bomber out of a pilsner glass.  This is such an great brew.  Every sip is quality.  Every sip is an easy drinker, not harsh, not overpowering with abv, just striaght up IPA with a stellar kick.  the aftertaste is what brings one back for more each time.  Head starts a medium solid and then simmers down to a decent film throughout the brew.  Color is dim golden copper with pale ale highlights, but the punch that lies within remains intact.  Decadant hops, earthy and organic, soil is turned over and over and maintained, this brew is fresh.  Nose is of sweet nectar, hops, citrus undertones and a decent balance of pine and florishing wild flowers.  Ive never had a DIPA that keeps bringing me back to each sip in pure enjoyment.  So glad I picked this one up and enjoyed on a late summers even in the hills of western Mass.

1. Look - The beer looks good. There are a rush of bubbles and a sturdy head. The beer is very clear with no sediment and golden in color. 
2. Sniff - A delicate citrus aroma is present with hints of grapefruit.
3. Sip - A smooth initial sip followed up with a strong bitterness that is definitely long lasting.  The bitterness is a desirable quality of this Double IPA.
4. Another Look  The head is long lasting with steady bubbles and looks very appétit zing. 
5. Evaluate - Overall, I like this beer.  Its flavor is full and long lasting with a great bitterness characteristic.  I would most definitely recommend this Double IPA to family and friends.  This beer is a top tier quality example of the Double IPA style.

22oz bomber shared with 3...omfg this beer is incredible with the delicious aroma of hops the citrus and the floral mix. the malt mix is dead on and the the flavors of the hops increase as your drink this beer. never had one just this damn good..

Bomber, bottled 6.3.11.  Pours clear and bright orange, lively, with a 2-finger creamy beige head that leaves some sticky lacing.  Aromas of sweet and juicy papaya, guava, and pine.  Also present are caramel, some pepper, and citrus peel.  The flavor is bitter pine and candied grapefruit peel, sweet earthy malt, and spruce; a nice bitter finish, with lingering grapefruit peel.  Medium carbonation and full-bodied, slightly warming, and dry.  Very nice.  [781]

My first experience with Firestone Walker. this IIPA has a nice balance of malts and hops. The overpowering features at the nose and mouth are grapefruit,orange, and a touch of spice. A very drinkable IIPA. The only problem is I find the bottom of the bomber all to fast!
On tap at Rose Alley in New Bedford. Served in a chalice. Comes in big and meaty. Lots of grapefruit and spruce. Hits hard like a heavyweight. Very drinkable though. Nice way to start the day.
Pours a golden honey color with slight head. Nose is full of piney and cannabis. First sip is malty and nicely boozy. Finish is solid with resin hops that linger. Great beer.

650 ml. bottle. Shared with Gabe. Pours a medium, short lived, white head, with some lacing, over a clear dark gold (SRM 6) body.....nose is citrus, pine, toffee/caramel....taste ispine, citrus to start, then heavy sweet malts with toffee/caramel dominating, finishing  with pine grapefruit, touch of pineapple bitterness....mouth feel thick, slightly stlcky, slightly astringent, carbonation low.  While this is a very nice beer, it is not great. The malt back bone is dominated by simple sweetness.too much. There is minimal layering of malt complexity. The hops are done with finesse, but the malty sweetness dominates. I think the hop back bone is in decline and the beer is getting old.  BJCP 7/3/15/4/7

UPDATED: JUL 28, 2014 Another well done beer by one of my favorite brewers. Not sure who brought this one to the September 3R6P gathering. Sampled from a 22 oz brown bottle this beer poured a bright caramel-amber color with a medium sized white head that faded fairly quickly and left no lacing. The aroma was sweet pine, grapefruit, caramel and pineapple. The flavor was sweet and tangy pine, resin, grapefruit and lemon with notes of caramel, nut and bread underneath. The finish was long tangy caramel, pine and resin. Fairly full bodied. Well done.
Bottle - avg foamy head, beautiful medium amber/orange color, strong hoppy, citrus, grapefruit aroma and flavor - awesome beer!

pours yellow with a small white head, has some staying power. smells of pines and flowers, classic ipa. citrus scent. tastes like pine with a nice wet hoppy feel. very flowery and pine needles, just tasty. great mouth feel. Would recommend for sure.

UPDATED: MAR 1, 2013 On tap in 2009 (the more recent offerings of this are MUCH better)

A: Light, bright golden-amber. Moderate frothy white cap. Decent retention and lacing.

S: Pine and grapefruit. Light malt underside. Not powerful enough to draw me in.

T: A bit more pack in its punch than the nose, however, not the firepower I was expecting from a dIPA. Mostly grapefruit with a light toasted malt base.

M: Light-medium body. Thin at various points. Somewhat rounded finish.

O: Decent, but when I want a dIPA I want something that actually registers on the bitterness scale that my tongue measures. In fact I think the regular FW union jack has more hop in its step.

Oh boy.  i am pretty excited about this little guy.  Nice orange color with an off white foamy head.  Oh my goodness this beer smells delicious.  It is like a forest of pine trees with many pine needles scattered on the ground and pine resin stuck on your body.  Hehe.  Taste is like a flowering pine tree!  Orange peels with dandelions and pine needles again!  I recommend this beer highly!

Medium sized offwhite head with good retention and a nice lacing. Bright, copper, amber colored brew. Nose is nice. Juicey with grapefruit and some funky malt notes. Body is med/full, little oily, little resiny with a soft carbonation. Citrus and grassy hop flavors with a mildly sweet malty backing. Hints of grapes and earth, light honey notes, malts are a bit sweet,, for me. Gentle bitternes in the finish, fruity, citrusy and lasting. Underwhelmed. Bomber from statelineliquors.

August 13, 2011 - bomber from lagerloather shared with MesandSim, Reakt, Nate2g and others.  Am I finally understanding why so many Brits hate crystal malt?  Because I was stunned by how underwhelmed I was by this beer - how most of the British-made IPAs I had during my trip blew this out of the water, and none of them used crystal malt....hmmm.   Anyway.  Bright, slightly hazy amber-gold with a smallish frothy/creamy beige head.  Aroma is quite sweet, a bit boozy, herbal, resinous, pungent and weirdly medicinal - barely a 7.  Taste is okay, but underwhelming, a real caramel character to the malt, it distracts from the solid dry somewhat characterless grapefruit bitterness, and that earthy, medicinal character intrudes as well - blue basil? - whatever, I dont care for it much;  a bit boozy too.  Sticky mouthfeel, undercarbonated, longish bitter finish, sharply herbal and pungent (yeah, basil .... why, FFS?).  Not BAD, but I wouldnt have it again.
Golden caramel body. Floral and citrus hops all come together nicely. Overall a good value too. Not too sweet and would love to try it fresh

22 oz bottle. Pours a clear orange with a 1 finger white head. Excellent lace and head retention. Strong citrus hop aroma with a touch of honey. Well balanced with malt and honey up front, doing a dangerously good job of masking the alcohol. Then a blast of floral, citrus hops towards the middle, lasting to the end. Heavy, full body with a mouthcoating palate. The finish is long and bitter, but with a hint of sweetness. Will seek this one out agian.

Pours clear golden, reasonable off white head. notes of grapefruit, pine on the nose. Malt bomb, pine, pineapple hop bitterness. rich, sweet and a slight bit of syrup texture. sticky on the lips. Quite good but was hoping for a bit more...

22 oz bottle from Beverages 4 Less in Santee, California, served in an English pint. Pours clear orange-amber with a small white head. The head fades quickly to a thin remnant, leaving a small amount of lace. The nose has big notes of grapefruit and orange, along with flowers, pineapple, some pine and a touch of caramel. The flavour is intensely bitter throughout, with smooth pine, citrus carried over from the aroma and plenty of resinous hops. The finish is long and bitter, with a peppery note. On the palate, it is medium in body with a smooth, syrupy texture and soft carbonation. Overall, this is an excellent imperial IPA. The aroma is quite beautiful, with harmonious citrus, fruit and pine. It is flavourful, but also subtle and quite enjoyable. Another gem from Firestone Walker. 2011-08-13

Bomber from Bottle Barn in Santa Rosa, CA.  Pleasant aroma of juicy fruits - apricot and orange.  Tastes are juicy citrus hops with strong earthy caramel malt backing.  Not a crazy hop bomb - floral bitter, but focus is the citrus.  Good balance.  Medium texture with lightly dry bitter finish.  Covers the alcohol well.  Amazing brew.

Weicher, gleichzeitig starker Hopfenantrunk. Dieser ist ausgewogen und bietet ein gleichermaßen hopfiges, grasiges und fruchtiges Feld. Im Mittelteil erkennt man den dahinterstehenden Alkohol, der aber in keiner Form einen negativen Eindruck hinterlässt sondern eher zum allgemeinen guten Geschmack beiträgt. Blumig, weiterhin vollmundig, Süßlich aber mit gelungenem herben Augleich. Ein rundum gelungenenes IIPA! 8/12/12/13/10/12
Pours copper with a light white head. Aroma is grapefruit, citrus, hops.  Flavor is piney, citrus , hops with hints of grapefruit. Pretty refreashing beer.
Pours a clear copper with a small head and a little lacing. Nice citrus aroma. Great hop flavor that finishes cleanly. Has a bit of a maltly backbone at the end.

22oz bottle.  Pours a clear golden orange with a medium creamy white head that retains well and laces the glass some.

The aroma is floral, piney, resiney hops with some fruit.

The flavor is a little sweet malt and melon with a big piney, peppery, resinous hop finish.  Lots of bitterness that lingers in the finish.  The mouthfeel is medium to full bodied with low carbonation.

Overall, a monster onedimensional hop bomb.  This is much more bitter in the bottle than on draft.  This and the Union Jack remind me a lot of Odells IPA - very similar flavor profile.

Very pale colored, lacy white head. Aroma of citrus masks some of the Simcoe(Amarillo?) oniony smell. Smooth spicey/sweet toffee flavors, very rich with many layers. Long lasting bitter hops rule the finish. Very nice, a little understated for a double.

Bottle poured into a stemless wine glass.  Pours a darkish peach with an offwhite head.  Smell is of sugary citrus notes with a known malt backing.  Taste hides the 9.5% very well inside the  citrus hops (tropical, orange zest and some grapefuit).  As it warms more and more powerful notes come out.  Great, great brew.  Too bad cant have it in Georgia.

Pours a golden color with a slight haze.  Respectable white head that laces the glass.  Aroma is grapefruit and pine cones.  Taste is a rock candy like sweetness of pale malt, grapefruit and pine once again, and a profound robust hop bitterness.  Well balanced though, with ABV barely showing.

Bottle. Pours a clear golden color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity piney hoppy grapefruit aroma. Sweetish malty hoppy bitter grapefruit flavor. Has a sweetish malty hoppy bitter pieny grapefruit finish.

On draft.  Very dark bar, hard to tell the color. Looked orange with an off white head. Orange, pinapple, mango and some sweeter citrus on the nose. Taste is fantastic!  Sweet orange, mango, pineapple, ripe peach flavors balance out the hop bitterness perfectly.  This was a bitter double ipa, but the citrus and tropical fruit balances everything out nicely. Medium body with just enough carbonation to accent both bitterness and fruit flavors.  Dangerously drinkable.  This is a world class DIPA!  Very impressed with this one.

UPDATED: AUG 13, 2011 Bottle. No date on the bottle so it was pretty much a shot in the dark. Appearance: Brown pour with decent white head and nice lacing. Aroma: Earthy and leafy hops upfront, lots of grass but not so much fruit. I love it. Taste: I get the earthy hops again, but I detect much more malt (Caramel) and the alcohol is present but nicely integrated. Palate: Solid mouthfeel, medium carbonation. Overall: Exactly my type of IIPA, we got lucky on this one this was pretty fresh.

(22oz bomber thanks to BMan1113VR) clear rich orange with soapy tan bubbles. Nose of mango, pineapple and its rind, a bit dank and more citrus rind. Taste of pineapple, mango, papaya, guava, sweet and delicious! An amazing DIPA.
Pours a amber orange with a white head.  Aroma is resiny, citrus and spicey.  Taste is a perfect combo of bittersweetness.  Mouthfeel is sticky.  A premier IPA, thanks to chalsk for this one.

Bright copper colored pour. Started out with a sizable white head, but it fades quickly and leaves a little bit of lacing. Big hoppy, citrusy aroma. Some malt in there too. Big malty taste with a big bitter bite. Sweet and tangy. Grapefruit and flowers. Very nice bitterness lingers, mixed with a carbonic dryness and a nice sweet mouth feel. Very good IIPA.

clear darker golden with nice dense white head leaving a hint of lacing.  Nice citrus nose, faint pine, slight malt sweetness.  Full palate coats the tongue with sharp hop bitterness.   Malt provides balance but its hops and slight warming alcohol.   Big and hearty and tons of flavor.   Not for novices or wusses.   Would be a great brew to sit back with on a chilly fall night.

Aroma	Fruity, citrusy, herbal
Appearance	Pale orange, light frothy head
Taste	Sweet grapefruit, dry, slightly peppery, bitter, floral hops
Palate	Smooth, silky, dry finish

Pours a one finger white head that fades slowly to a thin layer leaving a good lace. Crystal clear amber color.  Good carbonation and medium bodied.  Grapefruit nose, flavor is same almost sweet grapefruit, dry finish. $8.75 for a 22oz bottle from Berts Better Beers Hooksett, NH.

UPDATED: MAR 14, 2012 The pour is a sparkling clear, pale orange with a moderately full, white, creamy, frothy head which settles to a frothy layer throughout and leaves frothy, drippy lace.  The nose is very fragrant, very citrusy and spicy; lots of pepper, white grapefruit and faint passionfruit, some green hops, leafy hops, and a slight honeyed malt background.  The flavor is similar but turning a bit herbal (maybe basil, as the description suggests?), still grapefruit and tangerine, pepper everywhere almost chile pepper-esque, some honeyed cereal notes underneath, and a nearly high bitterness.  The palate is nearly lively, nearly full, creamy, sticky, and oily.  The beer finishes with the peppery spice almost seeming warm, bitter herbal notes, slight resin, and similar citrus notes still keeping from a dry IIPA.  My first experience with Firestone and I was pleasantly surprised.  Very different from other IIPAs, lots of peppery spice but minimal dryness, a pleasant malt base but still a nearly high bitterness, and very high herbal notes but still quite drinkable.  The palate worked very well for me with just enough carbonation and body as well as a mixture of mouthfeel textures that was just nice.  I am surprised by this one, the citrus calmed the intense pepper, the pine/resin notes were minimal which kept the dryness low, and somehow the herbal notes only added nice complexity.  Very nice surprise.
Sampled in a big bottle. Pours deep brown with a thick head on it. The hops are very fresh and leave a bit of a taste in the mouth. A very good brew.
Poor light gold with little head. Smell is dried grass with a little sweetness. Taste is raw grapefruit pulp with a little honey. Good stuff thx kickinchalice.

8/5/11. 22oz bomber courtesy KickInChalice! Clear amber pour with a small tan head. Dank, malty aroma with plenty of sweetness. Rich, sweet flavor with caramel, citrus, pineapple, and more. Very balanced, but I was hoping for more fresh hop character. Not bad!

Bottle shared by JaBier. The beer pours a clear copper color with a medium thick fluffy white head that has good retention. Rings of lacing on the glass. Aroma of caramel malt, floral hops and fruit.Medium body with a moderately bitter hops character that has resiny and floral qualities. Notes of sweet malt and citrus as well. The finish is hoppy with a lingering bitterness left behind. Good IIPA all around.

Had on Tap @ Flying Saucer, Kansas City .. . Pours a deep gold, great foam .. . lots of pine, resin and sap- very pure and sticky .. . I really enjoyed this brew and very well made also.. . were looking for treasure!

bomber on #IPADay - purchased at Whole Foods in Fairfax, VA.  pours a bright orange with a 2 finger creamy white head which falls to a thin lacing.  big citrus hop nose with some herbal qualities and a bit of spice.  medium to full body with lots of citrus bitterness and an underlying malt base that balances things out.  Very creamy throughout.  Soft, delicate and assertive.  Big finish with tons of orange peel, lemon and lots of lingering bitterness.  Outstanding IIPA!

22oz bomber, first from Firestone, tangerine orange hue with white creamy head, resin/piney aroma with lots of alcohol, grapefruit hops and bread malt, very astringency/alcohol comes through and though, subtle, balanced and clear but overriding alcohol detracted a tad, description says enjoy in moderation must be because the alcohol, better to share

UPDATED: AUG 27, 2011 22oz - Frothy white head over orange liquid leave nice lacing as it subsides. Fresh, resinous, citrus aromas. The taste is malt offsetting the hops, with nothing out of balance. Nice.

Just as awesome on tap. - 27 Aug 11

I pour the brew into my nonic pint glass and it arrives a very clear golden color with a frothy off white head sitting on top.  It leaves a good amount of lacing as it subsides too.

The nose is super fresh smelling.  Lots of resiny and citrus hop aromas.  Tons of grapefruit and tangerine.  Slight grassy note in there as well.

The taste is a lot of the same.  The hops just jump out at you.  Citrus and resin once again.  A slight bready malt character lends some backing to this hoppy attack.  And an alcohol bite comes through in the finish as it warms up.

I poured a 22oz bomber into a tulip glass.Appearance: Initially a very hazy, bright orange complexion. Forms a fairly large, white, frothy head that retains and laces very well. As I get towards the bottom of the bottom the beer becomes completely transparent and more red (Ive no idea why, though).Smell: Strong, sticky, syrup-like scent of mango, guava and papaya with some grapefruit juice. Flowes, pine needles and spiced rum are also quite prominent.Taste: Its rare that I encounter a beer whose palate is a combination of intense richness and bitterness simultaneously. Double Jack hits the tongue like pure tropical fruit juice concentrate or preservatives. At fridge temp this taste is actually very refreshing and lightly sweet. Strong bitterness follows immediately thereafter. Its sticky pine and resin combined with a liquor-like dryness. The tongue is saturated with the juicy sweetness and the hoppy bitterness - which makes for a very strange, but satisfying, sensation. As the beer warms the fruit flavors become richer and sweeter, tasting more like pure honey, maple syrup, or fruit extract. The bitterness remains about the same, but a rum-like spice begins to take hold as well. Its definitely a lot for the palate to handle, but because its so tasty its difficult to stop drinking.Mouthfeel: Full-bodied in all aspects - thick, sticky mouthfeel with a palate thats always intense. Whats amazing is despite the intense palate the hops do not linger here, giving the beer an amazing clean finish with no cloying, drying aftertaste.Drinkability: The only thing keeping Double Jack from being a perfect beer is the fact its a sipper. Even at fridge temp I found it difficult to drink more than a sip at a time. The sweetness and bitterness overwhelm the palate with a slight alcohol warmth on the throat. I guess this is to be expected considering its 9.5% ABV, although I have had even bigger beers that were smoother. This would probably be an ideal beer to pair with a hearty, spicy meal, but as a beer within itself its still enjoyable - but drinking more than one serving is challenging. Overall, Double Jack is one of the most impressive double IPAs Ive ever had. And while I wouldnt consider it a perfect beer, I understand where its reputation comes from.
22oz bottle. Pours clear copper with small white bubbly head. Amazing citrus aroma, grapefruit, candied sugar. Taste is resin and citrus. Very bitter that is especially present on lingering finish.

Draft at the Dutch this evening.  Nose of grapefruity hops.  Nice medium golden amber.  Oily bubbly head.  Nice open lacing.  Big body but not Godzilla big. I am rooting for the alcohol so that it may assist in anesthetizing my bruised and battered self from this weekends firewood gathering and splitting marathon.  Yeah, the left coast has something to brag about in this nice critter.

Nice amber/orange color; Medium slightly creamy body; Aroma of pine/floral hops, fruit, caramel malt, & citrus; Flavor of sweet malt, caramel, pine hops, some mango/pineapple, and citrus (notably orange & grapefruit); Finish is dry & bitter; Nicely balanced; Overall, very good and clean tasting DIPA.

Tap at Mayor of Old Town - oh yea - super dry imperial IPA here - crisp, Biscuity malt base sets the stage for dry, bitter grapefruit pith, orange rind, dank/resin/pine, woody character - very peppery and herbal - bitterness is intense, but not at all abrasive - perfectly masked alcohol - love it.

UPDATED: FEB 27, 2013 Date: July 28, 2011 Mode: Draft Source: Flying Saucer, Kansas City, MO Appearance: Translucent bronze with little head, nice amount of lacing. Aroma: Hoppy and alcohol. Flavor: Consistent with aroma, medium bodied. Other: Little bit too strong on the alcohol for me, could be that double ipas are just not my thing. 
Tried again at Foundry on 2/27/13. This had way more head. Hoppy but also fruity and sweet. Liked this much better. Funny both times I have had this in KC.

Fairly clear light copper pour with a fluffy white head, great retention. Very dank citrus aroma, slightly floral, Id be surprised if there wasnt any columbus added at the end of the boil, pacific northwest hops on display for sure. On the palate its a blast of sweetness up front that delicately transitions to hop bitterness and finishes with some dried grapefruit. Overall a delicious west coast imperial IPA. Very well done.

I hope the Craft Ale House in PA can supply a lot of this beer, because it has become one of my new favorite IPAs.  I sampled a glass of this at the Ale House in Limerick and I was very impressed!
