The beer poured a dark golden color with a slight orange hue.  The head featured an off-white color and was ample in size.  It showed some very good lacing around the edges of the glass.  The floral nose was perfectly balanced and was very inviting, with notes of citrus and hop resin.  I also got a slight hint of malt, bread and yeast.  The body was really smooth and extremely drinkable.  This is a very dangerous IPA, as you can barely sense the alcohol content in this.  I could have sat at the CAH bar all afternoon and drank one of these after another.  The flavors, as the nose, were perfectly balanced and delicious.  There was plenty of spicy and floral hop flavor, along with a balancing tone of caramel malt, bread and yeast.  With no disrespect to East Coast brewers, the folks on the West Coast, especially in California, know who to brew exceptional IPAs.  This one is definitely a true winner!  I loved this beer so much on draft, I had to take home a bomber.
(bottle) golden amber with white head. Huge grapefruit aroma. Flavor is grapefruit and tangerine hops. Quite bitter.
Smooth aftertaste to this highly bitter IIPA.  This is a well-rounded drink, with strong pine and sticky hop mouthfeel.  Strong.

On tap this brew pours out a medium amber color with  a nice fast disappearing head. Aromas of hops grapefruits along with other citrus  fruits and roasted malts. Tastes surprisingly  mellow considering its a double i p a. Semi sweet finish with a nice lingering aftertaste, very little alcohol presence .

Bottle. Light amber with generous off white head that disappears fairly quickly after the pour. Grapefruit, hops, booze, caramel; medium-bodied, good mouthfeel, well carbonated, starts sweet, growing bitterness but not overwhelming, finish is sweet and bitter, somewhat boozy. Decent DIPA but a little too sweet for my liking.

Bottle on 12/17/10 from az wine.

Slightly hazy orange colored pour with a toasted off white head.

The nose is full of candied grapefruit mixed with pineapple, orange, sweet malt, florals and a touch of pine.

The flavor is pretty much the same though a bit on the sweet side. Woodiness shows up on the finish along with a ton of hoppiness (which lingers as piney in the aftertaste) to dry it out.

The mouth feel is a little syrupy before the hops kick in. medium/medium-full bodied, soft and lux but mildly bitter. 7.5/3/7/3/16/3.7

Pours crystal clear. Light amber. Creamy head.

Nose: Wonderful citrus hops explode from the glass.

Palate: Medium body, flavorful, very citrusy/lemony hops, warm alcohol, but not harsh, finishes dry for a double.

Conclusion: Imperial IPAs are not my favorites, however Firestone walker did a great job ballancing this big boy.Its a solid imperial; Firestone Walker does not make bad beer!

Pours amber. Medium quite frizzy head. Aroma is absolutely faboulus. Shitloads of hops. Apricots, citrus, and mango (?!?) Medium bitterness. Perfectly smooth finish. The best IPA Ive had together with Pliny the Elder.

A very enjoyable dipa the only thing is that it is overly grapefruity which makes the beer very sticky in its palate. Instead of wanting to drink more, you find yourself wanting a glass of water. the color is very appetizing and besides the overwhelming grapefruit taste, this is one of the better dipas Ive had.

Pours mid to dark amber with notes of bitter citrus fruit.  The citrus becomes more pronounced on the palate and the malt ties in a nice yin to the bitterness of the hops yang.  Big long finish for a great DIPA.

Double Jack
Pours perfectly clear copper with a medium white head. Strong aroma of hops and booze with hints of caramel malt. Flavor is bittersweet caramel and hops. Strong bold flavor with booze and citrus. Holy hops this one is strong. Hopheads must love this. Very good

This is another you know it when you taste DIPA.  Starting with the citrus nose and the golden pour and onto the awesome yet enigmatic flavor this deserves its spot in the top 25.  Truly a great experience.

From a 22oz bomber into snifter.  Pours with some really nice fluffy head.  Plenty of lacing.  Aroma is of flowers, lime, and alcohol.  Color is a gorgeous orange.  Mouthfeel is almost the same as the regular FW Jack... which is to say, very nice.  Taste is of flowers, honey, pine, mango, pineapple and alcohol.  An excellent DIPA. I gotta say, I do like the regular FW Union Jack a little better than this one... but still, this is a keeper.

Tap sample. Poured copper color with a large frothy white head that was mostly lasting with excellent lacing. Moderate to heavy sour citrus west coast hop and fruit aroma. Medium to full body with slick texture and soft carbonation. Medium to heavy smooth bittersweet citrus flavor with a medium to heavy bittersweet finish of moderate to long duration.This is a standout beer.

09-JUL-2011, bottle @Ulkløbben Summerparty. Brought by Henrik.
Clear orange with white head.
Lemon and grape fruit is evident.
Some malts in the background but still a bit thin bodied. Long creamy aftertaste that is really bitter. Fantastic taste with loads of fruity hoppy stuff. Really good IIPA.

Sampled at SIB. Pours a clear golden orange with a thin white head. Aroma of grapefruit, citrus hops, and pine. Flavours include grapefruit, citrus hops, pine, caramel and resin. Very nicely balanced, full bodied and beautiful.

Bottle.... Clear light amber pour , thin off white head , excellent lace . Dense fruity hop aroma , peach , grapefruit and tangerine . Sweet caramel malt flavor backed by an excellent fruity hop bitterness . Medium bodied , smooth and creamy mouthfeel . Excellent bitterness in the finish . Fantastic .
On draft served in a Tulip glass.  Extremely bitter upfront and super carbonated.  Grapefruit in flavor.  Really clean tasting and a slick mouth feel.  One of the best Double IPAs Ive ever had.

22 oz. bottle.  Date on the neck:  03/14/11.  A relatively clear copper pour with a thick antique white head.  Excellent balance in the aroma with a great deal of caramel to offset the resiny pine and grapefruitiness.  Full-bodied and syrupy on the way down.  Lots of caramel, breadiness, and some rye qualities upfront in the taste.  Vanilla in the middle.  Some spruce and grapefruitiness at the tail end.  Solid stuff.

I didnt know that this beer had a 100/99 rating on ratebeer when I bought it. I just bought it cuz it was called "double jack" and it was only $9. Reason enough. Its beer.

I started drinking it after finishing two Dogfish 90-minute IPAs. Just a coincidence, but comparison is inevitable. 

Compared to DFH 90m, this beer is cloying and syrupy. Good, solid and tasty, but missing what makes a great beer great.

Thanks to Total Wine & More in Cherry Hill, NJ for stocking this.  Pours a hazy orange-copper with a tall light tan head and curtains of lacing worthy of a Broadway stage.  As soon as it hits the bottom of the glass you get the aroma of a citrus grove punctuated by pine trees.  Huge citrusy hops, caramel, milk chocolate, pine needles and a hint of Granny Smith apples.  Rock solid malt backbone.  Smooth medium body and a modestly dry, flavorful and quick finish.  A great IIPA all around.

Bomber bottle from The Beer Store. This is an excellent DIPA. Pours deep golden with white head. Nose full of citrus hops. Flavor was bursting with citrus and grassy hops, tempered with sweet malts, and finishing with a hop crispness. Medium body, great finish, just an excellent brew from start to finish. A hop lovers dream.

UPDATED: AUG 3, 2013 Bottle 650ml @ Hotel Room, Courtyard Oyster Point, San Francisco, CA
Pours clear deep golden with a off-white head. Aroma has notes of malt, caramel, citrus, grape, pine and alcohol. Taste is medium to heavy sweet and medium bitter with a long rather sweet fruity and bitter finish. Body is full, texture is oily, carbonation is soft.
Bottle 650ml
Pours clear amber with a off-white head. Aroma has notes of malt, caramel, citrus and grape. Taste is medium to heavy sweet and medium bitter. Body is full, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [8 4 7 4 15 = 3.8 7/8/2011]

Deep gold color with a big rocky head.  Aroma is citrus with a bit of grass and hay.  Taste is citrusy hops with a long bitter finish, just a hint of booze at the end.  Mouth feel is great, a bit oily with some noticeable carbonation... just right for this beer.  A great DIPA.

Pours bright yellow orange with a stiff and sticky white head. Big hoppy west coast iipa aroma, just as youd expect. The flavor is big and piney with a citrus finish. Battery with a tangible. Medium body with plenty of oil, and a balanced finish. Its been quite a while since Ive had a new iipa this good

UPDATED: JUL 7, 2011 Location/Date:Bottle shared with Dave on 7/4/2011.
Appearance: Pours a nice orange haze. 
Aroma: Aroma is of citrus and pine.
Taste: Medium bitterness that is not overpowering.
Palate:Medium body, smooth, covers alcohol well. Short aftertaste which is occasionally hard to find in a DIPA.
Summary: I enjoyed this beer a lot. It has a lot of qualities of a DIPA without overpowering you, which can be appreciated.

I felt like this was a much stronger, sharper, bolder version of the drinkable Union Jack. This was more like sipping a scotch whiskey. Well balanced, quite smooth even if it had a bit of alcohol to it, it was well masked and refined.

Bottle shared courtesy of jcos.  One of the better DIPAs Ive had because the flavor is big and bold and hoppy but yet its remarkably drinkable and very smooth.  Well balanced for a DIPA and does hide the alcohol well.  Also, drinks well when warm.
On tap. How??? Pours an orange red color. Very smooth, sweet, and lengthy. Notes of caramel and dried apricot not overt bitter or astringent. Damn good.
A very nice DIPA.  Pours clear gold with a white head.  ABV well hidden.  Nice clean beer with citrus hops.  Little bit of caramel malt for balance, but the flavor is all citrus.  Well done.
Bottle. Orange pour with light tan head. Orange, citrus, and fresh pine aroma. Citrus, pine, and grassy flavors have a light malt counterpart hiding the alcohol.

Thanks to James and Susan for sharing this. It pours deep clear gold with white head. The aroma has big bold hop notes such as spicy hops, malt sweetened citrus hops and some malt sweetness in the background. Smells great. The taste is pleasingly similar to the nose with big yummy sweet citrus hop flavor, spicy hops and slick malt sweetness. It gets modestly bitter with hops toward the finish. Awesome tasting hoppy brew.
22oz bottle-pours an off white head and gold color.  Aroma is citrus/pine, some light malt.  Taste is citrus-lemon zest/pine, some light malt-caramel.  Dry finish.  Good effervescence.

Piured from the bomber into my Sam Adams glass, this had a clear bronze body with a single-fingered head and some slippery lace.  The aroma was citrusy with tangerines, pink grapefruit, and lemon zest covering a grainy sweetness with a touch of earthiness.  The medium bodied ale had a surge of malty sweetness followed by the citrusy hops and a sturdy bitterness that wasnt quite as big as Id expected.  Finshing fairly dry with a decent enough biitterness (am I getting jaded?), this was a tasty, repeatable brew.

Poured into a snifter.

3.5 A: Clear medium orange color. Two fingers of white, creamy/frothy hybrid head. Average retention and a moderate amount of lacing.

4.0 S: Piney and citrusy hops. Tropical fruits including orange, mango, pineapple, and papaya. Malts are slightly bready with a fairly strong neutral maltiness underneath. Clean overall.

4.0 T: Hops flavor is like the nose. Lots of tropical fruit - mango, pineapple, papaya, and orange - with light pine and grapefruit. Surprisingly low bitterness. Moderate neutral maltiness, fairly bready, and maybe a bit of biscuit in there as well.

3.5 M: Medium body. Good moderate carbonation. I wish this was a bit creamier though. Smooth.

4.0 D: Good beer, but its in a weird state between a dry, hop-bursted west coast DIPA and an east coast malt fest. Surprisingly bready for a non-bottle conditioned brew, but clean.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 06-23-2011 04:23:58

This is in my estimation the best IPA available on the east coast.  Pours murky amber with a white head. Leafy green hop aromas.  Flavors of cirtus, hops and a sweet malty backbone.  Very balanced. Coats the palate with hops.  Absolutely awesome!

UPDATED: MAR 16, 2013 Pours a translucent orange with a fair white head and smells of cat piss, orange blossom, and a bit of pine.  This IIPA is fantastic.  Very citrusy (grapefruit and lemon) with a bit of pine in the background.  It isnt heavy in the least.  Theres a very refreshing quality to it that makes it a great summer option.  I love this beer.  Its a true gem and far superior to many other IIPAs that have a higher price point.  Id like to drink it next to Pliney and some of my other IIPA favorites, because I suspect it would match up nicely.
a standard double ipa: big and hoppy.  pours hazy yellow and topped with a fluffy white head, this brew has grapefruit aroma and fruity flavor.

UPDATED: JUN 24, 2011 Bomber thanks to Dak. About 3 months old, March 2011 bottling. Pours a crystal clear copper color with a large white head and some lacing. A sweet citrus and orange peel nose. The flavor is reminiscent of some of George Bretts bats, huge pine resin; sweet candied oranges, resin, bitterness, pine, massive fruit, some pears and more oranges. Super drinkable and has that addictive sweet hop profile that the top IIPAs have. Honestly, I could drink a few pints of this and get smashed. Had a second bottle, bottled on 3/14/11 drank in mid-June. Huge oranges and massive flavor. Awesome.

Pours a crystal clear, I mean super duper clear orange yellow color with a nice white head. This has to be the clearest IPA Ive ever seen, a full 5 points on appearance. Aromas are delicious citrus and floral hops. The taste is a very well balanced hoppyness leaning more toward the hoppy side than the malty side. Very impressive beer from Firestone walker.

Oh my, what delicious and glorious Ale! This is strong! Very strong. This is strong like one of my best girls glorious butt cheeks who liked to go to the gym and do specific exercises to make her lower portions meaty and strong! Oh how she would show off while we were together. She would often put on an LP of Louis Prima after she had bathed and oiled her magnificent frame and would go about a posing routine while we enjoyed fine Ale and the smooth sounds of the great Louis Prima. While this beer is powerful, it does not take away from the wonderful fruits and hay like flavor that this beer delivers. I would love to drink this beer often but it is strong like bull and would lead to a larger tolerance which would not be conducive to my normal routine of fine Ale and my best girls activities of love and valor. I have had many special beers but I must say that this is above the normal Ales that conjure up a fine appetite for love and food. This Ale is worth the additional price should it squeeze your wallet just a bit.

Draft at Rustico - Alexandria. Poured a dark copper color with a medium sized white head. Aroma was citrus hops - full of tropical pineapple, tart fruits, grapefruit especially. Flavor was big on malt, hops not nearly as powerful in the taste. A bit oily, though body wasnt too heavy. Alcohol peaks its head out and says "hi!"

THOUGHTS: Wow. Nothing earth shattering, but perfectly crafted. Hid alcohol very well. Extremely easy to drink for something this big.
TECHNICAL: Bottle. Poured a light orangey amber with an average, off-white head that mostly diminished and left excellent lacing. The aroma had moderate to heavy cookie, caramel, sugar, candy; lighter molasses; moderate to heavy resin, citrus, orange, tropical fruit and earthy hops; a little maple syrup; and alcohol. The initial flavor was moderately sweet and light to moderately bitter; while the finish was rather sweet and rather to heavily bitter with a long duration. There was caramel, tropical fruits, apricot, citrus, tons of caramel-coated fruit, a perfect blending of sweet and bitter; toast, cookie, candy, candied tropical fruit, and definitely some grapefruit tang at the end. The very close to full body was oily and then dry with lightly fizzy, but very tingly, carbonation and a dry and lightly alcoholic finish.

Hoppy and delicious flavor; full hop profile, bitter but not overwhelmingly so.  I had a glass of this outside on a warm summer evening and found it very refreshing.  The aroma was quite interesting, something reminding me of trees and the forest, but also some hints of fruit.

Nose is heavy on the pine and resin, slightly grassy, grapefruit and some melon, crisp grains and light caramel, solid dose of alcohol.  Pours a very clear golden color with fluffy white head, good retention and lots of lacing.  Flavor: nice robust hop character, pine and grapefruit, stiff bitterness, sticky resin.  Nice malt profile, caramel and some residual sweetness, noticeable alcoholic bite but not overly distracting.  Medium body and carbonation, slightly slick sweetness, crisp and bitter aftertaste.

In short: A by-the-book clean and crisp citrusy & grassy IPA.  Very good beer
How: Bottle 22oz.  Consumed relatively fresh approximately 3 months after it was first bottled
The look: Clear golden body topped by a medium off-white head with good retention
In long: The very hoppy nose is full of citrus fruits with a focus on grapefruits.  Taste is mostly about the hops.  A solid bready malt backbone with a fresh baguette flavor.  Some white sugar (crystal malts?) and only a tiny bit of honey and caramel.  Hops are dominant with plenty of grapefruits/citrus but also a lot of fresh and dry grass.  Very clean and crisp.  Bitterness level is medium-high  Its hard to find anything wrong with a beer like this, a beer that any IPA lover will find impossible not to like.  Drinks very easy for a near 10% beer.  Before I knew it the bottle was empty, I really killed that beer.  Then threw the empty bottle in the ocean.  I was hoping this would make me more popular, did not, worked for Obama though.

Bomber shared with mattyb83.  Pours a clean golden orange with almost no head.  Aroma of orange rind, grapefruit, slight booze, and slight herbal overtones.   Big, juicy, hop component in the flavor.  Cutie tangerines, grapefruit rind bitterness, apricot/marmalade and oily hops.  Huge mouth feel with only a mellow, slightly bitter finish.  Not a malt bomb whatsoever.  A real nice DIPA.

This is technically rating #401 because Im taking notes on whether the Brewdog Royal Virility Performance gives me a boner.  I suppose I could just rate and then edit the rating throughout the night, but Ive already begun to write it out in my notepad and Id rather not waste the precious paper.  

On to Double Jack.  Bottle from Phillybeer7779.  Big thanks man!  Clear orange with a small white head.  This is what I look for in a DIPA for the appearance.  Big citrus and tropical fruit aroma.  Grapefruit, some spicy herb notes, orange, and a touch of marmalade.  Caramel becomes prevalent in the taste of this beer.  More grapefruit and tropical fruit appears as wells.  Mildly bitter finish with a medium body.  Thank you once again Firestone Walker for crafting another solid beer.

No boner yet, btw.

Tap at 1702 in tucson-light orange with a fizzy white head.  big citric nose-just the opposite of the SN Hoptimum i had just before this beer.  pineapple, grapefruit, tangerine, and lite pine- a bit catty as well but wasnt over the top like some.  tropical flavors-peach, tangerine, and pineapple with a bitter piney finish to dry things out.  a very well balanced IIPA!  Most IIPAs that are tropical do not have the bitterness like this one does.  Its a bit sweet but again, the dry hops on the finish help thigns out with this one.  I dig!!!!

On tap at Capones.  Golden pour, smallish head.  Strong aroma of grapefruit.  Citrusy hops (grapefruit) dominate, but some nice floral notes as well.  Fruity sweetness keeps this from being overly one-dimensional, but make no mistake, its plenty bitter for the hoppiest hophead!  Pretty darned good.  Would seek out more FW beers now.

Bottle shared with Gabe, Thanks. Poured amber/copper with small white foamy head. Aroma was fruity, grassy, and malty. Taste was similar with a slight sugar taste. Had a very smooth mouth feel and very easy to drink for being 9.5% alcohol. Over all a very tasty DIPA.

Bottle via Spark-dog!  Shared with the infamous wolf. Great nose of fruits: Grapefruit, bitterness, and floral juices. Dark orange color, with a small head. Taste is bitter on the tounge. Lots of grapefruit, juicy bitterness, flower notes.....well balanced with some malty notes and sugar...  The alcohol isnt noticable but you know its a high octane beer. Medium body. Overall: Nice DIPA.... thanks E for knocking this off my wants list!

On tap at Capones, Norristown, PA. Very inviting deep orange pour, not nearly as cloudy as a lot of DIPAs tend to be. Translucent, vigorously carbonated, and quite clean looking. Nose is also far less malty than I expected, given descriptions I encountered before sampling. Bright, floral, and dry aromas for the most part. Body is crisp, a bit prickly, with a smooth dry finish. Flavors are where you detect the malt profile just a bit more, but its anything but bready and chewy; in fact, its so clean and dry throughout that I found myself wondering if Id encountered some bottle variation, given how frequently other ratings mention the strong biscuity caramel stuff that I just cant detect. Regardless, its very fresh and pert and easy-drinking for a big beer like this.

UPDATED: AUG 10, 2014 Pours very clear and bubbly with a color of liquid gold. Great lacing from a bright white head. Sweet aroma with big grapefruit hops. Lots of citrus scents. Flavor was malty sweet with smooth bitterness. Finish was real clean despite the high IBUs. Very tasty!

22 oz bottle.  I just finished working in the yard on a warm SoCal day and I could not have picked a better beer to drink while watching the end of the Angels game.  Pours a clear copper, big frothy head, and a ton-o-lacing.  Hops and citrus punch you in the nose.  Flavor is sweet and malty.  Typicaly flavors of a west coast IPA.  The ABV is hardly noticeable and this is a very easy beer to drink....very dangerous.  However, I like my DIPA to be hop bombs and this falls short.  Not a very long lasty bitter finish.  Overall, still a very decent DIPA.

UPDATED: AUG 19, 2011 Pours a very clear orangish golden color with a thick white head that leaves lacing galore.  Aromas just out with citrus: grapefruit, tangerines, and dare I say lime.   Taste is a nice blend of sourness and bitterness with just enough alcohol revealing itself to remind you its there.   The palate is lighter that I anticipated with a dry, bitter finish that dissipates nice and slow.  Overall, this is a mighty fine beer with a wonderful mix of malts and hops fulfill my idea of the ideal DIPA.

Bottle.  Golden orange, bright and clear.  The initial woosh of bubbles rises to quite a nicely impressive head of foam, but it surrenders inside of 2 minutes.  The aroma is simply phenomenal ... rich with fruit and fresh pine.  The beer delivers on the promise with a resin-laced silkiness and warming alcoholic sting.  This is a beaut.  (#4128, 5/30/2011)

Served from a bottle from OTM. The appearance is a slightly hazed golden hue with a great white head. The flavors and aromas are creamy with oranges and kumquats, a great malty backing. The mouth is wonderfully creamy with a lower carbonation. Excellent DIPA. .

Very clean drinkable Double IPA.  The malts are quite present and almost mask some of the good hop flavor.  Not bitter at all which would have been welcome.  Overall its a great introductory level Double IPA but if you have a palate for more hop forward DIPAs then you may not enjoy this one quite as much.

Very west coast, not that bitter,  pretty malty, clean. Couldve
Been bitter.

750ml bottle. Gold amber pour, very clear with a big fluffy head. Aroma was packed with citrus, grapefruit and  hops. Flavor was very earthy and dry with a nice malt backing. A straight forward in your face DIPA. A very good showing.

[Bottle] Clear golden appearance, good head formation and retention. Spicy hop and lemon citrus aroma, a little peppery. Slight oiliness on the palate, medium bodied with quite a bit of fizz. Sweet lemon citrus and biscuity malts in fron half and a big grapefruit bitter finish that lingers well into the aftertaste.

22oz bottle: Pours a clear copper with a one finger ivory head. The head dissipates quickly but there is still good lacing. The aroma is citrus driven with some sweeter notes, like orange. The taste is a little malty with some biscuit flavor. The palate is medium and well suited for the style.  The is a very good beer overall bu there are a handful of better DIPA around.

22oz bottle poured into a pint glass.  This beer is gorgeous and very clear.   Color is amber gold with an off white head that is thick and frothy.  Aromas are of citrus, but not harsh, with mild grapefruit and tangerine notes.  Tastewise, this one is a winner, with such a great balance, malts nor hops overwhelm, but they really shine.  The flavors are spruce, and citrus with a nice clean bitter (but not too) finish.  Goes down very easy, and the ABV is very well hidden.  Palate is medium with a nice medium finish and lively carbonation.  Overall, one of the best DIPA I have had in a while......very well done.
Clear gold; creamy white head; big juicy aromas of orange and other citrus fruits; dry and not suprisingly bitter.  Wonderful Imperial IPA.

Pours a golden orange color with very little white head, no lacing.  The smell is amazing, grapefruit, orange, citrus and slight pine.  Slightly sour and bitter taste, medium body, easy drinking.  Palate is suprisingly lively with a bit of alcohol but not enough for a full on buring aftertaste. Overall this is one of the best Double IPAs I have had in a long while.  Looking forward to more beers like this from Firestone Walker.

Pours a golden-amber with a persistent Imperial head.  Aroma is a real doozy here--this brew has a depth of hop and malt aroma that is 3-dimensional compared with most other IPAs or even IIPAs.  Smells like fresh, sticky green hops redolent of all manner of citrus fruit, herbs, and resinous pine balanced with bready, caramelly, and sweet malts.  Body is full and creamy with initial caramel candy sweetness and balanced by a truly imperial hop profile.   Dry hopping really is key here-- the aroma is far stronger than actual hop bitterness.  Or maybe the intense hop bitterness is balanced by an equally exquisite malt body...either way, big props to the guys at Firestone Walker for crafting such a heavenly beverage!
Clear light amber color/ white head. Nice pine sap, grass, caramel, pale malt aromas. medium body. Sweet pale malt, sugar, honey flavors with some pine sap bitterness to balance--good
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: Awesome beer.  The aroma is citrus, peach, bread.  The appearance is amber, white head.  The flavor is citrus, caramel, flowers, bread.  Very nice.  Medium in body, slightly syrupy.  The finish is pine, citrus and floral hops.  Very nicely done.

Dont get me wrong. This beer is great. Why is is great? ...................... Because it is a dead on clone of Pliny!!!!  No wonder it won an award. I wouldnt be surprised if Vinnie was involved brewing this.  I understand why breweries copy Pliny but wouldnt it suck if every double IPA you opened up and hoping for something original always tasted like Pliny?  To me it is lame and unimaginative.
Pours amber with a nice off white head.  Aroma is fresh, citrusy, piny hops.  Flavor is full of spicy, grapefruit and citrus hops with a subtle sweet malt backbone.  Very nice.

22 ounce bomber.  Pours a relatively clear light amber tinged with orange.  Intense hop aroma.  Pineapple and citrus dominate, backed up by sweet pine.  Caramel malts are off in the background.  My mouth is watering from the aroma alone.  Taste follows the aroma, with a wonderfully bitter finish.  Mango and pineapple tropical hops coat the tongue first, with spicy and pine notes in the middle.  Relatively high carbonation combines with caramel malt sweetness helps to balance things out, and the mouthfeel is full and creamy.  The ABV never really shows up, as the hops cover things up nicely.  This is one yummy and refreshing double IPA.  Highly drinkable, especially considering the high ABV.
Bomber:  Pours a clear orange with a thick foamy white head, huge pine grapefruit and bubblegum in the aroma, starts and ends very bitter, subtle carbonation, full bodied.

UPDATED: JUL 15, 2012 Bottle.  Amber with foamy off-white head.  Citrus, grapefruit, nuts, herb, bread, pine, and caramel.  Medium body with nice carbonation and silky and smooth finish.  Well balanced, complex, not overvpowering and a different double IPA.  Very good, especially when warm.

Bottle Clear amber ale with orange highlights and a small, ultra-sheer, white head. The nose provides earthy pine and cat piss as the aromatic foundation for a ton of citrusy pink grapefruit. Full-bodied and lightly creamy with modest carbonation. The flavor presents intense, major-league bitterness - grapefruit rind and pine. Lengthy, lightly malty, violently bitter finish that bites hard and doesnt release any time soon. Bottle provided by darkguardian!

Aroma - Slightly floral hoppy
Appearance - Dark golden, clear, nice head that faded with time
Taste - Malty
Palate - Medium body, very smooth for alcohol content
Overall - a different imperial IPA; not nearly as hoppy as most but very smooth

Bottle.  Pours clear amber with an average, frothy and bubbly white head, medium retention with good lacing.  Aroma is average/heavy malt (bread, cookie, cereal, caramel), heavy hops (floral, perfume, pine, citrus), and average esters (apple/pear) with notes of peach and apricot.  Flavor is average/heavy malt (bread, cookie, cereal, caramel), heavy hops (floral, perfume, pine, citrus), and average esters (apple/pear) with notes of alcohol, peach, and apricot.  Full body, medium warmth and carbonation with a slightly creamy texture and then a drying finish.

Pours a clear golden/copper color with a tightly bubbled white head that gets sticky. Pine and grapefruit pine and grapefruit. Little bit of tropical fruit and hints of malty caramel deep underneath. Curiously after a couple of sips the head disappeared and the aroma really changed. I get lots of pineapple and lemon with hints of alcohol. Taste is bitter and resinous with just enough of a bready caramel malt base to keep this drinkable. Finish is a bit dry with a long lingering resinous aftertaste long after each sip. Creamy oily mouthfeel, medium level of carbonation, medium to thin body. This is a big hoppy monster, bordering on harshly bitter. I enjoyed this Im glad I got to try this, but Ive enjoyed other DIPAs more.

Clear golden with off white faded head, little lively, little viscous, semi laced.. Dominant grapefruits and orange aroma with a smattering of pale malts sweetness and light alcohol aroma... Fruity pebbles, fresh hops, light alc, piney, woody, citrus fruits, complex hops with notes of sweet malts behind... Lively medium full body, not creamy... Awesome...

Very clear golden copper in color with a big frothy head that is off white.  Strong retention.   Delightful citrus aroma that also has pine and caramel.  Flavor is delightful, too.  Big citrus fruit and pine.  Toasty malt and brown sugar.  Very well balanced and very well crafted.

UPDATED: NOV 14, 2011 This is a great DIPA, just what I like, with plenty of aromatic hops, fragrance and taste, mellow and no off notes at the end.  golden color, modest head that does not hold and little lacing but the taste is great.
11/11 again this time on tap at RFDs.  still Great

WOW! A definite 4+ beer. This beer is a reminder that, when done right, IIPAs can be incredible! Aroma was perfect heavy citrus, grapefruit rind and lemon zest. Pour was a nice medium gold with a one finger off white head. Taste was all west coast IIPA. Strong, bitter grapefruit rind and citrus hops are in the front and not leaving any malt in to balance out the bitterness. Medium carbonation keeps the beer lively. Mouth is left dry and bitter and it lasts a long time. Amazing beer!
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Pint at Brouwers. Heavy Brown-golden pour. Unique juicy hop nose. Great sticky malt backbone. juicy-dry pine hop juice. So Tasty.

UPDATED: MAR 29, 2012 Update: Sept 2, 2011 draft at Brouwerij Lane, Greenpoint Brooklyn.  This is now becoming available good stores in NYC.

Getting more rum soaked pineapple and peaches.  Less rounded or full in general.  

Less yeast characteristics which added body and complexity.  Love it still but not as much from the keg.

Bottle Review

Aroma: ripe pineapple, alcohol, pine, citrus hops

Appearance, crystal clear orange/amber, tiny bubbles

Taste: Malt back bones carriers the agressive pine pine resin and tropical/citrus hops.  On the back of the tongue a cheesy yeast comes out late.

Palate: Alcohol and spicy hops attach front of the tongue early and dry/cool it late with a long astringent finish...even though my mouth is pretty much coated with the sugars.

Really love this one and wish I could get it in NYC more easily.
Draft at Black Squirrels new downstairs bar.  Dregs.  Very nice pineapple aroma and flavor with some pine overlay.  Nice.

Had a nice copper/honey hue, with a small fluffy white head.  Incredible aroma, didnt even have to hold the glass close!  Big tropical fruit aromas, like pineapple, tangerine, and some grapefruit, but with a spicy tang of alcohol to bring it out of the scenic tropics.  But the flavor was huge and, perhaps, restrained?  Ive had some beers similar in taste to this, but usually theyre too bitter or resinous.  This bad boy is just right, hiding the massive IBU count behind a silky sweet malt wall.  Oh its plenty hoppy, featuring the same juicy tropical fruit-hops from the nose, as well as some alcohol burn.  But its just as powerful malt-wise, with big sweetness and a touch of caramel.  New favorite DIPA?

Bottle, shared with Parksy. Clear honey gold, moderate creamy white head that leaves ropy lace. Intense tropical fruit aroma and flavour: pineapple, passionfruit, grapefruit, sweet pine. Full bodied with a beautiful balance between bright fruity juicy hoppiness and well structured sweet malt and long intense bitterness. Truly the best balanced IIPA Ive had in recent memory. Outstanding!
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: Mmmmmmm, solid all the way through DIPA here.  Nice and floral, grapefruit and citrused out.  Really liked the dryness factor of the malt and how it blended quite perfectly with the hop profile.  Thick, bold, and full.  Damn good stuff.  Wish it wasnt $8!!

This is a really nice beer - but like other IPAs with more than two or three hop varietals, the flavor gets muddied and you cant really tell what youre drinking.

A - Big grapefruit and apricot, and very floral.

C - Dark copper

T - Patches of both sweet and bitter, though like I said above, all of the different hop varietals muddy the flavor.

P - Despite the high alcohol content, its a really drinkable beer.

Serving - Troegs Mad Elf tulip glass.

Double Jack IPA is our first ever Imperial IPA. It features a big malty middle to cloak the high alcohol and mouth puckering hop bitterness. Huge tangerine, grapefruit and juicy fruit aroma blossom over the herbal blue basil and malt earthiness of this aggressive beer. Best enjoyed in moderation.

Bomber. Pours a rich golden color with full white head. Aromas of citrus, pine and slight caramel. Great citrus hop flavor, some nice sweetness inthe middle, and a bitter sweet finish; alcohol is well hidden...good stuff.

I really enjoyed this one, thanks zach. It had a nice pour, it was pale with a light head. The aroma was a very citrus like beer and it was quite citrusy with a nice bitterness. Good beer, would like some more
On tap at 38 Degrees, Alhambra, Los Angeles. Amber colour, medium head. Fruity caramel with some hop bitterness. Drinkable.

Bomber.  Poured crystal-clear, lighter orangey-golden with a sticky whitish head.  The aroma opened with a deep blend of honey and fruity notes, topped by an aggressive, but well-executed hop barrage (tangerine, floral, and spicy pine led).. black pepper and more tangerine trailed.. excellent!  The flavor found bready malts to go along with honey at the core.. floral and tangerine bitterness surrounded, amplified by alcohol warmth.. dry, lightly-scratchy peppery bitterness on the belly-warming finish.  Medium-plus bodied and well-balanced on the palate.. this was a big beer, but was juicy, and everything worked well together.

Bottle at Dark Lord Day. Thanks for the share. Poured light golden brown with small head. Very citrus with light pine in the aroma. Similar taste with light honey in the back. One of my favourites from the day.

Magnificent! Powerful and sweet with genuine pine forest cone bitterness so aromatic and delicious. A treat with malt backbone sufficient to hang out yet get of the frikin way. Good firey mouthfeel and firey alcohol available for your pleasure at the Iron Monkey JC.  There is some well defined juicy citrus but i could not get over the wonderful pine character. A great sipper.

Bottle enjoyed in small snifter. So nice to have a beer deliver. Ive had so many disappointments with double IPAs lately - BrewDog spoiled, a number of others hard to come by, so imagine my surprise to stumble upon this in my humble local store. Aroma just that lovely double IPA smell, like Dreadnaught, like Hop 15, like Hopslam. Bit of rose as it warms, bit of hay. Slight malty finish, but super bitter. Tons of citrus, though maybe light on pine (which is no problem). Certainly a bit sprucey, but nothing overpowering. Crisp, but ever so slightly syrupy, just dings the palate a touch. More malt as it warms, in the nose and on the tongue. Hint of medicine in the flavor. In the end, not quite as well defined as the very best for me, though still an excellent and delicious beer.

bottle. cloudy amber pour with medium sized white head. huge tropical fruit and sugar in the nose. big papaya and golden grapefruit. similar flavor...insanely fresh and inviting. a nice bitter and dry finish. excellent and well-balanced

Pours a rich golden orange with ample thick white head. Aroma is floral hops and tangerines. Taste is initially very sweet followed by large hop presence. It doesnt finish as crisp as I would prefer. It actually lingers a bit spicy. Not bad overall.

Tap at Tops in Tempe Az. Pours bright clear gold. Resiny, oily, piney nose-full of flavor. Taste is subtle-sweet, well balanced, nice mix of hops and malts. Closest thing to a Pliny/Younger on the street today. Delicious.
user_location: Seattle still not near Beersel., Washington, USA

text: Bottle. Pillowy off-white head on a mostly clear light yellowish orange body. Grapefruit, pine, woody, and aggressive overall hoppiness in the aroma.  Taste continues with the hop assault, and really loving the lack of a major underlying sweetness.  Just enough malt to back up the massive pine and grapefruit bursts, and ends fairly dry.  Hint of floral action coming in as well.  Medium body with bubbly carbonation.   Hell yes.

Issac Newtons. Nice golden / amber pour. 

A strong grapefruit and citrus aroma. 

Medium body hoppy muthfeel with hints of caramel malt and bitter finish.

Very Good.

22oz Bottle, purchased at Conn Ave Liquors - Washington, DC. Big piney and catty nose, clean and herbal. Flavors are a solid build of green, piney, and vegetal hops. It gets a bit grassy and a little light on floral or tropical or fruity for me, but I like it. Whats evident is the skill in composing and executing a well-balanced hoppy beer, something that so many breweries try to do and dont suceed, but that a California brewery like Firestone can handle deftly.

22 oz bottle from Pinocchios, Delaware Co. poured into a Duvel tulip.
Orangish/amber body with a two-finger, off-white head, nice lacing and decent retention. Nose was grapefruit, pine, caramel. Taste was mildly bitter orange, floral, pineapple, grapefruit with a sweeter middle before being followed by a nice interplay between the sweetness, citrus and bitternes in the finish.  Mouthfeel was smooth, medium in body and carbonation with a pleasing bitter bite to break up the sweetness.  You notice the alcohol but would have no idea it was 9.5%.  All-in-all a good DIPA I would not hesitate to try again.  Thanks FW for coming to Philly!

My favorite style and this did not disappoint. Big citrus and pine aroma from a light amber pour with a small head. The flavor was rich with malt sweetness followed by a big hop bitterness that didnt let up. A wonderful after taste of citrus and pine. Great.

Lightly hazy dark golden color with a small, white head that left nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma of citrus, floral hops, pine, sweeter toffee, some toast.  Taste of citrus, resiny pine, some sweet malts, with lots of resin, and grapefruit, with light alcohol as well.

I got to try a fresh bottle a few weeks ago. I poured it into a strait pint glass and it produced a three finger white billowy head that laced all the way down the glass. The body of the brew was a clear light liquid gold. The aroma was nothing but fresh hops right in your nose, nice and citrus with a light grassy note coming through. As for the flavor it was what I expect in a west coast DIPA, hoppy bitter with a light malt sweetness. Again the flavor is tilted towards the hops so the hop head in me was quite pleased it was crisp and clean in the mouth making for a really enjoyable brew to drink. I will be grabbing another bottle when I see it fresh again.

Serving type: bottle
Strong hops.  Aroma is citrus and hops.  Copper with a little lace.  Very unique beer (in a good way).
Very strong hops and citrus notes.  The grapefruit was hidden by the hops but were noticeable.

transparent copper with a thick, lasting, large bubbled white head. Nose of sharp grapefruit, dusty malt and slight cardboard leading to a cat litter impression, light bit of heat behind. Flavor similar, more heat than nose, light paper and cardboard clashing more with c hops, overly oily finish with a bit too much paper, slight pine. Heat too apparent. Never comes together.
Awesome, super well balanced IIPA. Nice smooth building bitterness and sweet malt aroma and big mouthfeel. All around great.

Aroma is bright citrus and pine. Great hop blend with just the right bitterness. ABV is very well hidden - dangerously smooth. Color is an orange ruby color with little head yet good lacing. One of the best DIPAs I have ever had.

pours a very clear golden/lt amber honey color with a thick lt. tan head...lively looking...nice retention and decent lacing.  aroma is dominated by spice and grapefruit...herb and pine notes as well...mild alcohol too.  actually has more notable malt backing than many DIPAs but hops still dominate...herbal spicy hops set off by hints of citrusy hops...lightly earthy or woody towards the end.  mouthfeel is a bit resinous and lively with a a very hoppy, lingering dry finish that warms a bit.

Draft at Capones.

Pours a dark golden orange/copper color with burnt orange/tangerine hues when held to a light and a half finger white head that slowly settles into a thin ring. Sporadic spots of lacing left behind.

Sweet citrus aroma with tons of tropical and citrus fruit notes bursting through. Dank, oily hops giving off hints of mango, pineapple, grapefruit and orange peel. Slightly boozy with some zesty spice and subtle malt backbone. Hints of biscuit and grainy graham cracker.

Medium bodied with a slick oily hops mouthfeel. Dank, dry and resinous with some nice bitterness that is quickly countered by a blast of sweet citrus and tropical fruit notes. Lots of grapefruit flavor with hints of mango, apricot and orange peel. This is countered by earthy, bitter pine needle flavor and a strong boozy presence. Subtle malt backbone with hints of biscuit and toast. As it warms the alcohol really starts to shoe and begins to dominate the flavor, making it a bit tough to drink down. Decently balanced at first but too hot for my liking.

On a fabulous second date I stepped away for a minute and came back to find a rich gold Double Jack waiting for me. Citrus aroma, honey undertones, blossoms into grapefruit and wild florals with a slow, lingering finish. So yes, a third date is in order.

Had while sitting outside watching softball. pour was a nice bodied gold with lasting head that laced well.  Aroma was full of sweet pine hops and mild fruits. Flavor was an awesome balance of hops, hops, and hops. There were also hints of very citrusy fruits like grapefruit. Awesome brew.

22oz bottle from Richie.

Pours an unbelievably clear amber with a thick creamy beige head that shows great lacing and sits as a thick cap for the duration.  Again, the clarity of the body is really striking.

Aroma is full of citrus in the form of pineapple and pithy grapefruit.  But there is also a big resinous pine character - a great combo overall - with some light sweet malts.

The taste is more of the same and really, really hoppy.  But, when I say hoppy, I dont just mean bitter, as the bitterness is present but not overpowering, I really mean just great hop-driven flavor.  Its got an initial pine kick but the grapefruit and mango bring some fruitiness to the taste.  The light caramel malts keep things from getting too out of control, but barely, as this is a seriously hoppy beer.

The mouthfeel is actually on the lighter side of things for a DIPA but has good carbonation and the tingly hop bitterness ensures the body never seems watery.

Another home run from Firestone Walker - right up there with PtE for me with all the right hop characteristics.  Its ridiculous how easy this drinks for a 9.5% DIPA.

Bottle. 22 oz. Split with Papa Steve and Uncle Mark. This beer pours a clear, shiny modest copper with a thin, fizzy, half-finger off-white head. Leaves nearly no lacing, but the head leaves a lovely ring around the edge of the glass and some thin tracing across the surface. Aroma of freshly squeezed grapfruit, papaya, mango, orange peel, soft piney resin, and subtle, sweet hints of caramel and vanilla. The body is not thin, but rather loose and roomy; it supports the juicy citrus and pine flavors quite well, whilst also coating the tongue with sticky sweet nectar. The finish is slow, tangy, and very sweet. This is a tremendously nuanced, delicious double IPA. Excellent.

UPDATED: SEP 25, 2012 New Rating: 7/3/8/3/14[3.5]

At a tasting,thanks Dagan,  pours a shiny yellow to orange with a medium white head, powerful aroma of pine, herbs, green coffee beans, lots of citrus, and fresh melon, flavor is dry and bitter with oranges, green pepper, grapefruit, malt, lots of hops freshness, full bodied, excellent. 9/4/8/5/16[4.2]

Tried the Double Jack Double IPA at the Day of the ales 2011 in Chicago. Really tasty beer, I bought a case of firestone walker in california based off of the experience of trying it at the DOTA event.

Deep gold bronze colored body with a long lasting light khaki head. The nose is roasted peanuts, caramel and lots of grapefruit. There is also some bread crust. The smooth body is complemented with a strong hop forward flavor. There is some warming booze. The sweetness of apple comes through after the initial wood and grapefruit bite. There is also a little bit of bread. I can see how people love this as a hop bomb. Its pretty good.

650 ml. pours golden in color with a light white head. Smell of grapefruit, orange, pine and some malt sweetness. Fresh pine, grapefruit, orange, mango, very smooth but complex. As I drink this I really notice the malt backbone that melds really well with the hops! Mouthfeel is oily and thick, finish is very long, bitter and wonderful!

Pours light golden honey with a pillowy white head and thick chunks of lace.  Aroma explodes with strong pine and sweet citrus fruits like grapefruits, sweet caramel, and honey.  Amazingly intense nose with mangoes, grapefruits, tangerines, and an insane amount of pine.  Loads of pine on the palate with intensely sweet citrus fruits, crystal malts, an almost wild flower honey-like flavor with increasingly bitter hops make this one fantastic!  The finish is very long and dry.  Wonderful!

Clear golden/light amber pour off white head .... aroma was awesome piney, citrusy fruity hops ..... taste was piney and citrusy hops, nice grapefruity taste with a nice bitter hop to it followed by a caramel malt and a dry malty bitter hop finish that lingers a bit .... just a touch of abv detected but a smooth and very sessionable dbl ipa loved it

UPDATED: JUL 15, 2011 on tap,citrus, grass, earthy, leaves, alcohol, amber, clear, frothy, light sweetness, medium bitterness, light body, oily feel, soft carbonation. great beerhad in bottle as well recently. much better than i had remembered.one of the best dipas. slight honeyed, intense hop becoming almost sweet....

UPDATED: APR 26, 2011 22oz. bottle, purchased on the very first day it was available in the state of MO, bottled on 2/10/11.  Fairly intoxicating aroma, luscious and rife with sweet, toasty malts and massively floral and fruity hops, along with suggestions of grapefruit, orange, melon, pine, honeysuckle, light caramel, faint dough and brown sugar, some very faint alcohol lurking beneath the surface to spice it up a bit as well.  Light copper color, clear, with a lasting head of uneven white bubbles, leaving a sheen of lace behind.  Flavor is hugely malty and hoppy, with all the complexity shown in the nose, featuring a very rich malt character, overlaid with massive amounts of fruity, piney, fresh hop flavors and bitterness, which blend with the nascent alcohol and ultimately manage to outweigh the thick, gently toasted malt character with just the right degree of dryness.  Huge and lasting finish, this itself features as much complexity and degree of development as some lesser beers entirely  (is that bubblegum, peppery spice and pineapple?).  Mouthfeel is quite hefty and thick, but again is assisted by the drying effects of the hugely generous hops, warming, showing a moderate degree of effervescence and a very full body.  Examples of this style really dont get much better.  World-class.

UPDATED: APR 14, 2011 On tap at Capones. Poured a deeper amber color with a smaller sized off white head. Aromas of citrus, rinds, some floral hops, and caramel. Tastes of citrus, caramel, fruity, and pine.

Such an amazing DIPA; likely my favorite in the category.  Have had 2 bottles of this now and will be looking for more.  Slight carbonation/head that pours a beautiful golden color and drinks super smooth.  Great flavor from start to finish.  Dont ruin this one with a flavorful meal - enjoy on its own then eat!

On draft at Capones.  Pours a clear deep orange vistalite color with a medium sized frosty off white head.  Aroma of fresh grapefruit, oranges, tropical fruit notes, Juicy Fruit gum, tons of hops and malt.  Taste is much the same as the aroma.  Bitter, hoppy, citrusy and well balanced.

Dark gold color, beautiful head retention and lacing. Has wonderful citrus hop aroma, tangerine and caramelized pineapple. texture on the tongue is creamy and velvety. The hops in this beer are definitely used more for flavor and aroma than for bittering.
Simply a wonderful beer, beautifully representative of the style.

Bomber from Capones.  Pours dark straw toward freshly minted copper penny with 2-finger frothy white head.  Nose is HUGE resiny tropical fruity feety hops, pineapple, tangerine, honeydew, black pepper,  Tastes rich, very caramel malty, with a huge IBU load, tons of tropical fruit, big peppery notes.  Reminds me a bit of Sculpin.  Gets a bit hot late, but just drips with hop juice, and this one is in the top 1% of IBU values, but with wnough malt to balance the hops.  This one is great, and even more  bitter than Rosie ODonnell after she finds out that they sold the last butter-slathered lobster at Legal Seafood.

Pours clear orange with nice lasting white head.  Aroma has notes of tangerine, watermelon, melon, some mango and tropical fruit, some slight caramel.  Taste is full and delicious, with notes of tangerine, melon, some tropical fruit including papaya, with a sweet caramel malt middle, finishing fairly bitter, lasting.  Excellent IIPA, but a little sweet for me.
Pours a deep golden/amber with an off white head.  Aroma of citrus and pine hops with caramel malts. Taste is the same. Thick mouthfeel and fairly sweet.
Very well balanced malts and hops. Great aroma. Sweet citrusy and caramel. Reminds me of DFH 90 minute, but a little heftier.
Bottle shared pre-ACBF 2011. Amazing citrus and pine, flavors follow more of the same - great IPA!

My pallet was not prepared for the absolute bitterness of this brew.  Pours hazy yellow with a white head.  Huge piney hop aroma.  Taste is very bitter hop with a nice caramel malt balance, with a bitter alcohol finish.  Good stuff.

Bomber. Clear, deep golden body. Frothy, white head, slowly diminishing. Big nose of grapefruit, resin, pine, sweet caramel. Some toasted grain, leafy hops. The flavor is moderately sweet and moderately bitter. It finishes moderately to heavily bitter and moderately sweet. Medium to full body, creamy texture, moderate carbonation. Warming alcohol in the finish. Taste of citrus, grapefruit, floral hops. This is not as crisp, clean as some double iPAs, but it is thick and rich and well balanced. Thanks Randy.

Bottle from a trade with cbkschubert. Pours clear orangish amber color with off white head. Aromas of grapefruit, tangerines and some caramel malts. Lots of citrus hop flavor balanced with sweet caramel malts. A little heat from the alcohol. Medium to full body with average carbination.  A really nice DIPA. Thanks Craig.
Bottle. Pour is clear amber.  Aroma is loaded with citrus hops. Just loaded.  Also faint malty sweetness.  Flavor also loaded with citrus hops: grapefruit, orange, light floral.  Soooo good.
By far the best IPA Ive had in a long while.  The aroma is perfect. The malty taste hides the acholol. You would never guess this beer clocks in at 9%.
hazy orange amber color. Huge grapefruit, grassy piney nose. Very well balanced and put together.

Bomber.  Crystal clear copper with a nice tall frothy white head that leaves some nice lace.  The aroma is amazing--perfect balance of hops and malt.  Just enough malt to make its presence known--some sticky robust pale malt and a hint of caramel--with TONS of hoppy goodness.  Very piney and citric (lemon and grapefruit).  The flavor is the same.  Its a bit heavy, but not much alcohol showing through.  The bitterness is sharp but somewhat short lived, leaving plenty of room for juicy citric notes to shine through.  The malt backbone compliments the hops perfectly.  Medium to full bodied with smooth mellow carbonation.  The resinous character with the thick body makes for a mouth coating experience.  Overall:  glad I saw someone else pick this up, because I walked right past it without even noticing. This is a damn fine IIPA.  God the west coast really knows how to use hops properly.

On tap at Khourys in LV 
Appearance: Clear golden with a medium sized off-white head and good lacing 
Aroma: Floral, caramel malts and pine 
Taste: Pine resin 
Very nice, I likey!

Bottle. Dark gold with a thick head and sticky lacing. Hoppy aroma with notes of tangerine and strong malt base. Body has a syrupy texture from the heavy malt. Flvours are strong on tangerine and grapefruit with a woody base. Good and well made but doesnt sing for me.

UPDATED: MAY 25, 2014 Pours a clear copper, nice compact and creamy white head with good staying power.  Aroma is a shot of citrus and caramel.  Flavor is hoppy, grapefruit, peach, a touch of pine, and a gummy caramel accented malt finish.  Really well done, the flavors worked great together on this one.  Balanced too.  RERATE:  on tap at Mekong.  Honestly the exact same.  Faintly more golden than I had remembered.

Bomber from Julios.
Appearance : clear pale yellow with a small foamy head.

Aroma : Awesome citrusy mangos and passion fruits. Leafy and floral hops. Light lychee.

Taste : Great floral and leafy hops. Citrusy and fruity. Notes of passion fruits and lychee. Awesome sweetness.

Overall : Wow that was a really nice surprise. Great balance between sugar and hops. Great malt. I had it during a tasting after a bunch of big belgians and stouts so maybe thats why it felt so good.
Bottle. Pours clear amber. White head. Nose and taste of caramel malt, maple spruce, hops, citrus and pineapple. Alcohol noticeable in the finish. Very bitter.

At a tasting, thanks Dagan, smallish head, clear depish yellow colour, citrusy aroma with some shurbs, pine and a hint of nuts, flavour of pomello, flowers and herbs, massive bitterness with some sweetish maltiness trying desperatly to restrain it. quite drinkable inspite of the bitterness.

Pours orange-tinged amber into a tulip. White conglomerate head with excellent retention recedes leaving spider lacing.  Tangerine, weed and resin aromas. Soft with sweet citrus upfront turning to caramel before the lasting bitter citrus and resin finish.

UPDATED: APR 5, 2011 A clear copper pour with a fluffy white head.  The aroma is all pine.  The medium to full body has a creamy texture and average carbonation.  The taste is bitter, but it smooths out nicely into a neutral finish.

Bottle thanks to Wavers!!  Clear vibrant orange pour, lasting lasing and a strong vanilla hops aroma.  Flavor is syrupy hops, rich orange citrus and very sweet with lasting bitterness on the aftertaste.  Solid DIPA and really enjoyable!  Thanks again Wavers!

2010 bottle shared by DalzAle (Greg). pour is clear amber with a off white frothy soapy head that fades to a collar. Aroma is caramel and grapefruit with citrus notes as well. Taste is bitter grapefruit and pine with a sweet caramel and warming alcohol finish (very subtle). Palate is medium and creamy with a sticky dry finish. Pretty tasty want more!

UPDATED: AUG 3, 2014 What can I say?

The most complex, fruitiest DIPA Ive ever tasted, and the fruitiest unfruited beer Ive tasted since Stille Nacht 1996 Reserve. Among the detectable fruity esters, there are grapefruit, mandarin orange, tangerine, peach, plum, agave nectar, cherry, mango, kiwi, lemon, lime, marion berry, and strawberry.

The finish is luxuriously long, and that seltzer quality slightly dries out the finish, and really adds a sprightly tingle.

Add to this a great malt backbone that has a fruitiness all its own with a substantial body (similar to Hercules, but not as syrupy and weighty).

The floral hoppiness in this beauty almost rivals the Plinys, and after awhile a seltzery saltiness develops, and while Im not normally a fan of seltzer, it works perfectly here, and leaves one craving another taste.

Perfection.

Bottle. Clear orangish/amber pour with a small fine head that lasts a while. Aroma is soapy, hoppy, pine and grapefruit. Flavor is soap, herbal, astringent. Nice little hint of alcohol in the finish. Nicely carbonated mouthfeel.Great DIPA enjoyed on a beautiful spring day.

Nose tickling citrus and pine aroma that deep clean fragrance we so love and crave,wouldnt quite use the word massive( thats reserved for Pliney or Furious)escalates as it warms,there is also a caramel awarness upon warming,beautiful, big round juicy hop and caramel flavors, tongue starts twitching a little from the bitterness, hop dominat but not insane,wunderbar!!
On tap T the Two Seven bar. Clear golden orange. Huge thick head, lacing to die for. Enormous hop, citrus, pine nose. Massive hop, straw, citrus, pine, earth taste. Just amazing!
very excited this one has made it to Chicago... the aroma and taste are balanced with nice sweetness on the front and some great pine hops, very smooth and crushable, one of the better dipas going

Bottle thanks to ajm: Pours a clear deep golden brass with a stringy-lacing froth of white head.  Has a fresh grapefruity hoppy nose with juicy resiny pine and sweet caramel character.  Starts with a chewy sweet light caramel maltiness and a good citrusy hop flavor with a resiny bittering balance before a drier slightly warming bittersweet finish.  An enjoyable, hop-forward and dangerously drinkable double IPA.
Draught at FS KC. Nice clear, copper color with a foamy khaki head and sheets of lacing.  Straight pine aroma. Wow, big piney but sweet flavor. Absolutely no hint of the alcohol. Well made.

On tap at CIRCA, High Bridge, NJ.  Clean lines.  Beer pours smooth and amber, good white head with nice retention.  Immediate, strong aroma of hops.  Attack is smooth with a full-on hop assault!  Beautiful overtones of hoppy goodness, and a big body to back it up.  Finishing hops are strong as well, and finish is still crisp - amazing imperial IPA.  Really worth finding on tap somewhere if you like IPA!

UPDATED: SEP 5, 2012 Un corps charnu et massif aux arômes évidentes de mangue et papaye très mûres. Lamertume, un peu moins agréable que la Nugget Nectar, est tout de même bien balancé. Un bijou qui fait parti de laxe de saveurs extrêmes des IPA américaines.

UPDATED: AUG 24, 2012 Re-rate 8/13/13: Bottle sample at a tasting at Ariels place. Thanks Ariel. Hazy orange. Slightly stale hoppy nose. Bitter flavor, hoppy, somewhat stale, resinous and a bit grapefruity with some maltiness. Medium-bodied. Past its prime. 6/4/6/3/12=3.1

Bottle at a tasting. Thanks Dagan. Clear golden with a white head. Powerful aroma of lots of citrus and flowers. Bitter hoppy flavor with a bit of sweet malty cookie-ish notes in the back, a bit of alcohol and a very bitter finish with grapefruit. Medium-bodied. Very nice. 8/3/7/3/15=3.6

Bouteille de 22 oz partagée lors dune dégustation Ratebeer Montréal. Arôme: Odeur dorange avec une pointe de pamplemousse. Apparence: La couleur est dorée. Présence dun mince col mousseux et dune fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût dorange avec une pointe de caramel et de pins. Durée moyenne de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture légèrement onctueuse. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. Arrière goût légèrement houblonné. (Rating #3570)

Bomber poured into a tulip glass. Clear copper color with thin off-white ring. Aroma of big orange, grapefruit, candied pineapple, sweet caramel malt, peach, and pine. Reminiscent of Hopslam. Taste is sweet with a great balance of bitterness. Mouthfeel is clean, crisp, and finishes dry. A big juicy balanced DIPA. Delicious!

UPDATED: JUN 13, 2012 What a great ipa. On draft at RnH with streets for the east vs westcoast ipa challenge. Pours light red amber body. Fresh fruit and pine hops in aroma. Mouthfeel is juicy with great notes of pine, grapefruit, orange, and maybe even some peach.

22oz bottle.  Pours a clear copper color.  Aroma of grapefruit, mango, strawberry, floral, resin.  Flavor is fantastic grapefruit and citrus with subtle pine and alcohol in the finish.  This is a fantastic Imperial IPA!
Pours a glowing yellow/orange with a sticky white head. The aroma has caramel, pine, orange, and spice. The flavor has pine, caramel, orange, spice, and a slight bitterness. Not bad at all.

So Awesome. Tons of fruit and sweet yet finishes dry. The aroma is out of this world good. Pours gold with a nice white head that laces the glass. Totally balanced. Tons of malts, tons of hops tons of perfection. The aroma is like taking fresh hops and smelling them. Really great!

UPDATED: NOV 6, 2011 Taste of orange juice, slightest grassiness, simcoe hops. Big malt backing; more than balanced. very good beer. I would like to try this fresh and not flown in a hot suitcase from across the country.

Pours a clear amber, with a nice off-white head.  Aroma is sweet with grapefruit, citrus hops, and malt.  Mouthfeel is smooth, with loads of caramel & citrus.  Finish is nice and bitter, with caramel and hops lingering

Aroma grapefruit, tangerine, pineapple, mango, caramel. Pour bronze amber white nice lasting head great lacing. Taste tangerine, malty sweetness, pineapple, mango, grapefruit, pine, caramel. MF medium body slightly sticky with a fine balanced carb. Overall a really good DIPA that is balanced nicely. Enjoyed more on draft then bottle at Piece(Chicago).

Sampler at W&C Ballwin, Mo. It poured an amber color with a small yellow head. The aroma was tropical fruits, caramel, and fruit juice. The taste was hoppy with a decent balance of sweet malt. Very good Double IPA.

22oz bottle poured into a tulip glass. Bottled on 2/10/11. Pours a crystal clear golden amber color with one finger of foam and moderate carbonation. Good lacing. Delicious nose. Pineapple and tangerine. Hops are nice and fresh and the malt is forward enough to give it very good, sweet balance. Carbonation is too low, giving the mouthfeel a smooth but heavier than desirable texture. But the overall balance of the palate still makes it pretty easy to drink. Piny/grassy hops and just as sweet honey malt flavors. The hops are crisp and bright enough to lend some lightness to the beer but the malt profile is nearly as big as the hop. As such, it doesnt come across as bitter as you would expect and has an uncommonly clean finish that features very little in the way of resiny hops. Not the hop bomb style I prefer but certainly as good a DIPA as I have had with this amount of balance.

Serving: 22 oz. bottle at Fireworks.  It pours a nice gold color with a small, white head.  The nose is full of hop, particularly tropical fruit.  The flavor has a touch of honey with lots of citric and tropical hops.  Medium bodied with average carbonation leading to a long, bitter finish.  This is a great, evenly balanced (considering) IIPA.  Definitely worth a try.

Clear orange amber with a nice head that lasted a long time and left nice lace. Citrusy tropical fruit aromas - pineapple, mango, apricot, grapefruit - with some grassy hops in the background. Plenty of biscuity malt flavors to balance out the flavor profile, but the hops bitterness is certainly the highlight. Some black pepper and honey sweetness make an appearance as well. Medium body and carbonation, no evident alcohol (uh-oh), and a super crisp and clean finish. Use this to clean up after a particularly spicy meal.

pour is a clear amber.  Aroma is sticky resin, pine, tangerine fruit.  Flavor is clementine zest, pine needle, a bit of zesty fruitiness.  Very tasty, relatively complex, sweet pine resin with some light zest fruit.

Clear golden pour with an offwhite head. The aroma holds the apricot, mango, mandarin, and peach that Sculpin has, with the dank herbal evergreen that Pliny has. Really powerful and vibrant. The flavor holds dank evergreen resin, orangepeel, lemonpeel, caramel, tangerine, and grassy herbals. The palate is thick for the style with perfectly full effervescence and a sticky resinous finish.

Clear amber pour with a nice frothy head. Aroma holds awesome west coast dankness, with fresh cut grass and spruce and pine, which mixes with a delightful mango/grapefruit/orange zest character, much like Sculpin. Flavor has awesome citrus presence, with clover honey, tangerine rind, piney resin, and a touch of earthiness. Aroma is delightfully drinkable with just the right amount of bitterness. Absolutely fantastic DIPA.

Pours clear orange with a thick frothy beige head that leaves good lacing. Beautiful hop aroma, citrus, herb. Taste is also excellent, great balance, not brutally bitter. Pretty damn good. I thought it was going to be more of a sweet citrus hop flavor while this definitely leans toward herbal and resinous. The alcohol comes through just slightly.

From bomber: glowingly bright  tawny with sparkling clarity and rising bubbles like champagne, with half-inch persistent off-white head. Bursting with aroma hop goodness of citrus peel, orange blossom and guava. Barely-medium body with compact and balanced malt presentation that is present without being caramel-like or in the way of the rush of resiny, green onion hop flavors dominating the mid-palate. There are complex peppery alcohol notes that are vivid yet not at all solventy. Character evolves toward more savory as it warms. New standard.

Pour is a beautyful bright copper with a small white head.  Aroma is a nice fresh hop.  Flavor is grapefruit upfront with some pine and a nice finishing caramel malt sweetness to give this some legs.  Finish leaves a nice hop on the tounge and the alcohol is no where to be found which makes this dangerous.  A well made IIPA that drinks like a IPA.

Really hard to find something wrong with this. Smells of sugar sweet hops. Flavor is sweet but with a bit of strength. Seems very similar to 90-minute Ipa to me, but maybe better. Only real downside is the high price.

An amber ale with a thin white head. In aroma, super mix of floral hops and honeydew soaked oranges, incense, catnip, and meat extracts. In mouth, a superb IPA with citrus pulp, c-hops, honey, cloves, and warming alcohol. Tasted March 12 2011 with Montreal crew.

Whoa!  A rush of IPA aromas right out of the bottle.  Tastes like it smells, picture hangliding through orange orchards in California and exiting through a pine forrest. A pleasant marriage of everything that makes a good IPA. California hops give a breif orange soda snap to the tongue with a fresca meets resin finish on the back of the throat.

Bottle.  Pours an amber and golden body with a scant white head with light retention.  Citrus, pine and grapefruit skins.  Citrus and bright grapefruit notes.  Modest warming, sweet and fruity with a big chewy grass y finish.  Nice dipa.  Sweet stuff.

UPDATED: JUL 7, 2011 This beer is absolutely incredible. The pour is bright orange copper body with a thick finger and a half of off white head. the aroma is incredibly sweet and resinous with a hit of powerful head. Fruity notes of apricot and grapefruit with sweet hops overpowering. A light caramel malt in the middle with a huge looming grapefruit hop. A resinous syrupy mouthfeel is incredibly desirable. A gentle grapefruit hop is overpowered by a gigantic resinous hop. One of my all time favourites.

Pours golden/amber with a small off-white soapy head.  The aroma has lots of hops with green onion, tropical fruits, pine and floral traits along with lots of toasty sweet malt to balance the hops.  It doesnt seem quite as complex as some, but everything that is there is really nice.  Medium full body with a decent amount of semi-sharp carbonation.  The flavor starts with the aroma notes with very funky hops and honey sweetness.  The finish has a bit of pine, spice and resin.  A straight forward IIPA that is quite nice and tasty.

Very fruit forward hop aroma.  It is quite malty, but doesnt get syrupy or cloying.  The hops are definitely there, but not super prominent or exceptionally bitter for a double IPA, though they do linger a bit in the finish.  Might be that the bottle I got was not at the peak of freshness.

Bomber from Binnys River Grove. Pours clear orange with small white head. Aromas of very fresh citrus including oranges, mangos, and grapefruit. Some sweet malt and good amount of hops there as well. Flavors of grapefruit, orange, tons of hop bitterness, fair amount of sweet malts, and booze in the finish. Can definitely tell this is a strong DIPA. Finishes bitter with malty sweetness. Large amount of hops saved this one.

Bottle thanks to Dmac. Pours out a beautiful copper color with nice carbonation and a small off white head. Aroma is of mango, citrus and some light sweet malt notes. Taste is tropical fruits, some grapefruity  hop notes, light sweet lingering malt notes with a nice hoppy finish. Alcohol is well hidden. Top notch.

Very similar to Firestones Union Jack IPA, but a little more alcohol. Aromas of orange and grapefruit.  Very refreshing smells and mouth watering. Bit of mineral and herb in there too. Big burst of grapefruit on the first taste, orange and nicely balanced with malt sweetness. Got to say despite its alcohol content this is a really well balanced and smooth beer. Dangerous - I could drink this without realising its 9%!!!

Bottle shared by a friend. Clear gold/amber pour with a medium white head. Aroma of orange, grapefruit, pine and sweet malt. Flavor starts with sweet malt and quickly turns to orange, pine and a bitter grapefruit rind finish. Right up my alley and truly delicious.

UPDATED: APR 13, 2013 3rd March 2011 Bottle at ACBF thanks to Steptin - Cheers James! Bright amber beer, tidy off white head. Fresh hop nose. Nice biscuit malt base. Deep rich hops. Orange and grapefruit marmalade. A tiny trace of aniseed alcohol. Comparatively mild hop bitterness. Nice beer! 3.818th August 2012Palate is slightly soft with nice fine carbonation. Smooth piney hops with a lime streak and lesser tangerine. Underpinned by beautiful light creamy malt. Light softish finish with a nettley hop aftertaste. A fantastically light and drinkable DIPA.

Shared bomber with son in law...very well done!  This is a delightful strong IPA....usually an IPA with this high an ABV is hotter / more boozy....this one is much more dangerous than that....guess the promo is right...the malty middle cover us the high alcohol...follow their advice....enjoy in moderation AND take a cab home...good stuff....may need to wander over to Binnys tomorrow for an encore.

Crystal clear with a well retained, Brussels lace foam.  This is one of the paler IIPAs Ive come across.  A dense, rich, resiny aroma thats pleasurabley musty.  The aroma contains orange, tangerine, grapefruit...an assortment of citrus.  Good amount of CO2 that really helps this beer from being cloying.  What an enjoyable double!

22oz bottle from Binnys Lakeview in Chicago.  Pours a clear, light amber color with a white head and nice lacing.  Aroma is citrus, grapefruit, hoppy.  Medium on the palate with average carbonation.  Flavor is sweet, lightly malty, with a nice hop finish.  Extremely drinkable at 9.5%

Im suprised how great this beer was. As soon as I opened the bottle the aroma presents itself of pine, grapefruit and sweet citrus. Nice copper color with a white foam. Taste is of pine herbal hops and citrus with some sweet malt but not much of that. Finishes bitter with a great sticky mouthfeel that only come from great iipas. Im not the biggest fan of Firestone but this one is recommended.
Draught at Sycamore for release. Floral Strong pine aroma that generates bitterness. Some fruit sweetness in the taste as well.

Bottle. Poured a hazy amber color with a two finger white head. Aroma was grapefruit, hops, spruce and pine. Flavor was well balanced. Hops and pines up front, followed by spruce and malts. Malty backbone. Sticky mouthfeel. A great beer.

UPDATED: SEP 16, 2012 New to the Chicago market. 650ml bomber proclaiming the 2011 World Beer Cup Mid-Size Brewery Champion.

It pours a beautiful color. It is a clear copper/orange with a big foamy white head that slowly recedes with some nice lacing.

The smell is fuckin incredible, it is orgasmic. It has the smooth scent of tropical fruits and citrus, pure hops.

The flavor is much more resiny with both pine and citrus rind. There is some dankness and some tropical fruit too. It has a ncie bitterness, not ultra-high, but up there. The malt is a perfect backing giving off a subtle sweetness but not overpowering the hops.

This is one glorious, glorious beer.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 02-09-2011 04:42:10

Had some more form the recent 4 packs. Maybe my fav beer ever, only my second 5.

Draft at The Bridge. Pours a clear orange-golden color with a small but resilient white head that leaves a thick ring all the way down. Aroma pops with piney west coast hops, sweet malts, fresh tangerine citrus, and some floral notes late. Flavor of pine resin, herbal and floral hops, grapefruit and tangerine citrus, caramel malts, and fresh oak chips. Medium-bodied, with pretty low carbonation and a fresh, fruity, leafy mouthfeel. So, so smooth and dangerously easy to drink. Alcohol is nowhere to be found. I enjoyed the hell out of this.

22oz bottle. Pours a golden orange color with creamy white head. The aroma pine, floral, and sweet citrus. The flavor is much of the same with some nice earthy hops and a lot of sweet malts (it has the sweetness of a east coast IIPA). This is a good IIPA.
Pours light orange with an off white head. Aroma is lots of citrusy hops. Flavor is lightly sweet, grapefruit, tangerine, light peach, with plenty of bitterness.

22 oz. bomber from Super Buy-Rite Jersey City. Poured a clear orange/amber with an average sized foamy bright white head. Aroma is super hoppy with tons of grapefruit and citrus. Fuller bodied with a syrupy feel, average carbonation and only a slight hint of heat from the 9.5% abv. Flavors of fresh hops, caramel, bread, tropical fruit and hop syrup. Very nicely done and FW is probably the best brewery to hit NJ in the last year.

Firestone Walker Double Jack, Double IPA is a big malty, high alcohol, huge hop bitter concussion. Large amounts of citrus and juicy aroma laying over top of the herbaceous malty Chuck Norris fist to the mouth beer you have in front of you. Best enjoyed only after years of Texas Ranger training

Bouteille de 22 oz, fraîche, lors dune dégustation. Arômes très intenses de houblon américain (orange, pamplemousse et résine). Belle robe dorée et limpide, légère dentelle et effervescence moyenne. Très houblonnée et aromatique, la bière met les agrumes et la résine à lavant-plan. Le malt, moyennement sucré, est relativement rond et montre des notes de sucre dorge. Texture légèrement sirupeuse. Lalcool demeure bien dissimulé. Finale montrant une longue et forte amertume. Le houblonnage de cette bière est exemplaire et elle serait vraiment exceptionnelle si un peu moins sucrée.

On tap at Nunu Chocolates in Brooklyn.  Clear bright copper with lasting head and lace.  (Nice clean glassware at a chocolates place.  Thumbs up.)  Very grapefruit floral aroma.  Nice round grapefruity pineapple sweet fruitiness with a little bit of crackery honey malt and then a bracing grapefruity fresh hop finish.  Awesome.  One of the best DIPAs Ive had.

22. Pours a crystal clear and very bright burnished golden amber. Dense, sudsy white head that sticks around for a fair few minutes. Drippy lace...and plenty of it at that. Bold piney nose. Smells like a big hotel room thats just been cleaned within an inch of its life. Roaring eruption of pine. Creamy medium body with light and lively carb. Bite to it from both the hop acid and the booze, though the booze is otherwise quite well hidden. Toast, caramel, and pine on the mid-palate. What you see is what you get--you swings your hop hammer and you takes what you gets. Hops are all from one big bag, and a nice big bag to be sure--flavor-wise, anyway. There might be more than one strain but the effect on the flavor is quite singular. Long piney finish.
