Delicious, refreshing, harmonious, everything you want from a snarling hoppy beast on a long malty leash.

Courtesy of rayl101.Brilliant golden/orange, decent head, great lacing, oily, growing legs. Great aroma, juicy fruit, big citrus character, grapefruit zest. Flavor just as aroma suggests, with light vanilla/oaky character. Really clean. Great mouthfeel, silky smooth. Really nice.

Pours golden with a thin white head that leaves nice lacing in my glass. Aroma is huge citrusy hops. Medium body Flavor is Huge hops, but not at all harsh. Slight oaky/vanilla notes with a nice clean finish. Absolutely loved this!

Courtesy of rayl101
Bottle:  The aroma has lots sweet citrus and tropical fruit along with some light grapefruit.  It pours a transparent amber with a small soapy white head.  The flavor starts with sweet citrus, light tropical fruit, and a touch of caramel. The finish has notes of grapefruit and light floral hops.  Medium bodied with soft carbonation.

Bomber from Beer Run in Charlottesville, VA. Pours a clear amber color with a medium frothy white head. Good head retention and lacing. Aroma of big spicy, floral, herbal hops, citrus notes in the back end and a good bit of toffeeish and toasted malt notes. The taste is strong bitter herbal hop notes, strong citrus and candied citrus, toffeeish malts, floral notes. Well balanced. Strong lingering bitterness. Almost chewy. Medium-full bodied. Very nice beer.
Bottle pours orange color with marshmellow  head.  Aroma is citrus.  Medium mouthfeel.  Flavor is citrus, has a nice malt backbone, and finishes citrus tart.  A nice brew.

bottle from Plaza at home 10Mar11 pours light caramel with a medium fluffy white head that leaves rings of lace through the pint.  Aroma is  tropical fruit and pine hop notes all the way.  Smells fantastic with layers of juicy fruit.  Flavor is pretty sweet upfront with toast, mandarin oranges and tangelos ending with a bitter toast/nut malt character and dry pine on the back of the throat.  Really a highly quaffable beer that remains dry and light but packs a punch with flavor.
22oz bottle. Pours clear amber with slight white head.  Citrus/floral hop aroma. Citrus hop to the tongue, nice bite to the back. Solid beer.

Clear gold with a cm of white head.  Aroma is sweet  red grapefruity nectar.  Taste is just as it smell with nectary hop goodness, beautiful malt, and relatively mild alcohol into the finish .  Medium carbonation.  Fantastic @ $8/22oz

Draft at 1702. Pours clear orange/amber; 1-finger white head, spotty lacing. Nose is grapefruit, mandarin, apricot; lovely spicy pine resin notes here as well. Flavours of soapy pine, grapefruit, white peach flesh. Very juicy finish. Killer stuff. Would drink this daily were it available locally.

Overall if this was a little better carbonated it would be excellent; a needed balance to the rich oiliness of the hops. High register hop aroma, citrus and pine. clear orange amber body but the the head faded in 30 seconds. Hops more resiny in flavor, along with a caramel, leather malt, alcohol well concealed. very clean finish.,

Strong head of varying sized bubbles with good carbonation.  Unbelievable aroma.  Loaded with fruit.  Pineapple, oranges, pears.  Like sniffing fruit cocktail.  A hint of pine sap and sweet malts round out the fantastic aroma.  Soft and smooth malty flavor.  Some butterscotch, sweet malts, juniper berries and a hint of fruit late swallow.  Prominent alcohol kick and presence.  Body is a bit on the thin side so the alcohol really stands out.  A slight bitterness which is not a strong as expected based upon the aroma.  Finishes warm and smooth with a lingering bit of bitterness.  An all around great IIPA!

Growler pours a slightly dark orange with a creamy, white head.  Nose is nice, fresh smelling, piney, resinous hops, sticky, oranges, grapefruit, some tropical fruit.  Flavor is sweet, honey, candied orange peel, oily, light crystal malt, grapefruit juice.  Full bodied, heavy finish.

22oz bottle 3/5/11 (Binnys Downers Grove)-52° in Snifter-Pours a clear orangish amber with a small off white head. Aroma of hops, citrus, and grapefruit. Taste of hops, citrus, malt, caramel, and grapefruit. This full bodied brew is well balanced and it hids the ABV very well. Nice job.

22oz. Bottle:  Aroma of hops, grass, pine, grapefruit, and more hops.  Poured amber in color with a small to medium-sized, creamy, dense, off-white head that greatly diminished but lasted throughout.  Clear.  Sparkling.  Excellent lacing.  Flavor is medium sweet and medium bitter.  Tastes of hops, malt, caramel, grapefruit, grass, and a hint of honey.  Medium body.  Average texture.  Average carbonation.  Medium sweet, medium bitter, hop, caramel, malt, grass finish.  9.5%ABV is completely hidden throughout.
Over all a good DIPA. Pours clear golden, nice hoppy cannabis nose, flavor is bitter, with just a touch of sweetness. Finishes with a chalky finish.

22 oz bottle.  Clear woody orange with a sturdy off-white head.  Nose is orange, pink grapefruit and caramel with floral hints.  Medium body, a touch syrupy.  Carb is sharp but soft adding just enough bite to counter the sticky palate.  Taste is mango, pineapple, honeydew and pine.  Silky swirls of vanilla caramel mingle with tart and bitter citrus.  Lingering black pepper with a bit of numbing.  More like a barleywine but still fantastic.  I might have rated this higher if i didnt have The Younger (4.3) a few days ago.

Bomber. Pours a sparkling orange and gold color with a thin layer of dense head. The aroma is a potent mix of ruby red grapefruit and tangerines with a dose of hops and cannabis resin. The taste begins with grapefruit and orange citrus flavors followed by toasted caramel malt and bitter, resiny hops. It finishes with strong citrusy bitterness and a slight alcohol kick at the end. The overall flavor is an aggressive blend of citrus and hops bitterness with a solid malt backbone to balance things out. A worthy companion to Union Jack.

Slightly hazy orange amber pour. Pine bouquet nose is heavenly. Massive big resinous citrusy hop profile is VERY delicious.   LIngering sticky grapefruity finish that stays on the palate for quite a while.  Damn good stuff.

Smells of fruit cake. Has a butterscotch color that is clear. Medium bitterness with a medium to heavy sweetness. Easy to drink with a little fizz and some oily texture. This is one of the better doubles, but not one of the best for me.

Bottle thanks to Steptin.  Clear gold amber colour. Lasting beeige head.  Lovely aroma of hops.  Touch burnt. Some burnt toffee in mouth.  Some sweetness on finish.  Some bitterness.  I liked the hops but there was this sweet burnt malt thing going on. Crystal malt I guess
Sometimes with high alcohol IPAs they can be harsh - not this one, excellent!

On tap at Firestone Brewery, tried this along with Union Jack at same time.  Way more fruity in aroma and flavor than the Union Jack.  Alcohol is hidden well but would have liked a little more of the hops to come through.

Effervescent golden pour with small white head. Resiny (wet hopped?) nose
Citrusy hops and light early malts make for a good combo.
Masks the alcohol well as advertised.
Super clean and well balanced. . quick bitter finish.  Wow

Poured a clear light orange color with an off white head. Nice mix of citrus fruits in the nose, particularly orange, lemon, and lime. Sweaty and pine hop notes as well. Also a good whiff of caramel. Medium bodied and sweet. The hop bitterness was somewhat attenuated by the sugars. Tasted of flan, caramel and orange liqueur with fresh cereal emerging at the end.

On tap.  Frothy white head with resinous lacing over caramel/copper beer.  Aroma is pungent, clean pine, medium-bitter and delicate floral hops, citrus, and a light breaded malty backdrop.  Taste is the bitter hops up front, clean pine and citrus, and slight alcohol before the malt which goes a touch sweet as the beer warms.  No loose ends on this one - very tightly structured and well done beer.  The brewery must have redone the recipe on this beer as this glass is much improved over other glasses Ive had directly from the brewery.

Bomber from IL (where Firestone is allowed to be) courtesy of my bro - thanks ck1!  Pours a pale orange with a lot of fine champagne-style bubbles.  Great lacing.  Aroma is fresh fruit, lots of pine, grass - great hoppy aroma.  Taste is pure hop juice; fruit, pine, sweetness.  Nice bitterness back.  Some malt, but more hops, hops and hops.  Alcohol well hidden.  As it warms it becomes more syrupy and bitter.  Somewhat thin.  Extremely quaffable.  Terrific!

Pours medium golden amber with an eggshell colored, finger thick head. Lots of sweet caramel malt in the nose and flavor, with more sweetness from the hop profile in the tangerine and orange influence. A bit of bitterness comes through in the late palate to finish.

Draft at pacific standard. Pours a copper brown color with no head. Smells of pine, grass and pot. Taste is sweet,syrupy with a stickly hoppiness. The taste is the same but the abv is not present making it quite drinkable. Has a flowery aftertaste. Im enjoying this very much

Bottle - thanks to bman1113vr.
Light orange color with some nice white head.  Tropical fruit and pine hop aromas - pine is definitely the star of the show here.  Pinepple and other tropical fruit flavors with a nice malt backbone.  ABV is almost non-existent, I really enjoyed this and want more!

UPDATED: MAR 10, 2011 On tap at Toronado..  Eerily similar to the Younger.  Amber in color with great hop aromas.  A huge caramel malt backbone in this bad boy to counter those grapefruit flavored hops...

On tap at Rose and Crown for SF Beerweek.  Massive grapefruit and floral jump out to the glass.  Beautiful aroma.  Very full mouthfeel with great malt backbone.  The hops and bitterness make this a complex and well rounded beer.

Bomber from City Beer Store.  Pours a nice clear copper with a medium sticky white head- great lace. Aroma is sticky sappy pine, big upfront citrus, orange grapefruit and pineapple hints- fresh and powerful hops.  Flavor is light cracker some slight honey but not too sweet, grapefruit, orange peel, citrus, juicy with pine and weed resins.  Finish is good bitterness, clean and mostly dry.  Pretty good!

bomber thanks to DaSilky1.  Pours a clear amber with a thin, off-white head.  Nose is powerful citrus and pine.  Very fresh and potent aroma that was quite impressive.  Taste was of fresh citrus and some sweet malts.  Mouthfeel was sweet and bitter.  Very good.

Pours a very orangy amber, medium head, very sudsy. Aroma is citrus, pine, and caramel malt. A bit of sweetness up front gives way to nice, moderately intense bittering and hints at stonefruit and sweet citrus.  The bittering lingers for a moment but definitely doesnt overstay its welcome. This is fantastically balance, I really didnt expect such a great composition. Extremely reminiscent of 90 Minute IPA or Hopslam. Delicious.
22 oz bomber.  A great refreshing citrusy double ipa. Cloudy yellow with a nice white head.

650ml bottle poured into a tulip glass.  Aggressive pour resulted in minimal head with some lacing.  Fruity aroma, I pick up a tangerine like smell but do not notice the grapefruit.  The first noticeable taste is bitter fruit that quickly becomes malty and finishes bitter with a very slight sweet taste.  This is a really good Double IPA.  I should have tried this side by side with Pliny!

UPDATED: MAR 20, 2011 Tap @ Boulder Strong Ale Festival. Light yellow orange appearance with a white head. Very floral hoppiness that mostly dominates the pale malts. Very floral and very citrusy hop flavor that makes up most of the flavor of the beer. Grapefruity, bitter finish..

650 mL bottle. Bottle dated 12/15/10. Drank 2/18/11. Poured into Duvel tulip. 

APPEARANCE: Pours orange gold. Quite translucent/filtered. 

Off-white, cream colored head is about 2 fingers, has lengthy duration, and fair amount of lacing. 


AROMA: Citrus, floral, cantaloupe, pine. Very clean, balanced, robust, and delightful. Faint hint of resinous hops and wet hay on nose as well. 


TASTE: More hop-forward (ie, less balanced) than aroma. Pine, citrus, resinous hops. Some floral/honey-like malt sweetness. 

Finish is more flavor-hop focused than excessively bitter. Bitterness and its duration are on the lighter side for the style - which I prefer.

Subtle graininess on finish as well. 


MOUTH FEEL: Medium bodied. Some minimal amount of syrupiness.  


OVERALL: A solid imperial/double IPA. Aroma is particularly impressive. However, little in the way of extremely unique characteristics. Appearance could have been slightly better if the beer was less filtered.

UPDATED: SEP 6, 2014 Growler from Cloverleaf.  Pours a clear copper color with a white foam head.  Has an aroma of grapefruit, caramel, pine, and booze.  Very malty smooth.  Sweet grapefruit taste with a more mellow but tasty hop hit. with some booze on the back end.  Damn tasty.  Unique in that it comes to play but is somehow still mellow.

Thanks to emacgee for sharing.   Nice mostly translucent orange pour with a sudsy steady white head that sticks.  Lots of nice lace and legs.  Big fresh hop resinous  nose--citrus, herbal, floral notes abound.  Flavor is big citrus, alcohol shows a bit, but its very dry and juicy overall.  California, knows how to party.

Thanks a bunch fear025. Pours a gorgeous crystal clear golden amber with two fingers of sticky white head. Mongo intense nose... extremely resinous and fresh, lots of citrus rind and some spicy piny notes.  Super sticky/oily hop flavor, lots of resins and citrus zest with notes of pine and a lightly sweet malt character. Has a bit more body than I would have expected but the bitterness is very well maintained and dissipates quickly on the finish.

Clear, dark golden, with decent, creamy, white head / Big nose of orange, grapefruit, and fresh cut pine / Medium to full body, biting hops with good fruit balance and long, lightly sweet, finish / Flavors of orange, grapefruit, fresh cut pine, resin, bubblegum, and caramel / Near perfect.

Bottle.  Pours a bright orange with soapy white head, very little lacing.  Nose is heavy on the grapefruit, I get sweet bubblegum and onions underneath, sounds gross but its not!  The caramel malt flavor really dominates the hops to begin this, but quickly gives way to a spicy middle, and finishes long with nothing but onion-like hops bitterness, it works in this beer since there is such an intense malt backbone.  Sticky for an DIPA, but suprisingly easy to put down, even at 9.5%.  Excellent beer.

Pretty good!  Grassy ( new cut ), grapefruit nose.  Bitter and sweet more to the sweet.  Grapefruit again in the taste.  Good mouthfeel.  Oily hop resin thru out taste and finish.  No notice of alcohol.  Full flavored dbl IPA.  What i call a well balanced imp ipa.
Bistro Double IPA Fest.  Poured golden amber, smooth, citrus and floral hops, caramel malts, clean finish.

Location: 12 oz bottle from Shop Rite - Hoboken, 2/16/11


Aroma: A big hop nose, grapefruit, mango, other citrus fruits, and a good amount of resin/pine

Appearance: It pours a clear caramel-orange color with a creamy white head and lots of lace

Flavor: The taste has some nice citrus sweetness and a good amount of hop bitterness

Palate: Medium bodied, mouth feels lightly creamy, well rounded, with soft to average carbonation

Overall Impression: 
I was very excited to see this one show up in a store in NJ, I didnt know it had distribution out this way.  Anyway, I was actually rather impressed.  This beer is right up my alley with lots of nice resin and citrus.  A really well-made and high quality Double IPA.

On tap at Jerrys.  Pours golden orange.  Floral nose with pine, citrus, resin, and honey. Medium sticky mouth-feel with plenty of carbonation.  More resinous hops, citrus in taste.  A very nice, well refined DIPA.

Tasted on tap at the 11th Bistro Double IPA Festival on 2/12/2011. This Imperial India Pale Ale pours a medium to light orange gold color from the tap. Medium sized white foamy head, with decent lacing and nice retention. The aroma is fruity and sweet, citrusy and floral. A medium to full bodied Imperial IPA. The malts are fruity and sweet. The hops are citrusy and floral. Good carbonation. Extremely well balanced between the malts and hops, there is just a touch of bitterness at the finish. Hides the alcohol very well. A very mellow double IPA, which is somewhat of a misnomer, but does apply to this beer. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly sweet.

22oz bottle from Bottleworks. Pours a crystal clear amber with persistent half inch of cream head. Aroma is vibrant, citrus hops, earthy malt and some spiciness. Taste is chewy with floral and citrus hops, really bright grapefruit note, slightly sweet. Excellent viscous mouthfeel. Malt back provides good mild caramel balance to offset the intense bitterness. I didnt get the basil note the brewers described but there is something vaguely herbal here. Finish is slow, long and rewarding. Top notch beer.

Draft.  Small off-white head that leaves nice lacing atop crystal clear light amber body.  Aroma is moderately sweet, orange/grapefruit, light bread.  Taste is moderately sweet, grapefruit/lemon, some orange.  Soft medium-full body, some resin.

Wow - this beer is delicious. It pours a perfect amber color with a white head on top. The aroma is smooth bitter light citrus hops. The flavor is so smooth for the ABV with a medium body and sweet but potent hops to end on the palate.

Bottle; poured a clear amber color with not much head.  Great aroma.  Caramel, fruit, herbs, flavors, citrus and grapefruit.  Flavor was smooth but bursting.  Know that really doesnt make sense.  Citrus, caramel, sguar, alcohol, and fruit.  Nice.

UPDATED: MAY 8, 2011 22 oz. bottle from Grape & Gourmet.  Pours dark orange with a fizzy off-white head.  Aroma of fresh cut grass and pine needles with hints of tangerine in the background.  Bitter grapefruit rind is at the forefront of the flavor with expected pine and grassy hops and only a hint of malty sweetness to balance. The bitter hops coat the tongue for a lingering effect.  An exceptional DIPA and a hop lovers delight.

Draft at Belmont Station and then a bottle from The Beer Mongers.  The description by FW pretty much nails it and really appealed to me.  One of these IIPAs that you have to try if you are a fan of the style.  The "...grapefruit and juicy fruit..." are the best part, its what I love in an IIPA.  I dont agree with it being too aggressive though, its very drinkable for having a high abv.  I believe it should be drank asap to enjoy the fresh flavors.

Bottle. Poured a clear rosie chestnut. Smell strikes an amazing balance between sweet maple and spicy hops. Taste is similar with the floral spicey and citrus hops over maple syrupy rich goodness. This is delicious!
This is seriously just a stronger version of the union jack. It tastes exactly like it but a bit boozier. Very sharp bitterness.  I little disappointing but still a fine beer.

Thanks to bman1113vr for sharing this bottle.

The beer pours a golden-orange color with a white head. The aroma is heavy on the grapefruit and pine hops, with some resiny, dank hops mixed in as well. 

The flavor is more of the same. I get a lot of resiny pine, as well as some pineapple, papaya and other tropical fruit. No detectable alcohol. Medium bitterness and very easy to drink. 

Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation. A very nice Double IPA.
Bottle, thanks to bman1113vr, golden color with an aroma of Christmas trees, garlic and onion rings, flavor of salty bit o honey and pineapple, somehow this worked

22oz bottle. Pours a crystal clear, golden-bronze colored body with a finger-width, dense and frothy, off-white head that dissipates slowly and leaves a nice, delicate lacing. Aroma jumps out with lots of sweet, resiny tropical fruits and some herbal spice behind the sweetness. Mango, peach, papaya, candy oranges, tangerine, and grapefruit. Very nice, juicy, fruity complexity with some light pines and florals alongside the soft herbal spice. The malts are fairly sweet with some honey, a touch of biscuity grain, and caramel. Flavor seems to lack some of the hop depth I was expecting, but is still quite nice. Lots of tropical fruits, grapefruits, and candy oranges with a sweeter resin. Medium pines and herbal pepper, but could use a bit more complexity IMO. The malts are again sweet and well rounded with some honey, grain, and caramel. The hops do dry this nicely with a medium, somewhat sticky, peppered pine bitterness that leaves a lengthy aftertaste. Medium, silky body and soft, moderate carbonation. Overall, a really nice DIPA. Fairly sweet, but filled with bright, tropical fruits and citruses. Nice, resiny, balanced finish with a really pleasant feeling body. Solid.

Super fresh 2011 bomber.  Pours a clear, dark golden color with a fluffy, yellowish-beige head of foam.  Slowly disbursing, the head becomes a thin center film with a pronounced, foamy edge.  When allowed to settle on its own, the head leaves dense, tattered sheets of tapestry lacing all over the glass, completing the attractive look.  In the true west coast tradition, the nose is loaded with juicy citrus hops, ranging from biting white grapefruit, to sweeter tangerine peel and freshly bloomed orange blossoms.  Theres a dry pithiness, but also sweeter citrus oiliness, countering one another beautifully.  A touch of fresh basil lends a green, herbal element, as do hints of grass and maybe a dash of pine needles.  Malts are prominent, yet sufficiently dry, hinting at light English biscuit that has been cut with a hint of galletas (Cuban crackers).  They provide a moderately sweet background that seems a perfect marriage for the abundant, juicy, resinous hops.  Flavors follow suit, again amply hopped and citrus driven, booming with bitter grapefruit, tangerine skin, naval orange, and even a touch of lemon rind.  Pine plays a backup role, as does herbal green grass.  Countering malts are lightly caramelized, coming across as more toasty and crackery than biscuity and cookie-like.  Still, theres the perfect amount of sweetness there to take the edge off of the substantial, biting hop profile.  The beer drinks lighter than its 9.5% ABV would suggest, towing the line between ample body and relative dryness, with moderate, unobtrusive carbonation throughout.  In short, this is a great beer.  Firestones limited releases continue to impress, and this one is right up there with the best of the Anniversary series in terms of a total package.

Pours rich golden with amber waves of grain. A mountainous frothy canopy above the malt is lain. IPA, IPA god shed his grace on thee for this is one of the best Ive had in a long time. A thick malty backbone supports the thriving hop community that instill fear in the faint of heart. This brew is rich with a bit of malty sweetness. Generous with its unnoticeably high ABV. Crown thy malt with cap and seal, and savor day to day. Very fresh tasting.

UPDATED: FEB 9, 2011 Bottle from DaSilky1.  Thanks man!  Amber-orange color with a thin off-white head settling on top for good.  Tropical fruity hops invade the aroma with notes of pine, florals, and light herbs.  The flavor mostly follows that with big juicy tropical fruity hops.  Grapefruit, orange peel, and some lemongrass seem to stand out.  A hop bomb for sure.  This is a little on the sweet side, especially for a west coast IIPA, but with ample bitterness its fine.  In that regard, it kind of resembles some of my favorites from the midwest.  A little alcohol heat sets in towards the finish although it tries to dry out a bit here as well.  This is just a really good beer that may slide just below some of the best within the style.

Bottle. Pours a golden/amber with a thin yellow head but decent/good retention. Aroma is tropical fruits, pineapple, caramel, and tropical fruit juice. Taste is sticky hops with a nice balance of sweet malt. Very easy drinking DIPA, and underrated imho.

On tap. Poured a clear deep gold with a white head that dissipated to the edges and laced nicely. Aroma was a combination of sweet grain, pine and citrus with mainly grapefruit coming from the citrus note. Flavor was similar with pine, resin and grapefruit and a relatively strong sweet grain backbone.

Bottle; Pour is clear copper colored ; frothy whitish head that retains well - mild lacing in this snifter. This brew has a fantastic balance of maltiness and floral hops on the nose. Juicy grapefruit rinds, caramel malts, a slight earth feel ; this brew is sweet, bitter, floral, and delicious. Really. Fantastic brew.

Moderately strong aroma of grapefruit peel and tangerine peel. Clear amber, medium quickly dissipating head.  Exquisite amount of hops for the amount of body and sweetness. Mango and tangerine peel flavor. Grapefruit peel toward the end, with a greater malt presence. Medium body, but not hot. Superbly well balanced and easy to drink.
On tap at 38 Degrees.  Pours dark gold with a one finger off white head.  The nose is ripe mango and orange peel.  The taste is ripe citrus, toffee and grapefruit.  A tad sweet but very nice.

Pours orangey gold with a nice frothy tan head. Malty aroma with a variety of spices and herbal hops. Sweet malt flavor with sugary bread that washes into a big herbal hop blast. Nice fruitiness but the bitterness is too modest for me. Slightly astringent, full bodied, a tad boozy.

Bomber from Vas Foremost. Pours a crystal clear gold with fluffy white head. Nose is robust hops. Bitter grapefruit, orange blossom and a bit of catty notes dominate. Some sweet malt in the background. On taste, quite bitter, but also quite boozy. Full hop character, tons of citrus, hint of onion on the finish. Full malt body that just supports. Pretty damn fine IIPA.

Crystal clear light copper color with a thin white head.  Slightly resinous, grassy hop aroma.  Excellent balance of malt and hops.   Unlike a lot of DIPAs, you dont get hit over the head with hops and then get the malt as an afterthought.  Theres an equal play between a strong, fruity hop bitterness and a lightly sweet, medium bodied malt fullness with caramel/butterscotch undertones.   As big as this beer is, it would pair very well with food without overpowering it (as long as the food was hearty enough to stand up to it).

Purchased at Pike Place Deli and Grocery, or what ever the hell its called. Still, that place has a nice selection. In fact, its the only place that Ive seen where this is available. Anyways, a nice fluffy head sits on-top of a coppery orange transparent beer. This beer has a pungent grapefruit, orange citrus aroma that just smacks my olfactories, like Ike slappin Tina. Sorry for the misogynistic statement, but I cant think of anything else. This has a nice subtle fruit aroma, that is pleasant to smell. Wow, this beer is delicious. It has a bit of a rough beginning, but it has a nice citrus and fruit hop flavor that blends almost perfectly with the sweet flavor coming from the malts. The beer uses hops perfectly, in my opinion. There is this lingering bitterness, but its not caustic. Im enjoying the lingering bitterness. The alcohol isnt noticeable. The texture is nice and resinous. I hope they produce this year-round. Pliny, watch out, someone is giving you a run for your money.

Not hard to believe that Firestone would get this beer so right.  Wonderful pine, grapefruit and orange with some herbal notes.  The taste is where the malt shines: caramel sweetness and earthy notes with a nice bit of alcohol heat.  Finishes with a medium to high bitterness and is nice a dry so that the bitterness doesnt linger overlong.  This beer is up there with some of the best Double IPAs out there, hands down.

UPDATED: FEB 8, 2011 651mL. Pours a clear amber with a very thin, yellow, dense head with fair retention but sticky, webby, white lace. Aroma is pineapple, fruity/tropical hops, caramel malt, lemon, sweet candies, sweet cherries, passionfruit, incredible amount of fruit juice tropical notes. Taste brings very sticky sweet malt as the base with some serous alcohol presence. Big fruity tropical hops with an oily mouthfeel. No cloying. No newspaper. No nutty, nut skin bitterness. Fairly soft and easy to love. Nice. Pretty solid, fresh, DIPA.

(22oz bottle, courtesy of BMan1113VR)  Pours a clear golden body with a small white head.  Aroma of weed, grapefruit, nuts, tangerine, grain, florals, and passion fruit.  Flavor of passion fruit, nuts, citrus, caramel, grain, and grass.  Excellent!

Really enjoyed this one...bright, floral, strong pine presence, and just a touch of noticeable alcohol.  Oily Ponderosa, Douglas Fir, and Spruce notes with grapefruit, citrus, and lemongrass.  Nice aromatics...fairly assertive...fills the nostrils.  Still a bit hot but really enjoyable.  Love Union Jack...this definitely kicks it up a notch.
Big DIPA from the hops perspective.  Light amber color, aroma is not as strong as youd think considering the taste.  Taste is both piney and citrusy hops all at once, a real hop assault.  Very good.

really does taste like an imperial union jack.  i loved the big full body and huge bitterness.  lots of pine, the finish lingers on for EVER.  holding it back was maybe too much caramel malt for my liking.  compared to hoptimum it really lacks the delicious tropical flavors and complexity, which is why I cant rate this higher than a 4.  this is a truly good beer but I really was expecting something a little more special from one of my favorite breweries, this one kind of felt "same old, same old" compared to Green Flash and even Hop Stoopid.

6.99 for a 22oz to the dome. pours a very light yellow orange, crisp, with an ample but not overdone creamy white head, leaves some spotting. aroma is bittersweet, lots of citrus and floral notes, some abv in there slightly, but the malt is most prominent still. the taste is great, nice malty breakfast breads are slathered with tons of sweet hops, very fruity and floral, tons of ruby red grapefruit, nice. good stuff, drinks pretty easy, a nice offering. glad i got to try this in a bottle, and fresh at that! definitely some good stuff, overall very sweet, especially for a west coaster, but i still like it.

UPDATED: MAR 18, 2012 This was tasted at MeKong restuarant in Richmond.  This  was a special beer for the day.  The color was a clear deep amber with very head.  There was a typical bitter taste of hops  with some citrus but deceptively high alcohol.  The smooth finish had no  bitter aftertaste.

Bomber.  Pours a brilliant orange-russet hue.  Little foam, just lacing on the surface of the pour.  Big citrus, grapefruit, and pine aroma.  First sip is big on body and carbonation, mouthfeel is smooth, not sticky and cloying.  Flavors are as expected, pine sap, and multiple citrus notes springing up throughout the palate, before a largely bitter, but balanced finish.  Sparkly, almost fizzy mouthfeel and balance characterize this big brew with a well-disguised ABV.

Had this on tap and it was amazing.  Very little head on the pour and all you could smell were the hops.  Im a hop-head so to me, theres nothing better.  Tastes floral and piney, the way a DIPA should.  This was almost as good as Pliny the Elder.  Have one bottle that I cant wait to try

Bottle. Pretty, translucent amber pour with a short, off-white head. Aroma is pungent, wet hops, pine resins, grapefruit juice and orange peel oils.  Taste is big juicy wet hops, pine cones, grapefruit juice, pineapple, chewy caramel, sweet malt and citrus oils. Much sweeter and richer than bitter and hoppy. Body is thick and full with a soft, creamy carbonation. Theres a pleasant lingering hop bitterness as well and a resinous feel. Ends with more grapefruit juice, pineapple, pine resins, wet hops and caramel. Yummy!

540 ml bottle from Bev4less. Pours a rich copper color with a medium white head that has fair retention. The aroma is big and bold with fresh citrus--I get grapefruit, oranges and lemons. The flavor, like the aroma,  is also citrus forward; add to the citrus some pine, herbs and toffee. The palate is full and smooth with lively carbonation. Finishes long and biter. Overall: A first rate DIPA, this compares favorably to PTE, perhaps someday Ill do a blind tasting.

The aroma is something not to be missed. The hops are overwhelming and intoxicating in and of themselves, needing not for you to even taste the brew to know its strength. The white head is foamy and drops off a bit to leave hefty laces. The beer is golden and much like a fruit juice in its depth. It is utterly flawless and clear. The landing on the palate takes no prisoners. It is wonderfully brutish in its creaminess and the aftertaste is wonderfully bitter without becoming too much. It is a proper and strong IPA. If you can find it, do not pass up the opportunity.

Wow!  Had this on 2/1/2011.  This beer pours a very light brown almost gold color that you can see through.  Lots of head on the initial pour with very nice lacing on glass.  I can get grapefruit, citrus, rich malt, almost orange and wheat out of the nose.  Just by the smell you can tell this is a west coast double.  I have to say on the palate though first things first this beer is very very crisp and clean for a 9.5% double IPA.  Nice grapefruit, citrus, malts mixing in as well to give you that backbone.  Leaves the palate with a very subtle sweet hop flavor.  Excellent beer, very highly recommended!!

Bomber served in a tulip. Love Union Jack so Im optimistic about this one... Pours ultra clear true orange with a medium-short off-white head. Decent retention and good lacing. Massive citrus hop nose! Tangerine...check. Grapefruit...check. Also pine and herb, both huge. Perfection erring on the side of H-O-P-S, as it should be. Very bitter, medium sweet flavor. Medium body, thick-creamy-sticky texture, mild fizz, and a sweet, xx bitter finish. Definitely plenty of heat in this too. Warm after the first glass. This is ridiculous.

Draft snifter at Bavarian Lodge, $6. Oooh, fresh Amarillo hops for sure from the first whiff. Thin, clingy white head andyipes! I just cant get the impression of cat whizz out of my nose. Thass one big hoppy beer. Really clear copper-amber color, which I suggest is their Union system at work. The first sip brings in syrupy malts, not sticky, but bright, with some impressions of iced tea. Hops are still nearly bringing tears to my eyes, so youve got to really be a hop-head to enjoy this one. Coats the tongue with both malt and bitterness, yet the total mouthfeel is a little lighter than, say a Hopslam. Still delivers on that big hippity hop hop. A smack in the face with a bale of wet hops. Did I mention this was hoppy?

On tap @ Fountainhead. Poured hazy amber, big white head, lots of lace. This has a huge complex flower hop aroma, creamy body, huge hop flavor on a nice sweet malt base, wonderful interplay between the big hop flavor and the malt sweetness.

Clear golden orange with a white head that starts large but quickly settles to a small film. Lots of stringy lacing. Strong, fruity aroma with citrus and grapefruit, Amarillo hops, and floral notes. The flavor is very sweet at first, with a lot of resinous hop flavors, then finishes with strong and hoppy bitterness and a little heat. Oily and sticky texture with a medium body and prickly carbonation. More on the sweet side of balance.
Aroma is sweet malts and citrus... Color is pure gold... Flavor is even better sweet citrus flavor, mild bitter palate... Like a 90 minute only slightly better... Amazing

Bottle.  Pours a somewhat viscous golden orange copper with a smaller frothy white head, lighter in color than I thought from the ratings.  It is a little medicinally sweet on the aftertaste, piney resiny.  Upfront is peachy, mango, passion fruit, tropical fruits, grape, orange, some grapefruit towards the finish, candy orange biscuit, medicinal bitterness, very juicy and quite a bit of sweetness, not toasty caramel like I was expecting from the ratings.   Hides the alcohol well, but just a bit too medicinal.  Medium bodied, bit sticky but very drinkable, sharp carbonation.  Aroma is bright and stingy, orange, citrus, some pine, juicy, candy sweetness, nice.  Kind of fruit loopy but really good and certainly better than most.

Bottle courtesy of Kan.  Pours a clear golden hued orange with a medium sized creamy white head that eventually fades away into some spidery lacing. Enormous cool clean citrus notes, big and hoppy, slightly dank and resinous.  Medium to thick bodied, sweet and full of caramel and crystal.  Smooth and easy drinking, and at 9.5% the ABV is pretty well hidden.

22oz bomber, dated 12/15/10, from grape & gourmet. pours a gorgeous, clear gold with a thick, creamy, eggshell head and great lacing. aroma is fantastic with huge, sticky, citrus hop notes of tangerine, pink grapefruit, and lemon pulp backed by tropical notes of mango, apricot, and pineapple with rich pine esters, wet grass, and herbal (garlic? rosemary?) notes rounding things out. flavor is wonderful as well, on the sweeter side of the DIPA world, with candied pineapple, apricots, and peach skins up front backed by tangerine and pink grapefruit citrus, sticky pine and floral esters, toffee, and bitter, herbal grass on the back end. palate is on the fuller side of medium bodied with light carbonation and a nice herbal spicyness and dry bitterness on the finish to balance the initial sweetness. overall, a great dipa at 6 weeks old. how amazing is this stuff at its freshest?!

Bomber. Pours a clear light golden with a thick foamy white head. Aroma is excellent fresh resiny hops, a nice blend of tropical citrus fruit, mango orange and grapefruit with just a bit of piney notes and a definite sweet toasty caramel malt.  Flavor is also very balanced, of course hop forward, but very fresh tropical and juicy fruits. Plenty of sweet caramel, honey and biscuity notes. Finishes crisp and bitter but clean, with a touch of booziness hops lingering. Medium to full lightly sticky body and a softer carbonation. Delicious beer

Snifter on tap at Jake Melnicks (Chicago, IL). Pours a glowing dulled amber gold hue, touches of fiery orange saturate the body, light haze, some darker influence with a cakey offwhite head atop that turns to soap, a decent head sticks atop and laces well. Aromas are big blasts of tropical hops, citrus moves into the fold, big grapefruit and mango, peach and pale and caramel malts. Biscuits and bread are overwhelmed by big Simcoe. Aromatics rue the day, as this is a very juicy beer on the nose. Initial is heavier end of medium bodied with a huge juicy fruit presence, mango and peach pair with more huge tropical hops, grapefruit and lemony citrus, not the most bitter beer, as alcohol and nice pine and florals provide bitterness on the backend. Maltbase is sweet, sticky biscuits and toffee, bread and pale malts creep in, but a heavier beer is needed to pick up all the hops flavors, a big Simcoe bomb in my opinion. Soapy and dry bitterness cling on the backend with lingering bubblegum and mango, big juicy fruit. They werent messing around. I think the aroma is rich and powerful, and a great hop. But frankly, the hop complexity on the palate is a bit tame and unkept. Sure there is tropical hops, but where is the bigger bitterness to back it? Soapy and tropical, moderate bitterness for the size, but a bit too sweet for me overall. A nice IPA that preaches that tropical and bubblegum blues.
Draft at piece, pours clear golden with white head. Nose of mango, pinnapple, flavors are nicely bitter, grassy, grapefruit juice and pinnapple, orange slices. Nice and bitter, clean. Awesome brew.

Welcometo Chicago firestone-walker... On tap at revbrew prior to the bigger release party at piece... Pours an extremely clear slightly lighter than copper brown hue and crowned with a lasting fluffy barely off-white head... Aroma is big on a lychee type base which I dont get too often but one that reminds me of  the homeland (along with the sweeter syrupy base that u get with canned lynchee). For some reason those notes quickly fade into a mostly citrus hops and a pineapple juice sweetness. Not sure what happened there... Flavors, however, dont promote that same sense of nostalgia for me. Hops are present but not very distinguishable due to the heavy emphasis on caramel malts and a pervading sweetness that goes along with it. A light bittermess in the finish but not all that muh when all is said and done. Body is medium to full with adequate carbonation. Generally a little too sweet for me. That and a heavily boozey finish hurts its enjoyability for sure.  
had some of drews pour at piece and the former didnt didnt taste as nearly as clean as pieces and that was on a fresh palate.  hmmmm, a case of dirty lines? regardless, both did not seem like one and the same.

Aroma consists of strong fruit with a hint of hop. The appearance is a golden color with a orange/yellow hue. First taste shows the alcohol content along with the hops. The middle is where the fruit flavor comes through. The finish is a slight alcohol flavor with the bitterness following closely behind. This is a big beer, but is balanced enough to be drinkable in moderation.

UPDATED: JAN 14, 2011 Draft, Beveridge Place.  Orange pour, short white head.  Aroma is very characteristic of an American IIPA, lots of citrus, floral, and piney hops backed by caramelly sweetness.  Unfortunately, when tasting it I found the big hop aromatics get drowned in excessive syrupy caramel and honey sweetness.  The hops and sugars combine when first cipped to make a vegetal sensation on a syrupy body.  It still had a nice bitter citrus and resin hop bite on the finish that lingered nicely.  Smells good and finishes well, but overall a bit of a let down compared to other beers Ive had from FW.

On tap at AZ wine.  Hazy deep orange pour with a foamy head.  Citrus and pine hops dominate the aroma, along with caramel malt and honey.  Flavor is slightly sweet at the start, but quickly turns bitter an hopalicious.  Very nice!

Nice oragne/gold pour with a creamy off white head.  Aroma of citrus, piney hops, honey, light bready notes.  Flavor is hoppy and juicy.  Really delicious.  Citrus hops, some earthy hops, tangerines, grapefruit, calamondin.  Superb brew.  Tap at AZWine.

Sampled on tap at 1702, Tucson; December 2010
Arrives from the tap with a hazy, gold copper hue and it is topped by a frothy, almost one finger thick, pretty long lasting, light tan colored head that manages to leave some nice lacing on the sides of my glass.  The aroma smells nice and hoppy with concentrated notes of lychee, tangelo and kumquat zest that is backed by a little bit rougher notes of essential citrus oil.  The nose is definitely expressive, but manages to be smoothly hoppy with out the sharper focus of pine and herbal notes often found in the style.

Oh yes, hops indeed, it is likely sucking on sweet hop nectar; definitely sweet tasting from both the supporting malt character and also the ample fruity hop notes.  The fruitiness is so tropical and vibrant in character with huge notes of lychee, a sort of mango / guava thing, softer tangelo zest notes, ripe kumquat freshly zested with essential oil bursting forth, .  The beer finishes with a softly biting bitterness that is quite a bit softer than a beer with this much hop character usually is and there is a light, sort of green, lightly herbal hop note that is just suggested.  In the long finish though, there is a note that reminds me just a touch of garlic chives, though this is fairly subtle.  The body of this brew definitely has some heft to it with a viscosity that sticks to the palate as the beer slides across the tongue, the linger bitterness helps to was this clean after each sip though & this is definitely appropriate for a Double IPA, though I might wish for a touch more lightness in the body; still this is quite drinkable & truthfully the fullness from the residual malt sugar also contributes to the huge expression of hop fruit character that this beer achieves.  The malt plays a clearly supporting role, but the sweetness is definitely an important part of this character (and in truth much of the sweetness comes from interaction with the hops rather than overly residual sugar levels) and it also contributes pale biscuit / cracker like malt character that is at times noticeable underneath the hop onslaught.  

I am really enjoying the vibrant hop focus of this beer.  I really like that the nose is completely focused on this character and that the flavor has just a touch of bitterness and hop-herbaceous character to add a needed balance.  A definite pleasant surprise, for some reason I wasnt expecting too much from this beer, despite really liking fresh Union Jack.  At this particular moment the fruit focus this beer has is definitely quite appealing, though I could see this being a bit too fruity and cloying to some (even to myself under a different situation).

On tap at Brouwers Cafe, pours hazy golden orange with an off-white head. Wonderful aroma of resinous hops, butter caramel, and grapefruit. Flavour of complex, rich caramel, resinous piney hops, and a little citrus. A most wonderful IIPA.

On draft at firestones tasting room in paso robles. Pour is amber with a thin persistent beige head. Nose is primarily caramel malt and citrusy hops.  Very heavy mouthfeel, caramel malt is predominant but well balanced with grapefruit and lemongrass hop notes. Hope notes persist through a dry finish with a touch of alcohol warming.

On tap at Firestone in August 2009.

A: Pours a darkened gold with a nice white head. Quite a bit of lacing.

S: Lots of hoppiness, mostly citrus and grapefruit with a little bit of pine. Some malty sweetness in the background.

T: Loads of hops and some malt sweetness in the background. 

M: Medium bodied and slightly creamy.

D: Quite drinkable, especially given the ABV. The hops make me want more and more.

Serving type: on-tap

Reviewed on: 10-01-2009

On tap @ 1702 - Pours a clear golden color with a small off white head was long lasting.  Thick lacing.  Aroma is lots of floral hops.  Flavor is floral and citrus hops with some lightly sweetened toasted malt.  Smooth finish.  Medium body.  A good clean 2IPA.

Draft pint.  Ive had this last year and this year and thought Id already rated it, but I guess not.  Pour a very slight hazed golden with small yet uniform eggshell white head with light lacing.  Nose is quite sweet and really fruity.  Pineapple, cherry, orange, mango...reminds me of hawaiian punch.  Carbonation is mellow yet even and enjoyable mouthfeel is medium light and has a slight sticky feel.  Sweet bready citrus malt up front, more with the pineapple heavy hawaiian punch flavor and the resinous pine hop flavor comes in light but does show on the end and adds some bittering to bite into the sweetness.  I tend to prefer my dipa to be on the sweet side, bit this one may be just a touch out of balance for me.  Still very enjoyable and keeps me coming back for multiples it seems.

Draft. An amber beer with a thin beige head. The aroma has notes of malt and caramel as well as strong notes of citrusy hops. The flavor is sweet with strong notes of hops lending it notes of grass and lime, combined with malt and caramel in the background. Very crisp.

On tap @ Papago for the FWXIV release. Pour is deep orange-copper with an off-white head.  Honey sweetness leads the way for peach, tangerine, and an underlying caramel backbone.  Flavor shows the same with sweet caramel leading to a moderate/heavy hop bitterness and a touch of pine.  Overall body is moderate to full and sticky.

(on draught at Papago for the FW XIV release).  Thanks Mike! Pours copper with white head.  Aroma of grapefruit and citrus in a major way!  Sweet with some bitterness.  Medium bodied with oily texture.  Finish is bitter, but super balanced.  An awesome brew!!

West USA trip 2010. On tap @ PIB. The aroma has some dark malts even, citrus, pine. Copper coloured with an off-white head. The taste is bitter, bit sparkling some caramel, pine citrus. Notes also say chocolate. Cant believe that now actually.

UPDATED: MAY 25, 2016 My Bottom Line:
Citrusy hops galore sink into each honeyed malt pore, building a luscious, silky Double IPA with a levelled resinous bitterness.

Further Personal Perceptions:
-A veil of foam tops the shiny golden amber. 
-The malts also offer light caramelization.
-Hops develop leaves, conifer needles and green peppercorns throughout.
-As in most Firestone Walker brews, the body is quite round and well polished; I really feel this type of mouthfeel works better in their stronger ales than in their quenchers.  
-Alcohol warmth swims within the plump body. 

Bottle and on tap at Toronado SF.
Poured Orange with rather thin head, perhaps a little too warm.  Aroma is resin and citrus.  Flavour is rather sweet for an IPA. Sweet citrus notes.  Lasting bitter hop finish which redeemed it.
user_location: Munchen an der Willamette, Oregon, USA

text: Draft at the Bistro DIPA Fest. Nose of floral, pine, and caramel with a hint of bubblegum. Lightly hazy gold with a small white head. Flavor is light bitterness with caramel and pine notes.

A: Dark orange in color, very nice white foam and great lacing.

S: Citrus hops, primarily grapefruit, a piney smell is also very present. Quite a bit of malt in the aroma, also.

T: Some bitterness, decent citrus characteristics, mild pine, and a lot of malty sweetness. I was hoping for a bit more hoppiness, however.

M: Medium bodied, a bit "sticky" from the malt.

D: Definitely a good drinking DIPA, but would have loved it to be more bitter and have more citrus.

On tap at Bistro DIPA Fest poured a clear gold with a lasting amber head. Aromas of biscuit, pine, earthiness and some light floral notes. Palate was light to medium bodied and smooth with a dry finish. Flavors of biscuit, earthiness, light pine and light citrus with a smooth dry lingering bitter finish.
Enjoyed on-tap at the Yard House, Scottsdale, tatum Road location.  Amber with a light head.  Bitterness dominated, alcohol well hidden, some malting down,not very balanced but a good hop delivery.

UPDATED: MAR 5, 2011 Rating #1 - Tap (from notes) (5 3 6 3 14).  Dark golden color with a white head.  Floral hops, light on the palate, bitter and dry.  Caramel malts and mildly sweet without the punch I would have expected from a double IPA.  Rating #2 - Bottle (7 3 7 3 17).  A golden color with a white head.  A strong pine aroma with a nice floral finish.  The citrus undertones are somewhat overpowered by the intense hop aroma.  It feels light in the body but has a nice earthy flavor.  Much better the second time around.

For an IPA, this beer, made by the folks at Firestone Walker, lacks that comfortable mouthfeel that its peers have. Nonetheless, the hops, clearly headbutting each other in the glass, make you understand that this is a sharp India Pale Ale, with enough bloody knuckled bite to keep your mouth sealed to the bottle. Perhaps not as memorable as other, more character driven IPAs, this Firestone Walker recipe is a classy notch in craft brewing history. Definitely something I would order again.
Crushed with Honkeybra at GABF.  I like a huge DIPA and this is one of em.  Big hops.  Pretty chewy brew and badass.

Draught @ Brouwers Café:   Vibrant amber, frothy white head, nice lacing, lively carbonation.   Musty hop nose, a little citrus peel.   Mild sweetness, a little bitter, but at 9.5% ABV it comes across as a lighter beer.   Feeks like a 1 1/2 IPA.   Needs more malt to balance it out.   Clean, soft bitterness, but this needs some more malt sweetness and a bit bigger body.   As is its a moderate body and mouthfeel.   Lingering citrus rind and hop bitterness.   Tiz okay, but its in need of more malts, sweetness, and a bigger body.

Cask Stillage from the Jug at the GABF, Colorado Convention Center 26/09/2009
Big hop aroma. Small white head. Golden coloured and very hoppy with a pine fruit flavour. Crisp and creamy on the palate with a little dryness in a bitter malt finish.
On tap at the firestone night at Sotne Bistro.  Pours a amber/gold with white head.  Citrus, sweet malt, lots of fresh hops, caramel, floral notes, and some pine.  A really tasty IIPA.
Tap at Firestone night at Stone.  Pours orange with a bright white ring.  Nose is sweet, very hoppy, lots of citrus.  Taste is sweet, hoppy and fresh, very nice dipa.

From a growler shared by DuffManSW, thanks for sharing Sean. Rating #44. Very clear darkish gold pour with a very nice fat white head and real good lacing. Great hop aroma, a little sweet and citrusy. Flavor was a little sweet as well, more citrus and a slight fruitiness as well, not to mention a nice lingering dose of hops that lasted for awhile, very well done. Good stuff. (1029)
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text: On tap @ Toronado SD.  Clear golden with a small off-white head, low retention.  Lots of overly sweet citrus, peach, and caramel in the nose.  Flavor is much the same with too much sweetness.  Bitterness peaks @ a 5 in the dry finish with just a little alcohol.  Medium body with light prickly carbonation.  The pint of Alpine Nelson rocked this 5 times more.  In conclusion, I didnt love this beer much.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: Pours a clear amber with a solid off-white head.  thick floral nose, quite perfumey, with maybe some orange blossom.   Thick, syrupy mouth with flavors of orange blossom, flowers, and sweetness.  I mean, it gets good flavors out of the ingrediants but its way too syrupy thick and sweet for my liking.
Sampled at GABF.  Big, piny hoppy aroma.  Some sweet malt too.  Flavor is oily resin hops, big hop flavor.  Mouthfeel was nice, thick, but not syrupy.  Pretty impressed with this one.
Smelled of of piney hops. Tasted of toffee and tons of hops. It was kind of oily in the mouth but overall was fantastic.

Poured a golden orange with  thin blanket of a head. 
Nose of grassy hops and piney hops. 
Taste is nice and malty, sweet with table sugar, toffee, good amount of sweetness, tons of hop bitterness,hop flavor is similar to the nose, lots of grassy and piney hops. Fairly oily with hop resin. A very big beer that was more of a sipper than i intended to order, but a very solid DIPA offering.

Draft @ Sac Brew. Pours a bright, clear orange color; creamy off-white head with forever lacing; great pour. A basic aroma of sweet fruitiness, nondescript; some orange and earthy hoppiness comes into play; still, lax. Medium-to-full mouthfeel: very sweet, sticky candy sugar and candied orange sweetness; a very disappointing, flabby presence in the mouth; one-sided sweetness. Lasting finish: the candy sugar and oranges eventually dissipate into a basic bitterness that should have appeared long before this.

UPDATED: OCT 19, 2009 Tap @ Witsend pub in Hill crest.  Pours a deep lightly hazed copper color with a small off white head.  faint aromas of citrus hops and some metallic maltiness.  Flavor was also very grainy with some hop bitterness.  I would like to try this beer again out of a tulip (not a pub glass like it was served in) and not after a long ass day, and Ill re rate it.

Sampled again at Blind Lady on October 18th.  Nice citrus peel and overall better flavor than the first time I tried it.

On tap at PP CBad. Pours clear copper with a  moderate sized white head that leaves spider web lace. Smells bitter and slightly metallic hoppy with some sygary sweetness as well. Tastes bitter hoppy right up front but after that its all caramel, cereal malt sweetness. Lingering sugary flavors and a bit of hops. Full body, slightly syrupy, good carbonation.

Draft at Small Bar. Cloudy bright orange hue with soapy sustaining white head. Nose is huge citrus hops, mostly sweet grapefruit, with a hint of pine. Flavor is big bitter hop flavors immediately which transition to citrus and light fruits, then pine and grass, nice bready malt backbone throughout, finishes on the sweeter side. Medium-full bodied, thick and sticky texture, moderate carbonation. An uber bitter/hoppy IIPA, good malt balance, alcohol presence is not overwhelming.

On tap at Stone 8/20.  Clear amber with a white head.  Strong lace.  Stinky hops nose.  Seriously stinky in a really good way.  Taste is lightly hoppy, nowhere near as strong as the nose.  Light mouthfeel and light finish.  Good.

Draught. 
Amber fall colors. Big citrus hop aroma. Crisp, clean body. Big aroma hop flavor, medium bitterness. Fruity and clean for a big beer. Nice, refreshing and drinkable.

Tap @ Baileys Taproom...  Poured into snifter an amber/dark orange with a bubbly, white head.  Intense aroma of big hops.  Thick, syrupy palate, a big bomb of hops and alcohol heat.  Some malt grains to balance, but an overall, sweet, boozy quality to the brew.  Some herbal tea leaves with a giant hop bitterness to the finish.
On tap @ Toronado.  Pours a clear copper color with a small white head.  Quite a hoppy, herbal aroma.  Tasty, hoppy body; very herbal with hints of pine and malt.  Bitter, but refreshing.  Tasty!

Fantastic DIPA that deserves regular rotation. First, lets get the Union Jack comparison out of the way. Double Jack is smoother with more sweet caramel malt and hoppier with quite a bit more fruit flavor. On to the review... Double Jack pours a bright orange-yellow without much in the way of head, but its always difficult to judge head when the beer is too cold and on tap. The aroma is simply wonderful. Its a blast of candied pine, tangerines and grapefruit rind. The sweet malt is noticeable, but the hops are clearly the focus. The flavor is rich with hops, much like the aroma. The malt backbone provides good sweetness. Its well-balanced on my scale of DIPAs, anyway, which is to say not balanced but not quite as bitter as some. The flavor also imparts some other fruit flavors, apricots, peaches, other lighter stone fruits. I found the fruit flavors more varied and fuller than nearly any other DIPA Ive tried. The feel is round and strong without any cloying sweetness or bitter astringency. Drinkability is quite good for the size and style.

Wow!  Beautiful clear orange color with a moderate-light pale head.  Heavy citrus aroma, and a really hoppy, fruity, citrus flavor.  Quite drinkable for the high ABV, and very well balance.  Excellent.
A very nice iipa. Clear orange with a fizzy white head. Big grapefruit aroma and taste with a goodbitter bite and notes of caramel oak and vanilla.
on tap at the Ojai Bev Co. Excellent brew with twice the bite as the regular union jack. Love this beer.

On tap at Pizza Port Solana Beach, after attempting to get a pint at Toronado the night before. Pours a toasted gold color with a small frothy white head. Aroma is mild potpourri with citrus and crisp hops. Very nice. Flavor shies away from the aroma, not in strength but in character, as I expected a much more prominent pine needle overtone. Malt profile is well balanced underneath, with a moderately thick body. Finish is characterized by short-lived grapefruit and medium bitterness.

At Najas Place on Tap

Appearance:  Pours a vibrant golden amber with a 1/8 inch of off white foam.

Aroma: Light whiffs of pine and grapefruit.

Taste:  A large mouthful of grapefruit that is followed by a piney flowery mango blast finishing moderately bitter.

Mouthfeel:  Medium bodied. About the same viscosity as Union Jack.

Overall:  Way more balanced than I had anticipated.  I wouldnt have minded it being offensively hoppy, but it just wasnt.  A really great beer.

Came in a wine glass at the Rose and Crown, a nice dark red-gold. Smell isnt very strong, but the taste packs a bitter wallop. I think Id prefer a bit less bitterness, but this makes for a great beer to sip over the course of an hour or so.

UPDATED: JAN 23, 2011 On tap at Najas in Redondo Beach, Ca. Big floral aroma. Flavors are gloriously mango and pineapple summer fruits. Very balanced and way easy to drink. I hope this beer makes the regular rotation from Firestone. 

1/23/11: upgraded from a 4.1 to a 4.5. Shared a bomber with some friends, we had this after having Hoptimum (which was excellent) but this was even better. More on the mango/kiwi/passion fruit end. Great creamy texture and just deliciously refreshing.

On Tap. White head clear bronze body. Hoppy goodness aroma, mango, exotic fruits, caramel and table sugar. Taste is  mango and exotic hops (no other way to describe it; it is a jungle of hops!) nicely balanced out caramel malt backing. Medium carbonation. Great.

Had on tap at Stone Brewery. Poured a golden copper color with nice little head.Aroma was sweet with some citrus. Very well balanced IPA with some good malt on the back of the palate. Not bitter but rather smooth. I really liked this stuff.
Peaches, caramel, and florals in the aroma and flavor. Thick and frothy mouthfeel. A better than average double IPA.
Bright sunny gold, sticky white head.  Resiny aroma of blended hops.  Some honey sweetness stands up a bit to the powerful gummy hop drippings.  This balance continues into the finish, great job.
On tap at Sacramento Brewing. This amber ale poured with a decent beige head and a floral aroma. The flavor is fairly well-balanced between caramel malt and hop bitterness. Very mellow and tasty.

On tap. Clear amber golden with a yellowish beige head. Intense aroma hops in the nose - peach in particular - with loads of caramel. Quite full-bodied, lots of caramel and fruit with great hoppy peach accents. Yum. 090709

On tap at Beachwood BBQ.  Pours orange-amber with a small cream colored head and tons of lacing.  Aroma is a blast of wonderful, juicy, piney-citrus hops.  Jeez, there as a bunch of orange, watermelon, grapefruit, and pine in there.  Palate is full-bodied, thicker than most DIPAs, a chewy but satisfying liquid.  Flavor holds a bunch of hops, though the first sip seriously reminded me of the malt-balanced approach of Union Jack IPA.  There is, undoubtedly, a ton of flavor here.  What I find interesting is that besides the caramel malt that can be picked up on, Double Jack is essentially a fruit assault  both citrus and sweet.  Great beer all in all.

16 ounce sample at the Davis Graduate.  Significant orange-lemon-pine nose with some bright sugary sweetness.  Smells like Apple Jacks cereal in a way.  Transparent orange body with a smallish off-yellow head.  Sweet, citrus orange/tangerine hop flavors to start, before this becomes sticky and malty in the middle.  Finishes with a catty, metallic, spicy hop bitterness.  No ethanol..  Extremely balanced.  This is a hell of a beer!!

Tap at Sac Brew. Pours a pretty orange/copper with a largish creamy beige head. Seems full bodied. Carbonation is quite creamy. Hop is strong and citric.  A really smooth and pleasant brew with a deal of bitter. Bitter coats the mouth. In a creamy sort of way. Its very surprising and pleasant. Its very thick. No hop shortage in Paso Robles.

Draft at Brouwers.

Deep orange and super-pretty w/ a small head. Stronger, smoother version of the Union Jack. Again, lovey juicy amora. Big over-the-top orange-lemon hoppiness, malts there but not overly roasted (+1)  .

Draft. Amber beer with a cream colored head. Big grapefruit and summer fruit aroma. Sumemr fruit and light grapefruit flavor with sweet caramel. Medium-plus bodied. Good bitterness. Summer and grapefruit lingers with caramel. Expected a little more bitterness, but its very nice.

From tap at the brewery. Pours clear golden orange with a small white head. Dense hopy fruity aroma, wooden, grapefruity and mild tangerine. Sweet and smooth hops fruity. Nice mellow set of citrusy fruity flavours. Mild sweetness to a smooth bitterness into the far finish.

Tap at City Beer in SF.  Nice light copper color with an off-white head.  Amazing aroma of sweet malt and loads of citrusy hops.  Flavor somewhat sweet with a well-balanced citrusy hoppiness thats big but not too intense.  Palate somewhat syrupy and fairly full.  Great stuff.

Draught at Toronado during RBSG09.   This really is just concentrated Union Jack.   the malt is just a bit sweeter, the hops pack more of a punch, and the alcohol is slightly more evident, though still well concealed.   Its good, but Im already a big fan of Union Jack and this doesnt bring a whole lot new to the table.   I do appreciate all the effort it took to get such an intense hop aroma in there though.   Since it is not very widely available, I can see myself indulging when I get the chance, but I wouldnt pay more for it if it came in bottles on the shelf next to its little brother.   I think that FW has to start from scratch to make a winner of a DIPA.

Eighth rating of the beer.  Tap at the brewery.  Nose was really sharp, bright, and contained sweet hop, flower, grapefruit, peach juice.  Flavor was mostly just sweet hops and alcohol - maybe too much alcohol (the kind that is so bright it can disguise itself as pungent hop).  Maybe mild apple juice and faint malt in the flavor as well.  I simply feel as though I have tasted this beer before.

On-Tap @ Baileys Taproom poured into Snifter glass.

Pours a brilliant reddish-orange that radiates from the glass and has a bubbly off-white head that dissolves into a swirly fine layer around the glass. The aroma is fresh citrus hops with some toasted malt in the background. The flavor is piney and citrusy hops upfront and is accompanied by some a nice touch of malt and finishes with a grapefruit bitterness. Its full-medium bodied and has a nice amount of carbonation. This beer absolutely blew me away. The aroma smells like a basket of hops and the flavor doesnt let you down. In my opinion this is far superior to my encounters with Pliny. This just has a nice malt backbone to accompany the delicious bouquet of hops.

UPDATED: AUG 14, 2009 At the brewpub, it was clear copper colored and a hop bomb, no balance. 
I was expecting a bit more balance and complexity
Had a sample at the brewery before release date.  For an imperial it is nicely balanced and doesnt blast you with hops.

Tap at Toronado. Wow, this stuff is great and dangerous, hides alcohol incredibly well and is so smooth. Pours with a copper color. Nice aroma of hops and caramel and some citrus. Flavor is pine, grapefruit some orange, but offset with lots of caramel and butterscotch. Very complex and smooth brew.

On tap at Brouwers. Crap theres a lot of hops in here. Pours a transparent orange, with a smallish head. Hop oils on the nose, and not much else. Citrus - grapefruit and some sweeter mandarin. Dry aftertaste, but this is a quencher up until then, which I was a bit disappointed about. I wanted this to be a big palate bomb, but it turned out to be more delicate. Its good, but no Pliny - I think I actually like the regular Union Jack better.

On tap at Brouwers Cafe.  Pours a clear copper golden color with a small creamy off white head.  Aroma is fresh and intensely hoppy, mostly citrus and pine with some hints of caramel.  Flavor is strong and hoppy with a perfectly balanced malt backbone.  Finishes dry with moderate bitterness.  Full bodied with nice moderate carbonation.

7/1/09 on draft at Bottleworks, Seattle, Wa. Aroma is fairly sweet, with moderate caramel malt balancing bitter flora of roast citrus and pine. Appearance is nearly clear honey gold with a moderate maintained white head and LOTS of legs. Flavor is extremely rich, but with no harshness. No individual flavors dominate, with characteristics of honey, pine, grass, orange rind and roasty earth all playing fairly with each other. Mouthfeel is full bodied, just shy of syrupy, with a low carb texture. Overall, this big brew goes down way too easy for all thats packed into it; almost as if it has been aged, a notable contrast to all the fresh flora shining through.
